I also personally disagree that a high growth fintech should be valued as a legacy bank most of which have sub 10 rev growth. If their tech platform really accelerates and gets deals with large financial institutions itll be hard to ignore its part of the valuation delta vs banks. Theyve also leaned into originating for other companies no capital loan origination and loan servicing revenue where they dont take on risk. Its possible that growth completely stagnates in 27 but I dont think itll be that mature of company by then. Right now massive tailwinds for company with interest rate cuts, regulatory changes driving demand for tech platform, significant demand for loans for higher income individuals which is Sofia bread and butter. Im extremely bullish over next year , not necessarily beyond that as there wont be as much comparative tailwinds.

Gsat 1.13 Globalstar is planning to launch up to eight satellites in 2025 to replenish its LowEarth Orbit LEO constellation. The satellites will be launched by SpaceX and are intended to support Apples satellite emergency messaging service. Here are some details about the launch Contract Globalstar contracted SpaceX to launch the satellites for 64 million. Satellites The satellites are being built by MDA, a Canadian manufacturer, and Rocket Lab is supplying the satellite bus. Funding Apple is paying for 95 of the launch and manufacturing costs, and is also lending Globalstar 252 million. Launch window Globalstar aims to deploy the satellites before the end of 2025. Launch failure Globalstar plans to launch additional satellites within months of a launch failure to maintain service quality and safety Globalstars constellation will consist of 48 LEO satellites, with four spares in orbit. The systems software is located on the ground, which makes it easier to maintain and upgrade.

I dont know whats more concerning, the post itself, or that 70 of the comments dont even seem to understand what OP is literally saying. Dude. If you want to stay in META, then stay. If you sell and take your profit and then put it in META again, you are literally doing nothing except paying taxes. Do you understand how a stock works? It doesnt matter how much in profit you are, all that matters is how much money do you have in total in META. Lets say you invested 500 in META, now 100 in Profit so your total position is 1000. If you sell that and put 1000 in META again, you accomplished nothing. You have the same position as before, except that you payed tax.
Why would you sell it to repurchase what you already have? That is the biggest thing that confuses me about this. If you are going to sell a portion of it, invest that money somewhere else.

This is probably the weirdest, most braintwisted idea Ive heard when it comes to stocks. Not the worst, but the weirdest. It literally doesnt make a difference to hold or sell and immediately rebuy except for fees and taxes you have to pay and cosmetic differences.

To sell and buy again doesnt get you anywhere. It might initially seem like you are locking in your gains, but when you repurchase your cost basis is the new purchase price. There is no free lunch. About the only time something similar to this happens is if you can offset the profits with some losses from selling some losing stocks. That reduces your taxes. But there is also a restriction that you cant rebuy the stock you sold for 30 days.

It depends on the size of your profit and what you need. If you need your profit to cover expenses or for something you are saving for, you can shave off some of it everytime you make a profit. Leaving a stock too long without looking at it comes with a risk. For example, you may be in 10 profit in week X, but after a couple of weeks it may be down again by 15 and all of it is gone again. This way you can never realize your gains and lose more time. I advice to always look at it at least once a week. On the other hand. If you want to diversify for example not all eggs in one basket, you can use the profit to reinvest in a different stock and leave your original investment in your previous stock.

Youre getting such mixed responses and differing views, I think, because this is one of the hardest conundrums that investors face, insanely hard. For me, I look at fundamentals now and going forward along with valuation to decide when and if to trim a position. Ill give you a couple of examples of recent trims and an example of where I havent and my thoughts on your situation. Itd be interesting to look back at this comment a year from now and see if my decision was wise. ANET has been one of my best performers. Bought it at 150ish after Nvidias marketshaking May quarter when the AI craze truly started. In hindsight, I should have bought Nvidia, but ANET felt like it could have more material upside given how unknown it was to the general investing public. Anyway, fastforward to this week. I finally trimmed it. I still have a position in it, but its valuation seems to be getting ahead of its skis and given managements penchant for conservative guides, I could see a disappointment in the cards. Couple that with potential election volatility, I thought I could get a better reentry point. So far, Ive been right. Almost to the dollar I topticked it but I feel apprehension about it. Its hard to trim a stock thats at the forefront of its industry when its industry is at the forefront of new capital allocation. That being said, well see. SITM This one I felt more comfortable trimming. I sold my costbasis after 100 gain. While the companys revenue has cyclically bottomed, I think investors speculators are pumping and preparing to dump this thing. Just about topticked it. Ill get back in if it drops materially. Now when it comes to Meta, heres a company thats at the forefront of AI in actually delivering the product to customers. No matter what people think about the picks and shovels, the companies that can actually make it useful for people will be the real winners. Meta may be one of the true monetizers of AI. On top of that, theyre a cashflow machine helmed by a man who has a newfound appreciation for efficiency. At the same time, hes not afraid to innovate. On top of that, Reels is a real competitor to TikTok, and now they have an X competitor. Instagram remains a strong, growing asset. Facebook is the old workhorse. Falling out of favor with many, it still generates insane revenue. On top of that, its not expensive on a forward basis. To me, Id trim this thing only tactically and get back in quickly.
You can spell enough to cover your cost and implied tax, and then the rest is free money that stay as meta forever if that makes you feel better.

Id trim it tactically, only, with a view to get back in quickly. Meta is an innovator and a cash machine that trades at a very reasonable forward basis with extremely valuable IP. Those are the stocks you ride unless something truly looks to threaten its place at the forefront.

replies.text: Companies will do a stock buyback when they have excess capital and think the share price is undervalued. Its a good thing. The best time to sell UAL is the moment you have a better opportunity to deploy the capital, and not a second later.

I am also a UAL holder. For how buybacks work, I would watch the Joseph Carlson buyback video on YouTube. The gist of it is that the companies purchase and retire their own shares, meaning less are available and the earnings per share is greater both positive and negative going forward. Generally a great thing because additionally, a company buying their own shares shows investors that they think their stock is cheap internally. As for when to sell, I doubt youll get a specific and correct answer, airlines seem to be cyclical, but are also on a huge upswing with travel demand projected to stay high and fuel being cheap. I guess before it goes down however whenever you are comfortable taking a profit works too.
Stock buybacks reduce shares, boosting value per share. Timing your sell depends on price outlook.

Stock buyback, especially for airlines, is the absolute dumbest way to spend your money. It basically means that you have no better way to spend money on improving the corporations. Delta for example blew over 15 BS on buybacks, while flying antique airplanes... bought the shares high...then begged the government for a bailout during the pandemic.. There always will be a downturn in that kind of business. Save for that rainy day or pay down debt.

How does the buyback help the company in the context of their stock being undervalued? If they were to sell it back at a profit Id understand but everything Ive read says most likely they just reabsorb the stocks. And let me rephrase the bonus question How will the buyback affect stock price which influences when Ill sell?

The best time to sell UAL is the moment you have a better opportunity to deploy the capital, and not a second later. Noob question, but why not a second later? Did you mean UAL share price tends not to drop but also not to rise much?

Say you have a company worth 1M and it has 1000 shares outstanding. So each share is worth 1000. If the company buys 100 shares back, there are only 900 left. If the companies worth hasnt changed, then each share would now be worth 1111. In a simplistic theory like that example stock price goes up, and many times in practice share price will also increase with buyback but there are a lot of variables in practice since company values fluctuate and the company has to spend assets to perform the buyback

replies.text: I go online and get advice from people who have no background on finance or valuation

I listen to Bloomberg every morning for a few hours, it is free if you have Samsung TV. I also read articles on Yahoo, Seeking Alpha, the WSJ and any money magazine in the doctors office. Come up with your own strategy. I buy stocks that are 20 below their 52week high, pay a decent dividend and have rising sales and earnings. And I love bad news for good companies. Sometimes those are the best buying opportunities. INTC, ABBV, CRWD are all in my portfolio due to bad news and they are all in the green.
From Reddit of course. You have any tips for me?
I look for irrational drops large oneday drops as a starting point and find out why they got hammered. If its an overreaction Ill give it a shot. Its worked well

I tend to ignore most people because they just like to spread their propaganda for whatever theyre in or their opinions. I simply tend to just Google what Im looking for. I dont over complicate it. What are the various PEs, RSI, how has company done, professional analyst opinions and why they hold them, recent financial reportsguidance, general industry trendsoutlook, how politics and world events coming up and in the present might play into it, etc. Also, very understated, generally know what a company truly does inside and out. If you only know surface level information you probably shouldnt invest in a company. Know the products andor services, industry, and leadershipfuture plans. I ignore all those stupid line graphs people make to try to predict the future. They mean nothing generally and people just try to use them to paint the picture they want. I tend to mostly just ETFmutual fund invest to avoid the hassle but I do, do some individual picking sometimes. Works good for me
TradingView, Yahoo Finance, my broker
see news, think what will happen in 6 months. example. hurricane season. happens every year. did you buy home depotlowes in march?

Off late I have a 3045min conversation with ChatGPT voice mode on my drive tofrom work. For example I say meta is scheduled to build many data centers over the next decade to meet its compute demands, what public companies can benefit from this? Then ask follow ups. I do this across various industries and companies. This has been a great way to learn and find some gems.

I just read a lot of finance news from Google News and Yahoo Finance to make long term investment decisions. I dont think we can get or react to any hot news or insider tips faster than hedge funds, so trying to make money based on any immediate news isnt likely to happen. However, you can make long term decisions based on whats happening in the world. For example, Tesla Robo Taxi reveal is a big news. Now you have to decide what does that mean. Does it mean Tesla is likely going to make a lot of money or maybe its competitor will be successful. It gives you some direction to start your research.

I work in semi, so I typically hear my network griping about how things are going internally. Layoffs , morale , monumental fuck ups etc. I dont think anyone with zero technical insight can really rate a company like that effectively, making analysts even more of a joke. The production issues on 13th14th gen parts were monthly news for over a year in tech outlets, but not picked up any analysts until it reached crisis point. Anyone in the industry at that point could easily infer the cause was a serious company failing, as it just doesnt happen at Intel. Or shouldnt Then without the issues, you could easily infer the huge problems with the products coming out each generation power usage out of control vs. competition. Power and temperatures being critical for their bread and butter, data centers and laptops. Investors Business Daily is a companydatabase created by William ONeil to provide individual investors with information so they can do their own analyses in one place and so they can make their own decisions without relying on others. Highly highly recommend reading How to Make Money in Stocks by ONeil and Profiting in Bull and Bear Markets by Weinstein. Take what you learn from these 2 books together, and use the information from IBD, and Im confident people wont need to rely on others for stock investments. They will answer your questions on when to buy, hold, sell. If you read them you wont need this sub and will be ahead of 95 of other people IMO. Note you can get some info for free but the paid subscription is worth it imo. Especially if you do your homework. Read those 2 books first as your homework, starting with ONeil. Then consider the IBD subscription. This changed me for the better. Hope this helps.

What youre referencing is separating signal from noise. Most information is irrelevant to long term returns. Boil down your strategy to its essence and search for information that fits that framework. For me I care most about superior management and industry disruption. Info on areas outside of that is nice but I dont focus on it. What is your competitive advantage and how are you expanding it? Thats all I care about

I dont do intradays, nor Im holding for few weeks. I hold for long time more than a year and I sell whenever I feel so. The only short term 34 months investment I made was JPM, when SVB collapsed. It seemed to me a good idea to invest in some big bank too big to fail and apparently I was right even though it was some sort of a gamble. In any case I made a 20 profit in just 34 months.

If you dont want to find a financial expert, and youre parking money for a few weeks or months, then you shouldnt be making any decisions on the run, in the fist place Im referring to your other comment. Instead, make time to study one specific company and stock indepth, using the multiple solutions given to you above. That way, you get a crosssection of feedback on that particular stock. Its not going to get any easier for you than that.

I know that aluminum bottles typically need plastic to seal correctly. However, if we remove that plastic and its metal on metal, its going to grind aluminum dust into your beverage isnt it?
Im just wondering if ball will make more cans and I should buy the stock, im not too bothered either way about the plastic for The scope of this post
Im not sure this is accurate. I work in the can making industry, we make cans for pepsi. 0 plastic involved. We use a lacquer as a wear resistant coating. I work for balls competitor.

Canada got rid of plastic straws and single use grocery bags. Its been terrible and makes very little difference. The paper straws dont last through a coke from McDonalds and theres reports of the crap in the paper straws being not great for us. The reusable bags at the grocery store are a great concept, BUT, if you forget to pack them, you buy another one. I currently have like 200 reusable bags. Apparently they use like 40x as much plastic as the single use. And still not recyclable. In any given day at work, I create more garbage than I do at home in a year. Although the sentiment is nice, and yes, we should be looking at ways to cut back our impact on the world around us, there are much better places to shift our focus than plastic straws bags and bottles. I just opened this Minecraft toy craft thing with my son. Its full of goo filled with glitter and foam sand that is impossible to clean. Crap like that should be outlawed first. An innocent gift from my sister, she didnt know whats in the box. But it was 90 plastic waste with a little mini figure that he will keep in the end. Theres a ton of different variations of these flashy boxes of garbage being sold as toys, like smasher eggs and treasure x sets. Marketed to children, very flashy box. No decent toy in the end and a never ending pile of nonrecyclable trash.

To clarify I am not defending a position one way or the other. I think some things will work and some are boneheaded but in this exact instance Im just wondering if ball will make more money if consumer driven or regulation pushed demand grows the need to make more cans.
This is unrelated but dang dude ur vocab in ur writing is great! How did u reach this level of clarity and coherence?
They did aerospace for a bit, but the majority of their money comes from packaging. So Im interested in the thesis that they will make more money given their skillset in this area.
Im not defending an anti plastics position Im simply interested in making money, hence am kicking the tired and asking if there is scope for the company to grow.
Yes
When googling and whenever I cut open a Can I have seen a plastic lining. Might be a Europe thing though?

As a fellow Canadian I wish they had just banned single use straws period. The paper straws are awful and restaurants keep giving me the straws whether I want them or not. Its just a lot of wasted resources when I am perfectly capable of drinking without a straw. The only reason to need a straw is if you are 2 or 90 or they put a mountain of ice in the cup for a tiny amount of liquid.
there is scope but not rapidly

My biggest beefs are you cant finish a slurpee with a paper straw, and kids cant finish their juiceboxes before the straw melts. Ive also noticed places like AW are now giving 2 kids, one with a straw hole and the other without. Other places have switched from paper to plastic cups. So not really cutting down on the plastic. Just giving us useless plastic instead

I think my concern with China is that the last 5 years or so have seemed like a cycle of 1 new regulationcrackdown largely on tech, which is where Id be primarily interested, 2 stocks go down, 3 China walks back regulationoffers stimulus, 4 China stocks are so back and after enough of a bounce the cycle goes back to 1. And while these names have had a good run lately, looking longer term Tencent is now almost back to the 2018 peak. When I think about names in China that Id most like to own longterm thats certainly at or near the top of the list, but its also clear that the government does not like the sector and they can do what they want but theres other places to invest. Im looking for at least medium and preferrably longterm holdings, optimally Tencent is a good, wellrun company but I feel like investing in China is and maybe things will change at some point? trying to time the 3 part of the cycle above and sell before 4 is over and the cycle starts again. If say gaming is going to be something thats going to continually encounter regulations in China, Id rather look at a TTWO still around the level where it announced the GTAVI trailer and which is above 2018 highs. Im not against China and great to anyone who did well with the recent move although some of the BABA discussion in particular feels like a fair amount of this, given how many times people have tried to call the bottom in recent years even after the recent move its still down 36 over the last 5 years while AMZN 115. I avoid Chinese stocks for a few reasons. First of all, you dont actually own the stock, foreign investors arent allowed to own Chinese stocks. What youre buying is an ADR run by a Cayman Islands based shell corp. They can close this loophole for any sector such as online education at their whim and youre left holding nothing. Secondly, you cant trust Chinese balance sheets, their regulation isnt anything close to a first world nation. Finally, if you dont understand Guanxi business culture, you have no idea what youre getting into as a foreign investor.

There are 100k gas stations in China, so they have a lot more room to build even internally. The problem is scaling production and so much money was already thrown into them, while payouts from utilization are yet to bear fruit. I think cash flow will dramatically increase in coming years and give the company room to grow. The negative scenario is that competition is very tough inside China and tariffs will impact somewhat the chane to sell to Europe and USA. I still believe that selling to MENA, Latam, Russia, UK, Norway, etc. is sufficient to bring global numbers up. The deal they made with Dubai will give them more exposure to the Islamic part of the world which has the cash to afford their more premium vehicles.

China underwent a huge shift under Mao. This is well known. But in the last 30 years, every big mouth analyst and their mother has been saying to invest in China saying insane things like their economy will zoom ahead of the USA by 2020 and so on. Of course that date keeps getting pushed forward and in reality, they fell behind the USA since 2000. The mania was real and it keeps coming back every few years only to thud again. The stuff you are seeing on their street today is tech creep. Creep has been rather brisk the last 30 years. It wasnt China specific. Pics of high growth USA cities over the last 30 years are stark but if you want to see something like China, check out Panama, Thailand, Singapore, Qatar, Dubai, Brazil, Malasia, and im sure we can find many more if we try. All of them had huge leaps forward thanks to tech advancement and creep. That in itself, if not remarkable. Its the history of human civilization.

Stop using a brokerage account like a checking account and your problems will magically disappear. There are no shortage of free online checking accounts.

It takes Fidelity 1 2 business days to sell an ETF and have your money in cash in the account, and then another day or two to deposit the money into your bank account, which then takes another day or two to clear the transaction. In all, you have the money at your disposal 3 to 6 days after placing a sell order. Typically 3 4.

I see these posts about Fidelity all the time and as a customer for over a decade, I have no experienced this. My friends Venmo me alllll the time and I send the money to my CMA and can withdraw it the next day. Not to dismiss your issue, its just weird is all.

Just because Apple builds their own devices doesnt make it not anticompetition or monopolistic.
Sorry I had to get the time out fricken DOJ

so an app developer can get a bigger of the pie depends on if the app developer passes on the savings in the form of lower prices for example, Twitter Blues subscription is cheaper when purchased in a browser as opposed to from the app which requires Twitter to remit IAP commissions to AppleGoogle

only if their app store marketshare becomes dominant its the reason why Apple could preinstall Safari on Macs and Microsoft got in trouble for preinstalling Internet Explorer on Windows back during the browser antitrust era

Google got caught red handed paying phone manufacturers to preinstall Google Play and shut out other app stores, thats a very low hanging legal fruit in the antitrust world Intel got busted for something similar many years back, giving bulk discounts on Intel chips to PC makers on the condition they dont use AMD chips
Google obviously paid the wrong people lol
Not sure why youre being downvoted phone is clearly not suitable for their needs, so... The best thing to do is stop buying it.
I never said it wasnt. I was just giving the reason outlined in the case.

I dont see why Samsung would continue to obey that agreement they probably wont although Im curious to see what kind of clauses are in these agreements for contract termination in the event of a judicial antitrust order and ironically enough, the other antitrust case on browser search engines also focused on Googles billion dollar deals with Apple and Mozilla to make Google the default search engine on Safari and Firefox Apple will probably shrug off the deal termination given their size, but Mozilla will lose a huge chunk of their revenue Xiaomi or Oneplus who already do the same in China with their own stores China already has a very competitive Android app store market TencentBaiduXiaomiOppoHuaweiAppChinaFlymeVivoetc., granted some of those are also because of preinstallation XiaomiOppoHuaweiVivo, but no single device manufacturer is dominant and hence no single device manufacturers preinstalled Android app store has a market monopoly a lot of it is also attributed to the absence of Google services and the Google Play store there, but for overseas markets outside China, those device makers install Google Play because no one will buy those Androids if they dont Huawei and ZTEs overseas phone business also got hammered after the US government banned Google from doing business with them, so theres also an additional push these days to move to opensource or CN homegrown software ecosystems that cant be unilaterally rugpulled by the US gov

Fair enough, but going to TwitterXs website gives you a little bit of secure feeling. I used to play a game named Kings of Avalon, its a P2W type of game that finally got too expensive to play. Needless to say I never meet a single player outside our handful that were Chinese inside our kingdom that purchased them. Chiefly among the reasons is I didnt want to hand over all of my data to a Chinese company. Its bad enough American companies fuck me raw without even a curtesy spit when it comes to data, I dont need Chinese companies doing it as well. That and at least if something bad happens because of a data leak or misuse I can at least sue the American company, winning is another discussion, with a Chinese company I would only get laughed at.

Google needs better lawyers. Im not sure how Apple can get away with it while Google cannot, and the judge things itll be less monopolistic for Google to suddenly turn around and say Android is exclusive to Pixel phones! and think thats better for the industry.
Google got busted paying money to phone manufacturers to preinstall Google Play and no other app stores that kind of legal red flag is something Apple was able to avoid
Right, and so its best to avoid it by Google making their own phones and their own OS exclusive to their hardware. Is that what the judge prefers?

I think under that scenario another software company will take over the market for all the nonPixel Androids by forking the open source code or a third mobile OS like Windows becomes viable if Google is exiting the market for nonPixel Android OSes

Sounds like an absolute nightmare and further locks people into their own bubblesbrands, or makes people hesitant to spend money in the first place since their purchases wont carry over despite it being the same OS. There is no good solution for this and so Apple should not be allowed to do the same. Microsoft resolved this nonsense with PCs in thr 80s and Google with Android since Symbian didnt go anywhere. Lets not go back in time please.

since their purchases wont carry over despite it being the same OS most apps are subscriptionbased now Microsoft resolved this nonsense with PCs in thr 80s Microsoft was actually in danger of being split up into separate companies, one for Windows OS and one for Office and Internet Explorer software Microsoft finally compromised and allowed more access to private Windows APIs for other software makers to avoid the antitrust breakup and in Europe, Microsoft allowed multiple browser choice selections at Windows OS setup to settle that antitrust suit whats most likely is that Google makes a similar deal where they allow alternate app stores to be installed on all Androids and stop their exclusivity deals with OEMs Google Pixel has piss poor hardware marketshare so if Google went the route youre imagining, its likely the forked Android OS gets dominant marketshare maybe with Samsung, and the Pixelonly OS ends up dying due to the chickenandegg problem with Pixel phone adoption Apple should not be allowed to do the same Apple is already in trouble in EU and likely other countries more and more Apple is already required to allow 3rd party app stores to be installed on iOS and bypass IAP commissions in EU and its still possible Apple faces more US antitrust scrutiny, its just that Googles app store exclusivity deals with OEMs is such a blatant antitrust violation and legal lowhanging fruit, mirroring Intels problematic deals with PC makers in the 2000s to shut out AMD from their products

replies.text: I think the neutral interest rate is somewhere around 4. I expect a series of 25 basis point cuts with a target of 3.75 to 4.25 by the end of 2025.

Barring a major economic recession, its unlikely to go below about 4 I would say. The Fed was pretty aggressive with the last rate cut, but I see them going back to form with minor adjustments depending on how things are shaking. Even in a relatively medium grade recession, I doubt less than 23. It will only go below that if the economy blows up for some reason.
Just look at the most recent dot plot. Seems like Fed governors have a consensus ranging from 3 to 3.5
2.5 chance of 250275 would be lowest possible 50 chance of 325350 or higher

Im expecting the economy to have a tough time, post election. From here to end of 2025, Im completely guessing at a 175bp reduction. Im also guessing the economy will have a rough time, as well. However, with 16 of the last 17 jobs numbers reports revised down, after the fact, I feel like the feel good statistics are on their last legs. I have no experience or education in economics, just a gut feeling that things are going to get bumpy. The numbers dont match the sentiment

Median 3.5, lower bound 3, if anything goes wrong though. Unemployment really begins to ramp up, the stock market is off north of 10, unexpected events, thats how you get the Fed rate into the 2s. If youre looking to strategize interest rates, the easy trade is being short atm puts on rate products that expire, maybe January 2026. While I think we probably have 6x 25 point cuts between right now and the end of next year, this strategy doesnt really require that to play out. You just need things to not get worse from an inflationary perspective As long as you watch your deltas and overall exposure You have a pretty straightforward trade on your hands
I think we get 100 bps cuts this year and then another 150 next year. 3.5 seems like a good place for the Fed to go down to and then pause while they wait to see the effects from the cuts.

Its hard to see the Fed cutting rates below 3 in 2025, given the current economic factors you mentioned. With unemployment stabilizing and oil prices uncertain, along with the potential for inflationary pressure from geopolitical issues, the Fed might be cautious about making deep rate cuts. This environment could favor companies that benefit from higher rates, like payment systems e.g., PAYO, WISE.LSE. On the other hand, some retail construction companies with strong fundamentals, like LEN and MHO, might still be attractive investments even if rates stay elevated.
Luckily the fed publishes a report with expert projections that will be much more accurate than redditors. Figure 2 About 3.253.5.
deleted
3.754 if no recession. That said the economy Might just be strong enough for the fed to maintain 4.254.75 indefinitely
Ill be happy if I see it get below 5.5. the recent jobs report was disappointing for future cuts.

I dont see much reason for any major change. We might see .25 or .5 drop from here. But things are pretty stable right now and it will be tough for the fed to make the case for a major change UNLESS some outside factor happens, which is totally possible. The most obvious potential factor is if theres a regime change and Trump wins and then makes major policy changes that have some form of economic impact at home or abroad. But aside from that, Israel is getting out of hand and may cause this localized conflict to become a bigger regional problem. The Arab governments are already unstable and their inaction against Israel has their citizens ready to riot. I was just in Turkey and there is constant discussions on the news, in the streets and in Taxis about the need for Turkeys military to join Iran and intervene. Also saw regular rallies and protests against Israel and America.
Im not going to believe any government numbers right now until after the election.
And the government would also have to stop printing so much money. That isnt going to happen.
that dot plot also assumed a 4.4 unemployment rate and 2.0 GDP in 2024. The GDP assumption is definitely wrong. The unemployment rate is probably too high unless if we tip into a recession this year.
Props for sharing this tool. I like to check it throughout the week beforeafter big data prints.
Why?
Quantitative tightening isnt happening, it stopped a while ago. The m2 money supply shows thiss
There will be well over 100 bps in cuts coming our way in the next year... we arent close to the neutral rate yet.

A large number of people are reportedly financially hurting right now. Our recent economic numbers have looked good, but they dont reflect how the average consumer has felt lately. Then, those economic numbers are often revised lower than initially reported, well after the fact. I dont think Ill ever short a stock in my life, its not my thing. And Im not going to stop buying at any point in the next 30 years or so. Im not any kind of bear. I just feel like the covid responsemoney printer broke the economy more than weve allowed ourselves to feel, so far. I think Powells doing a good job, but we printed a ton of money, and the government seems intent to continue spending more than they should. His job is damn near impossible, especially in an election cycle with two change candidates in the running. Ill be forever impressed if we avoid a recession. I just dont think were going to avoid one. It wont be the end of the world

Many Fed officials are kinda panicking, while trying hard to not look like it. Powell took the risk of starting the cutting cycle with 50 basis point, and probably tried really hard to convince multiple Fed officials to go along with the 50 bps cut I think Barkin, Waller, Schmid, Logan, Musalem, Bostic wouldve all preferred starting with 25 bps and 75bps total in 2024. 7 people wanted 75 bps total in 2024 and 2 wanted 50 bps cut total in 2024. So to start with 50 bps cut and only cut 25 bps in 1 out of 2 remaining meetings, just gives off an inconsistentbizarre message instead of 25 bps in each of the 3 remaining meetings. Even if the economy is fine, doing so really risks the financial market taking it the wrong way and thinking the Fed is worried about recession. So if market thinks so and sell off, that would kill consumer sentiments, and would lead to an actual recession. So thats the big risk. Theres really no huge benefit to 50 bps cut other than if the Fed needs to cut 75bps in the next meeting to react to a recession, they are in a better position to do so. If they cut 25 basis point in Sept and gave a really dovish speech, even saying theyll cut 50 bps in Nov, the market wouldve priced in more Fed cuts, and the net effect on financial condition wouldve been pretty similar. So I wasnt sure why they did the 50 bps cut for minimal benefits and huge tail risk. Its even more bizarre they made that decision during the blackout no communication period, which further gives the impression theyre panicking. As you can see below, were at the same restrictiveness as where we were in summer 2022 when Fed fund rate was around 2, and the loosening happened in May 2024, months ago. Of course lower inflation gave the Fed reason to cut 50 bps. But doing so 1.5 months early makes little difference, and they took huge risk of the market misinterpreting the message. So I dont know why they did that, if they werent actually concerned themselves. Maybe their local business contacts have been telling them negative things.

I see, thanks for explaining

replies.text: LLYs more diversified, has had success elsewhere beyond obesity their obesity drug is more highly regarded then NVOs. There is already discussion of the next generation of obesity drugs and NVOs CB1 drug didnt have great results the other week in terms of side effectsAE VKTXs drug is highly regarded, with lower side effects than most. Compared to LLY it seems like this company is more focused and leaner, which to me seems like a plus. It can be but thats often an it is until it isnt imo its great when the theme in question is big but the moment others start to become competitive Id be surprised if a large pharma co wo obesity exposure doesnt eventually buy VKTX andor trials start disappointing, the name is going lower. Id rather the more diversified company. I think the NVO selloff is overdone at this point, but not without some reason behind it imo. Interesting discussion of tirzepatide vs semaglutide
Isnt NVO being grilled by the congress for their pricing strategies?

I cant speak for other drugs, but Lilly is far ahead of Novo in the obesity medicine space at the moment. They may have gotten a head start with Ozempic, but Lilly now has more effective drugs in play that are no longer in shortages. Semaglutide OzempicWegovy is significantly less effective than Tirzepatide MounjaroZepbound. Retratutide is coming down the line soon enough for Lily and all indications are that it will be even more effective than Tirzepatide. No one wants a less effective weight loss plan, especially when youre talking about 1,000 per month for folks who pay out of pocket.
NVO has a forward PE of 29. I fail to see what the discrepancy here is. Stocks run up, then they rebalance to fair value. That fair value seems to be similar to LLY.
I mean with all the hype over the past year its expected to finally rebalance right? Just like the clean energy, EV, AI hype.
Im going with a NVO bounce back up to new high now that profit takes are gone. Buying more shares now
Now is the time to get 2026 calls
They are leaner than Lilly, but not in a good way in the US. recognize the gorilla in the room.
What are everyones thoughts on HIMS?
Buy GILD
HS pattern shows price target to 100. I dumped over a week ago. edit Came back a month later to say I told you so.
Profit taking. Any stock that runs up so much is at risk of dropping.
The stock is overvalued. Simple as that.

NVO will likely acquire Nanexa within months for their PharmaShell technology. Nanexas tech allows for monthly injections with lower side effects, due to the technology basically drip feeding the medicine. Theyre about 2 years in with a development deal with an undisclosed amount of substances. Nanexas own phase 1 with Liraglutide is about a month from concluding and theyve presented great results so far. Might give NVO the edge longterm.

If LLY cannot compound and supply tirzapetide and other simpler made GLP1 receptor agonist drugs, how is LLY going to supply is mass quantity their better GLP1 agonists? Also the CB1 drug failure was so fucking predictable its funnyWhy would you go after cannabinoid receptors when there are so many other better targets in the brain and mechanisms of action to go after? Of course the cannabinoid receptors are going to have more side effects if you modify them strictly.

Saw the CB1 results. This isnt necessarily a bad thing though. Drug companies might test out different types of drugs that treat the same things. Their CB1 drug isnt their frontrunner when it comes to the oral pills theyre researching, that would be amycretin. Each drug has a different approach to achieving weight loss. I think of it as them testing which one performs best overall. I agree on how being leaner isnt necessarily a good thing all the time. 40 of LLYs revenue comes from obesity and diabetes medication versus around 75 for NVO. All to say a sizable chunk of revenue for both companies is in this segment. But to be fair most of LLYs profit comes actually from other drugs. When it comes to companies like Viking Therapeutics my opinion is theyd still run into capacity problems that the bigger manufacturers are running into. In that regard I cant see it eating into LLY and NVOs sales.
Meanwhile congress just looking for insider trading

They are but when you compare, really LLY should be getting grilled for the same thing, and the PBMs should be getting called to hearings as well. To me it seems like election year virtue signaling. You have a regulatory body asking why unregulated drug list pricing is so high. Its their job to add regulations so that theres a cap. Practically every other country does, we dont and politicians at this point choose not to. In the case of obesity and diabetes PBMs drive up list prices during negotiations so they can get favorable rebates. PBMs are middlemen that are also publicly traded like Cigna and CVS so they stand to lose more performance wise if they dont keep those prices high. NVO could slash prices and still keep a very healthy margin and potentially even sell more volume, but if they dont agree to PBM list prices they risk getting removed from their formularies which means lower sales all together and people not getting medication from NVO. Its one major factor not all that causes the price of diabetes and obesity medication to be so high in the US but low everywhere else.
True, but not their fault. Just the messed up system of the US... like.. obvious?
NVO has been getting grilled by Congress for the last 15 years. Same song and dance but like in the past nothing substantial will come of it.

Ive heard Retratutide is better than CagriSema in how it works and has less symptoms. Theyre both injectables though and thinking towards the longterm personally I dont think injectables for obesity treatment are the future. For the longterm imo, the one who wins in the obesity space is whoever nails the oral treatment strategy, including having favorable cost and production capacity. That means amycretin vs orforglipron. I think people will prefer oral vs injectable at a slight cost to effectiveness. In that sense I lean towards focusing on that race for oral treatment over injectable treatments.
LLY is comparatively overvalued in my opinon

I agree that hype can drive up stock prices. But whereas AI and EVs are a market where people can lose interest and the value of such products services can change, you may NEED medication if youre morbidly obese and you NEED medication for some forms of diabetes. Additionally, you may prefer medication if youre not morbidly obese but feel the need to lose weight. In that sense its an industry based a little more on need rather than preference, and growing need at that ex. 14 people in China are obese up from just 8 in 2018.
I was hoping itd bounce back but it keeps dropping...

HIMS is something Im a bit weary of. They have an oral medication thats only a shortterm treatment, and its not a compounded medication so it would be less effective than your traditional GLP1. Plus from what I understand its 2400 upfront for a year or something like 250400 per month. Being noncompounded its not as effective and not intended to be a long term treatment. So it doesnt work for everyone and I dont think its covered by insurance. In that regard it sounds like a niche market. It should be noted that none of what it sells is FDA approved. Not sure if this would really affect their oral medications. As for the GLP1 HIMS recently began offering, this would be compounded and can be a longer term treatment, but my understanding is theyre only allowed to sell this in the first place because theres a shortage right now. Ifwhen Nordisk ends its shortage on GLP1s I think the FDA at that point would demand HIMS to pull GLP1s from their shelves. So yes, they do have that loophole to sell without approval because of the shortages, but at the same time we dont even know if HIMS is violating patents or is unsafe and ineffective as far as their GLP1s go. Personally, Im not a fan of tossing someone desperate to lose weight who took a 10 minute survey and never talked to a doctor some drugs to inject into themselves. Dont know if when all is said and done FDA approved GLP1 makers or the FDA would be okay with this either so IMO its sounding real risky.
Elaborate?

I hope youve seen LLY 4.5B investment announced today amongst a myriad of other investments to bolster their TZP manufacturing capabilities. They will absolutely be able to meet demand. And that doesnt take into consideration their potential upcoming weightloss pill that will allow further market penetrationconsolidation. Things look solid for LLY

I certainly like how NVO has a sole focus on obesity and metabolic health for their company. Their drugs like semaglutide are easier to make and compound, and distribute with more storied research behind them. I feel like most people do not know shit about the differences between these drugs, especially those pesky suits on CNBC.
Very possible
Oh okay...I figured the stock was dropping due to this congress thing. Still a solid long term stock
Im very curious to see how it will all eventually pan out. Given a choice at a similar cost I would prefer a once a week injectable over something I have to remember to take daily.
Believe it or not, its possible for multiple companies in an industry to be overvalued.

Im not an expert trader, let alone a regular trader, but as one thing I have realized is that the market can and will be irrational. I dont think everything can be explained. This 20 drop is probably insignificant in the grand scheme of things. If you got in a year ago this is just regular variability of a crazy hot stock. And sure, demand has probably increased over the past year, but I dont think revenue from this drug has increased dramatically from this drug to explain this 2x increase in company value. So to me, this just feels like FOMO and people wanting to take profits. Again, I do not have a finance background. But to your point, I dont think the company stock price will dramatically decrease, this miracle drug will continue to be in demand. What I obviously cant predict is how much higher the stock will go.
There is a technical pattern called head and shoulders that you see at the ends of trends. Its a reversal signal. Read more on the Google.

Comparatively NVO spent upwards of 10B already this year to expand their production capacity with a MA deal with Catalent. They announced those steps to improve production 8 months ago. This isnt including any internal investment. As I said earlier too LLY tends to prefer taking on debt as well for expansion, whereas Nordisk doesnt have their capital structure set up like this. Additionally, orforglipron Eli Lillys weight loss pill leads to 810 weight loss in 3 months whereas amycretin Nordisks leads to 13 in the same time period. Im just trying to understand why it seems the market is treating Nordisk as losing in this race when so far its future in this specific space looks brighter in terms of efficacy and production growth prospects. My point in all this is it makes sense the stock did drop in the short term, but 20 feels overblown given their longterm prospects havent dramatically changed.
Based on the market reaction it definitely seemed that way. Guess thats part of the risk of healthcare stocks.
For themselves to do
Yeah thats the one drawback of oral treatments, should be interesting to see once they roll out at scale what people tend to prefer.

you are probably in a very big minority. the only reason why im not on these drugs yet is because i dont like the whole aspect of injecting... and i suspect 95 of people are like me... give me this drug in a pill and im signing up in a queue on day 1.

I think the point is the industry has an estimated CAGR of 810 over the next few years and one of the two companies were discussing is much much closer to fair value and yet comparatively slid more than twice as much in the same period of time. Its not so much why it dropped, it makes sense that it did, its more so why its dropped so much.
Bro head and shoulders is shampoo

I dont know how much HS applies here, with news waves around congressional hearings and mixed runnerup oral pill results this added some noise to the charts. Some of that noise imo is shortterm. Im looking at this from a long term perspective. With all the shorter term noise aside, if its a failing business. Im not seeing why they would be, they they didnt take any substantial debt via MAs to expand their capacity which is impressive and often ran into a problem where they didnt have enough medication to distribute rather than not having someone to distribute to. Its still a problem but certainly a better problem to have.

Oh I totally understand all your points and its fair. What you are missing are the other investments Lilly has made including a previously announced 9B manufacturing facility in Lebanon, IN. None of that includes the myriad of other therapeutic spaces they are actively investing. I would also double check your data for orforglipron. Data presented by Lilly suggests weightloss up to 14 with statistically significant weightloss of 13 at a dose that appears to be lower than what NVO uses for their pill. I dont think folks are treating NVO as the loser but semaglutide is an older generation drug and LLY has started to outpace them. NVO will of course present some amazing next gen products including their triple agonist that is in development. At the moment LLY is the better bet but they will both see strong performance over the next 5 years with their own ups and downs.
LLY will drop too sooner or later. Both NVO and LLY had parabolic price moves upward. Neither is sustainable.
Price was 15 higher when I made that post. The pattern is dead on. The shampoo works too.

I agree some of the highs for NVO specifically felt premature given their product capacity issues. It those jumps also occurred close to announcements around amycretin which also probably added momentum. I will say their growth trajectory was notable over the past few years, and theres going to be some work on their end before it can start picking up momentum again. Seems like itll be some time before momentum builds up again.
Analysis ratings suggest a strong buy. Is that for long term horizon? Are you suggesting this correction soon?
I dont give a damn about analyst ratings. Theyre meaningless. I expect Novo Nordisk to continue to correct.
Correct to how much?

I like Quest protein bars and cookies. Theyre relatively expensive compared to brands like pure protein but very tasty. But a 20g protein bar could be too heavy for people who dont work out regularly. So, maybe the target audience is limited?

Why do you think distribution is a strong moat? The shelf space gives them an advantage against other start ups but is still tied to their own performance and bigger brands can still just substitute old products with new ones and be an immediate treat due to the low entry barrier. 23 of the category sales is through retail, so ecommerce is also not that important for snacksbars I would be really cautious about your assumption of a health conscious consumer. While I would agree that healthier eating is on the raise it doesnt mean plant based alternatives are also winning. Actually we know from trails at McDonalds and the evolution of plant based brands like Oatly that the demand might be limited. Simply Good Food does seem to be managed well as they are decreasing debt while increasing margins but for a growth stock the falling revenue growth is still a warning sign. Which seems to be reflected in the current stock performance. In general, I dont see a point in creating a 20 year strategy with single stocks. What might be a good stock now can be seen completely different in the 510 years because of bad management, macroeconomics, regulatory changes or consumer behavior shifts. If you believe in the category its probably more of an ETF or managed funds opportunity.

Whenever Im looking at a single stock investment, I always ask myself if I think the company will beat the passive part of my portfolio. Do you think this will beat the benchmarks lets say SPY or QQQ over the next 135 years? If so, why?

Quest choc. chip cookies are great, peanut butter are only ok but I prefer Think or Power Crunch for protein bars. Think brownie version are really dense so you can eat them slowly and get chew. Power Crunch are like sugar wafers so have an enjoyable crunch, crunch, crunch to them. Atkins Ive never tried, always too expensive. It seemed like they were marketing to keto people. If I were to research them for comparisons, I would look at the various sugar alcohols. Some things affect people differently maltitol, erythritol, chicory root etc. can make some peoples stomach churn.

Longterm exposure to a single stock is a romance with variance, and if the gods are on your side, youll end up very wealthy, potentially stinky wealthy even. But honestly, I dont have that level of risk tolerance.

there major red flags I should be aware of? When I look up the companys HQ address, it appears to be in some sort of Canadian TV building in an industrial area across from a closed weed dispensary and a discount flooring distributor. It does not look like a confidence inspiring medical device company HQ on the 2015 street view you can clearly see the address on the front of the building as per listed on their website. By the 2019 street view, it has faded off almost completely. Their US address seems to be some sort of Weworky coworking space. If you look up the Canadian address and their former business name Picomole there are pictures of the company in a meeting on the Google listing and it looks like some sort of Canadian microcap medical device version of The Office. This is a Canadian microcap medical device co in an early stage. At the midpoint of the proposed range, Breathe BioMedical would command a fully diluted market value of 54 million. IMO, when you are looking at that sort of microcap it becomes are there signs that the story might be less than advertised? Im not against investing in biotech IPOs if something appears compelling proof of concept this doesnt have that It is currently conducting a proofofconcept study, for which data collection will be completed in 3Q24, strong management, compelling IPtechnology, etc. but this doesnt check any boxes for me. I dont see any evidence of noteworthy biotechhealthcare investors taking interest as a private co. This is a very early stage name where I dont have a sense they can achieve what theyre setting out to do and even if they do, will probably be heavily diluted between here and there. No idea what it does as an IPO, but Ill feel comfortable saying no to this one. If they actually manage to do something eventually, I think theres time later on to determine whether to invest but looking at the name right now not confident given information available that that will happen.

Its biotech, you are always throwing dice with these. The product in these is always amazing if it ever works and becomes comercially viable. But you will never know if it passes trials or when, if the market will actually be interested and when, and if the margins make this a good business or not because nobody knows them yet. Nobody ever knows, even the scientists in the lab working for these companies do not know if anything will come out of it. Of course on the flip side, because they are super high risk you get a huge upside if you buy on a penny. So I am not saying biotech stocks are to avoid at all costs, just be aware it sounding great means little. You try to throw money at the better looking ones but you are still rolling dice. As for buying on IPO, I wouldnt be in a rush most IPOs go up on hype short term and then crawl down under IPO price for quite a while as the business proves itself. And in biotech expect great volatility no matter what.
biotech.....here today, gone tomorrow depending on a how test comes back
For every IPO that doubles your money or more, there are many more losers. The time to buy is after the hype is over and the stock has deflated... It might even be a good deal at that point.

There are so many biotechs that go nowhere and drop to otc penny status. Id say if you were to invest you should have a sub segment of your portfolio you play these. Not just one. Maybe 5 of your account in 5 or so. Just saying
I can say that I havent had much luck with IPOs and even less luck with Biotech, Medical, Pharmacies. The R D on new products, the FDA. It requires knowledge of the industry that I dont have.
The Thesis is just that... an idea that sounds plausible. Non invasive diagnostic tools have inherent error margins 1040 not accurate at all. Remember, Theranos?

Im also invested in Nvidia, Amd, and a couple smaller chip companies which are less related like Marvell and TSEM. replies.text: Could you name any other company in a dying industry that youd invest in, that has no business plan for their cash reserve? Im not busting your balls, just curious. me, I wouldnt invest in a coal power company knowing they have massive amounts of cash reserve, thinking that they could become the next name successful business entirely unrelated to coal power, but have no forward guidance, no plan that supports that transition, only random ideas from users on a social media platform.

I dont think the dismissal is solely because of the fan base type following. I think if you separate the name involved it just doesnt look like an appealing investment when assessing the information available against underlying businesses. Compare GME to some busted IPOs like MQ, FRSH, or PATH. They are all also debt free with 25 of their market cap value in cash. Blind the names. If you compared underlying fundamental metrics like balance sheet health with operating margins, recent growth, forecasted growth, etc, then would you really end up picking GME. Let alone if you compared to a GOOG, HD, or any random actual blue chip selection. The bull case you lay out when you ignore the name involved is basically that youre buying a SPAC, but one that happens to be tied to a business that more often than not loses money. That has resulted in it chasing additional financing which has diluted your share. I just dont see where that comes through as a clearly compelling investment?
Confidence is quiet.

Your whole pitch is theyre shuddering the legacy business and will deploy the cash once thats steady. But as youve also stated, upper management is telling investors nothing and gives no updates. With all due respect, this sounds like gambling. Youre betting on a positive outcome with no real information other than theyre shutting down their business and are sitting on a cash pile. 1. With the number of shares outstanding and a market cap made up mostly of their cash pile, any merger or acquisition wont move the dial. Its not like they can use 4 billion to buy a company earning 4 billion annually. 2. GME current PE is 170ish? If I take the idea that they are going to act like a bank, why would one target GME when you could get JPM at a PE of 13ish. The metrics alone tell me Im more likely to make money buying JPM than GME. 3. With no communication from management, this stock feels like a SPAC. But even SPACs had a timeline for acquisitions. Currently, GME can potentially burn this candle for a long time.

I think OP already stated the obvious. Downsize the legacy business until its no longer a liability. But thats literally it. Its legacy business will always be a liability, and they would be better of closing every store and liquidating everything and sit on cash. They would literally be more profitable.

Glad you posted this and I agree it is hard to find a reasonable discussion on this ticker. As many have commented here a business with a lot of cash, some small revenue stream and no known plan for deploying that cash is often perceived as not attractive. However, I would point out that is omitting the most important consideration price. The discussion here should be around at what price is it worth betting on Cohen, 4.5b, and minimal chance of bankruptcy? That price is where the market should clear and us traders should be looking to express a position in when our view diverges.

Easy to see how a bull could be passionate about the stock, as they see huge upside potential. So interesting seeing the odd off post about gamestop in random subs and seeing a few people absolutely hate on it, with as much passion as the other side of the coin. I think the bull case for Gamestop is the management team. I think RC is a once in a generation entrepreneur and Just based on what hes done already, hes set the company up for success. Obviously there are still issues with the core business and revenues have been declining rapidly, but that is because theyve been closing underperforming stores while building their e commerce business. Im not saying there arent risks, but based on the state of the business, no debt, cash flow positive, stellar management team and roughly half their market cap in cash, I see much more upside potential than downside risk at todays share price... and I dont see that in many other stocks at the moment.

The issue is that as a business they are doing nothing but selling stuff to generate income to offset their business losses. And they refuse to release a business plan to suggest they ever plan to do otherwise

You never acknowledged that until just now in fact youve been chasing me around telling me Im in a cult because I said to someone if its not for them they dont have to buy it while ignoring all of the other context of my comment. Thats only an issue if you dont believe the long term bull thesis that is basically Ryan Cohens not a complete dumbass and if thats what you do think then thats fine. Nobody cares if you invest in GameStop or not.

I didnt tell you that you were in a cult. I said when your response to criticism is to dismiss it as not understanding or believing, that is the same thinking cults employ. I reiterate that point. I never denied those basic facts and you never asked me to acknowledge them. You arent providing context except to repeat the same 4 points and insist you have faith in the board and the company because of it, which doesnt address same of the criticism. It just reiterates your position. And once again, you handwaive away that it doesnt matter if I invest or not, which has nothing to do with the actual discussion. Fwiw I have no doubt Ryan cohen will make money, just as he did in bbby. I have much less confidence that your average shareholder will

You implied I was, whether or not you specifically said Im in a cult isnt any different lol I was not dissmissive at all to the commentor you came in to respond for, i layed out multiple things in my comment and told them maybe this level of risk isnt for them and they shouldnt invest. You seemed to take offense to that and singled it out while ignoring everything else I said. Your inability to accept the answer that you will not get a plan told to you by the board is not my failure to address that criticism. It is known. Theres nothing more to say about it lol what more conversation do you want to have. I dont care if you think Cohen will make money or not??? I made like 20k on bbby personally but I only risked like 2k to do it. He made out much better.

Again, not taking offense, just discussing a stock. You havent laid out anything except the lack of debt, the cash position and your view of the board. And that is not a response to the criticism being presented. When you say this level of risk isnt for you, you are dismissing people actually talking about the merits of the company. You are glossing over the huge risk that exists, and pretending your confidence is an actual reasoning. Theres no answer Im looking for, and you are giving nothing to accept. I mentioned RC because you said I can think hes an idiot. I dont, he will make money. Im glad you made money too. That means you sold, and made money off the others who bought your shares. Which is the same exact business model gme has

Implying Im in a cult for investing in a stock is discussing a stock to you? The criticism being made is that they havent shared a plan. They said they wouldnt. People say theyre losing revenue. Yes theyre closing stores and shut down a distribution warehouse. They have obviously scaled back which is going to create a loss of revenue. Im not responding with only telling people this level of risk is not for them and Im not dismissing anyone by saying that. Nobody has to invest in this story if they dont want to and I would never pressure someone into it. I know theres no answer youre looking for. Youve made up your mind already. It is absolutely not their business model and if raising capital is a foreign concept to you capital markets are probably very confusing.

Once again, I did not imply youre in a cult. Youre still doing right here, saying no one has to invest. Of course not dude, thats not the point... When you raise capital, you do something with it... thats exactly the point
You absolutely implied it lol otherwise you wouldnt have even been throwing the word around. They literally are doing something with it.

Someone else said cult and I explained when you respond to criticism with some iteration of if you dont believe its ok its not for you, that does sound culty. I still stand by that. They are doing absolutely nothing besides selling stock and sitting in cash, as you acknowledged they openly said they will not provide a business plan

You said I was being dismissive and thats a tactic that cults use. Cults try to recruit people, all I said is if you dont want to buy a stock dont buy it lol. Youre fuckin wack dude. Theyre doing more than just selling stock and sitting on it but you can go off about whatever you want.

I said its cult thinking to dismiss actual criticism by saying you dont believe. Ive reiterated this now half a dozen times to you. Youve named absolutely nothing they are doing with the money and went further to say they dont release a business plan and thats totally ok

The way to profit from EV is not to buy Tesla or Rivian etc.. they have huge capital investments competition and have to take risks. The way to play is follow the classic picks and shovels strategy.. buy the supply chain players.. power semiconductors, lithium, copper, electrical connections, charging infrastructure, etc. electrification is a given... These companies will make money. Selling EV at loss that replaces ICE vehicles is not going to make you money as you are replacing one with another... Not necessarily increasing sales...

Just buy it. High risk but high reward. We all hold a few of these. Buy it and look at it after R12 and R13 numbers come out 2026. If its anything like the bump to profitability Tesla got look out. They are very busy selling everything they make. Look at the website store for what is available nationwide. I think they only have a few 3 or 4 R1S trimotors in the store. They are also busy building service centers and charging stations. As these numbers grow and people live closer to service centers the sales numbers will continue to grow. They have a unique product unlike anything on market now. They have also retooled the factory and make motors in house etc. so the cost per vehicle is going down to make. Lastly I own the stock and like it full disclosure.

Management doesnt care about shareholders at all. Anyone objectively looking at the stock can see the ridiculously high cash burn rate, the shareholder dilution, and the ever increasing debt loads. Theyve missed virtually every metric they ever set and dont even have their performance compensation tied to company performance. Note that gross margin is still massively negative, meaning theyre selling their vehicles for less than the basic raw materials and labor to build the vehicles even cost something Tesla and other EV makers never did. Imo wait until they show a clear path to profitability before buying. This is a company that has the potential to thrive but in its current state the stock is just a piggy bank that the execs are using to increase their own wealth while they dilute and destroy shareholder value.

With Rivians stock dropping significantly since its IPO, People looking at the IPO price and how much its down since it should have never been at that price. They were lucky to go public at that valuation, but shareholders who piled into that bubble got obliterated. Looking forward, RIVN probably is one of the few smaller companies that went public in 202021 who will get through this period but I dont think thats ultimately as exciting as people think. Too many people still treating the EV theme like its the 202021 bubble and trying to pick the next Tesla. Meanwhile, a number of 202021 EV ipospac names are already 0s some of which are 0s for the second time. The automobile business with a couple of exceptions is not a great business I mean, again multiple EV companies that went public a few years ago already 0s and Tesla made everyone think it is, despite Musk frequently going on about what a difficult business it is over the years. So, can RIVN bounce? Sure. Is it going lower if there was a recession in the next couple years? Absolutely. Do I think it can be one of the few smaller names that ultimately gets through this period? Yes, but I think the market has gone back to the idea that automobiles are not a great business and people keep wanting them to be something they arent. So, I think RIVN could bounce on any good news, its going to be a tough hold through whenever the next recession is and on the other side of that will probably do fine on the upturn but I think people still expect too muchis it the next TSLA!?!?! from the theme.

I do not know much about Rivian.. but as an investor for you to make money they have to sell a lot more vehicles at profit while investing in massive factories and competing with other players Instead I would bet on lithium miners like albamerle or sqm and other lithium lifecycle companies beyond miners. I heard battery might be commoditized .. so maybe battery recycling. Think what changes in the car architecture.. more motors more copper more high voltage electric lines and interconnects .. companies like molex amphenol comes to mind. Then semiconductors that focus on power conversions and controls like nxp infineon renesas will also win irrespective of who sells more EV. Then there are utility companies which should see more demand along with data centers. There is massive work in EV infrastructure and charging but again focus on the vendors and not necessarily blink or charge point. Along with ev.. there will be a shift to automation .. the players making the cameras lidar chips and software would make more profit than waymo Tesla or gm who are competing to bring the vehicles. It doesnt mean that Rivian or Tesla is a bad investment but its no longer a first mover environment... I have no idea of knowing if they will or will not but if I trust that EV is going to be the future.. then I would bet on the supply chain. Solar might be a big winner in EV . Not so much in data center case. Think ancillary issues... Charging time is still a problem... Land is limited... You want chargers in strategic location. Who has land that might become useless with ev chargers.. think the gas stations... So they will transition there with scope of commercial real estate developing. Else the grid will transition to micro grid with battery storage becoming more critical.

10 plus years now. Lost money for the first six or seven years I was trading, blew up to accounts. I trade a lot of statistics but theres one Ive been looking at that practically anyone could do that seems incredibly useful. So if you look at the run in the 90s or even the recent run this decade if someone had small positions in companies or an ideas that had a future or they thought had a future. Even if you get a few wrong. One or two of those can make you an absolute mint. So its kind of an experiment with the majority of your money being in the sp 500 but you have a 10 or 20 allocation you mess around with looking for these breakthrough ideas but rather than selling them when you get a 10 profit or 20 or whatever, you let the idea play out which is where the big money has been. The hard part is figuring out what the next company to do that is going to be or where you can get those multiples or how long they are going to go The majority of my outperformance has came from being short theta and anticipating where the market is going to go before it does. I know that last part might sound cliche but buying TLT when its in the 80s, you see that 50 correction from the top, you start shorting puts down there that are one or two years out. You start buying the shares. Cyclical companies like UPS, massive correction from COVID, back down to its original trend line, big dividend, you buy some shares, you short some puts. The small cat play, load up there, also loaded up on BTC beginning in 2016, didnt sell the top in 2017, didnt have that much but I did unload in 2021 and paid off my house and then some. I think that one is setting up to go again but even if Im wrong the risk is asymmetrical which is the type of trade you should be looking for. Its like if youre wrong you lose 20 30 40 50 but if youre right you make Xs. That account I started in 2017 with 5,000 is now worth a little over 200k but the part thats seriously impressive and I would say this to anyone if they accomplished similar is that no one trade really did it. That growth is from tens of thousands of trades with a high percent profitability. My win rate is pretty crazy its 65 to 70 and the gains are also larger than the losses. Biggest loss this year was Intel, short 30 puts which definitely got put to me but I took in so much premium for selling them, Im already almost back to break even so well see how that goes If anyone is going to even attempt to be an active trader, you need all the education you can get. If your resourceful you should be able to figure out how to get the courses from profitable people like Adam khoo, anton from the institute of trading, the old IBD courses, the chart guys, krown, there are downloads of all of these out there and no Im not going to tell you where, thats part of the fun, if you want it bad enough, youll find it. In fact Im not sure I could tell you where, the people who have these are constantly changing the sites and the download locations

I have probably made around 30 returns per annum since 201718, roughly 25 in Dollar terms in Indian Stock market where the market has returned 1215 in dollar terms so Im sure my principals would work in US markets as well. I dont try to find companies or even ETFs with higher expected returns, the key is to find negatively correlated assets with equity and put part of your portfolio in those instrumentslike LEAPS, Treasury bills, Tail risk hedges etc.. The way you beat the market via this, and Im sure even Warren Buffett beats the market because of this is 2 reasons. 1. When the markets are down, say Covid or even during the inflation heating up 202223 ish and the subsequent selloff in stocks, I sell the non equity componentwhich is now sitting at profits because its price moves opposite to stocks to buy stocks, ETFs or whatever you prefer for your exposure to equity. 2. Your volatility drag is reduced, this concept needs a bit of a deeper understanding but basically if a stock is at 100 goes down 20 to 80 and then goes up by 25 to reach back 100, if Im able to avoid the 20 downturn and only gain exposure to the 25 up move I would make 25 while other people have broken even. The derivation is more nuanced and conceptual than this so try reading it up on google, what Ive told you is an oversimplification. Now because of my portfolio positioning is like this, I can take on higher risk, generally and in CAPM world also, more volatile pockets of the asset marketslike smallcaps, junk bonds etc. have higher returns, but in downturns they fall harder than the Blue chipsApple, Nvidia etc. like the ones in DJIA index so we say these assets are more risky than mainstream Blue chips, given my exposure to downturns is reduced due to my non stock component but the upside is mine I can generate a higher profit than being invested in the SP 500 alone

Sure, one might outperform the index by taking a concentrated position in AMZN, AMD, GOOG, TSM etc. But like it or not, the portfolio needs diversifiers from all industries, i.e. also boring, slow growing ones like utilities, commodities. In the world.of investing, when people talk about beating the market, they talk about the whole USA market. SP500 can be used as a measure of the USA market because it contains its top 500 companies. If the top 500 companies are growing, the whole market is growing. If the top 500 conpanies are losing money, the whole market is losing money. You will always find an index or ETF that performed better or worse than you did. This is completely false. Indexes and ETFs are diluted, so you can do worse than any ETF or better than any index by investing on individual stocks.

I took profits in Tesla, and eventually sold out of it due to valuation concerns, and cyclicality in the auto business.
