replies.text: I used to lament every bad event. Selling too lowearly, buying too earlyhigh. I changed that by doing 3 purchases of the same stock in a 10 day period. This averages the buyin cost, and made me stop looking for absolute bottom, and I either set a sell price and lock it in with an indefinite date range, or I set an alert 6 mos, 1 year, 3 years etc and decide then. The MOST CRITICAL part of the equation is to buy quality companies and to not chase meme stocks or trends. My buyholds are typically 10 years, and 75 of my holdings are divided paying stocks in companies that have paid out a dividend for X years.
It seems like youre largely talking about timing the marketstock. You probably know this is a bad idea.

Ive heard to let your winners run and cut your losers. But Ive also heard always have a plan before you enter a position. The two seem slightly at odds unless your plan is to constantly adjust the exit e.g. Trailing stop loss. How do you let your winners run properly?

how did you overcome it if you did? Experience helps. Knowing that even though a stock left the station without you, based on historical evidence you know it will very likely come back down again at some point. Also if it helps I also sell some puts.

There are many psychological pitfalls. One of mine is always remembering the wins but suppressing the losses. Eventually I just gave up and faced reality youll never beat the index anyway, so control the only thing that you can fees, and invest in low fee index funds based on your risk tolerance 7525 for me. Now that Im wise which really means not wise at all but older, my portfolio has grown and I also inherited, so now I have another puzzle that is above my intelligence tax strategy, because Im navigating inherited IRA distributions and small trust income. And also, how to invest the 25 conservative part in something that doesnt suck as much as bond funds. So, I use financial advisors and they do invest in individual stocks, along with broadbased long term index funds, to take advantage of tax harvesting and other tax strategies. I hate the advisory fees, but its needed once you have actual capital. Before that, as an individual, consistently socking small amounts into VOO, or VTSAX, and other index funds was not as exciting as stocks, but over time, was a helluva lot more profitable. Less stressful too. Generally, if you are betting on individual companies yourself, you may as well just go to Vegas. At least youll get free cocktails and access to the 12 leather steak and rubber lobster.

There are several counters, nonmeme, I was vested in or had interest in lately which spiked ranging from 20 to 60 at some point in the past month due to news, unfortunately I dont have the fortitude to reenter or buyin in fears that some bagholders will be offloading and causing it to dip back down. The 3 purchase in 10 days option also gives me anxiety, you could be averaging across those 3 trades only for it to drop after the 10 days like how the SP had a dip back in August. Honestly this instance wouldnt matter, just that it would slow down ones compoundingaccumulation by a bit. Thanks for sharing nevertheless, I appreciate it.

Here. SO. Southern Company. Utility stock with steady growth. Good dividends. Buy it. Deposit more money into your account whenever possible and keep buying more. Throw money at it every chance you get. Think of it like a savings account with REALLY GOOD INTEREST. Dividends plus stock value increases. 10 years from now youll be glad you did.

Oh, oh I would be cautious with that strategy. First off, rate cuts may not produce the results you expect. Second, I would expect stocks that dont issue dividends to benefit much more from rate cuts, since those are usually higher growth companies. And lastly the more you adjust your portfolio the more chances for errors you introduce. Closer maybe but wouldnt match it. The reality is that companies which issue dividends meaningful dividends just dont grow as quickly as companies which dont. Schd I would argue is safer in the sense that companies that can pay significant dividends usually are generating surplus profits and can be resilient towards market headwinds. But they are trading off reinvestment in the company, aka growth. So by and large spy would most likely grow more than schd over equivalent periods of time. I find schd is to be a good hedge in those lower growthhigher volatility years

replies.text: Get rid of the advisor and buy an sp 500 index. VOO, SPY, or whatever is available to you. The sp is up 18.44 ytd.

So, your underperforming the market, and overpaying, please drop the advisors, you dont need them or their fees. Your 33, you dont need any bond allocation, bonds dont build wealth, only help maintain it. When your over 50 then maybe start introducing bonds into your portfolio. With 401Ks, keep it very simple, 100 into a low cost index fund like the SP 500. If you dont have a fully funded emergency fund, I would get that funded quickly, at least 6 months of living expenses in a High Yield Savings Account. I do, however, have copies of all my hearing tests for the last 10 years, so I can see how it has changed and can extrapolate reasonably well. Plus, Apple claims theyll provide a hearing test feature. If Apple provides all those same frequencies, it would be truly game changing. The Airpods Pro 2 are ungainly and only last 6 hours, but for about 250 each I could afford to buy two pair and charge one while wearing the other pair, then swap out when theyre spent. Given culture the way it is today, I can get away with wearing them anywhere, too. Plus, listening to music on them would be a far better experience than anything my current hearing aids can do since they require a loop necklace antenna and buggy bluetooth sync to work today. That will be a huge win for Apple right there. Finally, I could easily build a set of microphones to feed into the Airpods. I work with Raspberry Pi and IoT all the time, so assembling and programming a microphone array would not take more than a month for me. First of all, hearing aid thing is not ground breaking at all. It has been in the works in the industry for a couple of years, every single earphone company is working on it. Gn resound had something like this a year back. But why now? US FDA changed regulations around sharing aids sometime in 2019 or so, and they allowed hearing aid to be sold over the counter. This enabled consumer companies like Apple to roll this out. So, is the apple one any good? Not really. Its a gimmick. Why? Apple AirPods only last 67 hours with a single charge and continuous playback hearing aid feature is effectively continuous playback mode. This is not usable for most people. Medical grade hearing aids last 34 days with one battery. You dont want grandma worrying about charging her AirPods every 6 hours and sit down for an hour for it to charge without hearing. This is why traditional hearing aids last multiple days. This is a nothing burger. They already had the transparency mode, which passes through external sounds to the ear. Hearing Aid mode is basically amplifying it and playing it louder, with some additional minor challenges. If you are looking for Apple and health, this aint it. Apple HealthKit is more promising. More and more medical grade devices now integrate with Apple HealthKit and their fertility tracking etc is getting really really good. Recently, FDA allowed Dexcomm to sell their continuous glucose monitor directly to customers and dexcom is now working with Apple HealthKit giving Apple glucose data from users. This is a medical grade FDA cleared device used by millions of people who are diabeticpre diabetic . Source myself, an electrical engineer who used to design hearing aids for a living

And if you can adjust the audio processing to match your specific hearing problem, that cuts are out thousands more on the services. Its why Costco can sell hearing aid solutions for about 80 less than the price gouging specialists.

I speculate that if the medical industry were to start integrating and and leveraging the provided software that Apple gives to help paitents and medical professionals give quality care, it could allow for cheaper services and less visits. I do not mean to come off drone like, or as an Apple developer. For context I am a Veteran and Information Technology Systems Management student currently attending my associates, as well as an enthusiastic Apple user. The purpose for my question was more so to gauge exposure to the ecosystem and its native software such as Apple Health, Fitness, etc. For further context, I absolutely dislike the stranglehold that Microsoft has on all of the industries especially when it comes to those who value a privacy first model such as yourself. I myself value a transparency and privacy centric model which Apple allows and encourages. Lastly and I apologize for making this reply so outrageously long, but my most compelling argument that I can make utilizing Apple Health comes to mind when you utilize the Apple Watch in conjunction with shortcuts on your iPhone to systematically log your nutrition, and various other data points such as mental health, or medication tracking. There are a lot of things that can be done in the health app that also require little interaction with third party developers or their applications, although you may utilize them at your discretion. It is my belief that my data is mine, I will not allow another entity to have my data unless I specifically share it.

Modern hearing aids have been doing that for years. They have a tiny microphone pickups, and precision sound processing. They can receive audio data directly from devices like your television and play the sound directly into the ear.
The signal is that Apple is slowly adding more and more features to cover the whole market. Evolution not revoluton.

Its good PR, and its just a cheap software update. What they just did is give every white collar worker a great excuse to give their aging parent AirPods Pro 2 for Christmas. Unlike hearing aides, these are one size fits all consumer electronics so they can be gifted.

The global hearing aids market size was valued at USD 12.96 billion in 2023, and is projected to grow from USD 14.35 billion in 2024 to USD 34.76 billion by 2032, exhibiting a CAGR of 11.7 during the forecast period. So not big now but big market in the future. And there are probably a lot of people in that market who cannot afford it and dont wanna try but can now.

I cant say if theyre going bankrupt again, but I personally wouldnt ever invest in company thats so short sighted that its flirting with bankruptcy a few years after exiting bankruptcy. Edit I decided to dig into the specifics more. The company has written down or sold for a loss about 467 million of their EV inventory since 1223. Of note, they still have EVs, but I couldnt find the specifics on how much they have left. I dont think theyll go bankrupt soon, based on their debt maturities, but I wouldnt be suprised if they filed in 34 years based on their terrible decision making. I worked for a major competitor for 6 years, most of which as a branch manager, and the issue Hertz has is a result of poor loss managementleadership. The amount of effort and strict protocol we had to follow to report a car stolen was significant. Following which there was an operational process to maintain, that was fully integrated in our normal day to day functions. Ifwhen we recovered a stolen car, assuming it wasnt just sold at auction, we had to take additional steps before the system let us rent the car again. No system was perfect and mistakes were made but I only ever heard about it happening once anywhere in our group. This wouldve been across millions of rental contracts. TLDR Hertz is a mess and this is entirely selfinflicted.

replies.text: You are so young. I personally would suggest you invest In growth funds which tend to beat the total market index funds over the long haul. Trust me, at your age, getting another 2 compounding interest over the long term is a great way to go.

SP 500 includes both Googl and Goog equally so the magnificant 7 holding is actually 1 less companies. Bulk momentum from SP is generated from these 7. If one removes them you have a 2.5 annual growth. If they are growing that is great but some years they return very negatively. In 20 years you will see more country rotation. What startles me is the total market capitalization distribution today has changed so much just within last 15 years. US will have less an influence on economy than before. If one can study identify some countries, etfs or even stocks now before others you will do even better. I discovered CELH, a drink company paid 3. Ditto a chip company UMC paid 1 s for IC fab and did well. Most requiring reading through pages of earnings, K1 statements. My international is 16 of total portfolio. I like lower volatile funds with beta lower than 1. Sometimes I catch big fish other times my return is lower than some of the indices.

Its hard to argue with that portfolio. Low maintenance, well diversified, and will perform like the US market. Some foreign equity exposure is the general recommendation to optimize your riskreturn characteristics, but that advice is more rooted in smoothing volatility, based on the Markowitz MPT concept. At your age, volatility is your friend so long as you remain disciplined in regularly adding to the portfolio. Markets are dynamic and your life will be dynamic so your views and portfolio will evolve over time. Youre good for now. The real secret is discipline and patience.
Youre already diversified in stocks. We dont know your age or situation, so its hard to tailor bonds. You should probably ask rpersonalfinance
He said he just turned 20
I stated that im only 20 and got a lot of time on my hands for growth. My situation is Im married in college working part time while my wife is full time. I will check out rpersonalfinance though!

My bad missed that. I guess 100 allocation to stocks isnt too bad. But hes as diversified without extending to international which is debatable even by bogleheads standards. Most major US companies have international presence anyways

Depends on what you need to make you happy. I imagine having a minimalist dwelling in a village while exploring with a motorcycle. This wouldnt cost much and I would have a ton of fun. Malaysia has dirt cheap gas prices, one of the lowest in the world. There are whats known as kumpung villages there. Theyre tightly knit communities where everyone helps each other. I met this Thai uncle in one of those communities and he showed me his little garden with chickens and he said he shares them with the village. He also showed me research papers he published on the caves around his village, so its not like you have uncivilized uneducated people living there. I went to a rural farm village in China with absolutely breathtaking scenery at a place called Yangshuo. Met some really nice people there with a homestay. They also had a small farm there and cooked farm fresh food. The whole village looked old and run down but its funny that they pulled out with an Audi SUV. Turned out its a couple who retired back in their home village after having a successful restaurant business in the city.

Its better because the cost of living is a fraction of first world countries. Since youre taking your first world country income to a third world country, your money goes much further there. Honestly I can just say I think its totally worth it to at least have 500 youre willing to lose as an experiment in Bitcoin and leave it alone a few years, just out of curiosity. Ive been DCA or Dollar Cost Averaging in for years now. I hope to someday have a full coin. I ignored it for years and thought it was fringe bullshit and then kept hearing about the price going up. I remember working with an older guy in a tech job a few years back and he was oldschool wallstreet and was a millionaire, but wanted to learn about tech so he took a low paying PM role at my company just to learn the ins and outs of tech. He was telling me that bitcoin was the most successful stock hed ever had. At the time it had gone up to idk around 5000 dollars and he and a bunch of the dev guys I worked with got in early so I figured it was over and not worth buying in. But if you watch year after year trend, it keeps going up. I used to be in a signal group on Telegram and a guy mentioned FEG token so I bought in super early at 500. After several months, it shot up all of a sudden to 45,000 100X basically because China was pouring into it. Then it immediately shot back down because they found an offensive social media post with a caricature of a Chinese leader and banned it. I never cashed out bc it happened so fast and I didnt know where the top was in the moment. Now its worthless. But the point is, the opportunities are there, but its like the wild west. I am pretty much just a basic bitch now when it comes to crypto, I just buy 50 or so whenever I get paid of bitcoin no matter the cost. I would just use an exchange like Kraken or Binance, or Coinbase because its easy, and buy some and if you ever accumulate a lot you would want to transfer it off the exchange and into a cold wallet but I wouldnt worry about that til you have enough that it matters. I am not sure about specific videos, Ive just watched a ton of general ones about it, learning about blockchain, Satoshi, halving, etc those are the main concepts. Its kind of like how they say I dont know how my car works, but I still want to drive it. Its a complex technology and very worth learning about. I dont perfectly understand it, but I believe in it, if that makes sense. If you can afford to lose a little that you may have spent otherwise on doordash or something, its well worth taking a chance and seeing what happens

Often, yeah! And theres mad switch ups toofor example, if this September is a negative month it will be the third time in history theres been a fifth negative September in a row. Not impossible, and its been something like 35 or something years since the last time so its possible. But we could easily have a positive September after a few days of dips. But basically, unless someone is in it for the long haul where these averages will work in their favor, the only direction you can bet the market will move is to the right.

So obviously this guy is saying the average return for the month is 1 and we are already at that point so were done. Obviously youre gonna have to make a guess if its gonna be a green month or red month but historically it skews red
Beatings

So obviously this guy is saying the average return for the month is 1 and we are already at that point so were done. They didnt say that. You inferred that. Their comment simply points out that the average September return is barely negative, so much so that the magnitude of daily swings can eclipse it by a large amount.
No, its beating. Me beating it to my puts.

So you dont use the average. You extract what it actually is, which is the frequency of red Sept months dwarfs green Sept months to the point of skewing down the average to negative Is that so difficult to comprehend? you also inferred that the other guy was talking about how trivial the return is. Of course a big daily move is gonna dwarf the average return for the whole month. If the sp500 only returns 10 annually on average, and you have Sept with an average return of 5 or something, that annualizes to 60, or youre gonna need other months with huge 5 to balance it.

So you dont use the average. You extract what it actually is, which is the frequency of red Sept months dwarfs green Sept months to the point of skewing down the average to negative Is that so difficult to comprehend? Lol, that is still an average. Im a statistician, so no, thats not hard to comprehend. You dont have to be a douchebag. The probability of a red September is barely above 50. Its trivial. you also inferred that the other guy was talking about how trivial the return is. No I didnt, that is literally what the numbers in the comment are about. Youre the only one who made an assumption, namably, that they were trying to imply were done already, which is absurd. Of course a big daily move is gonna dwarf the average return for the whole month. Yeah, so its a good fucking point to keep in mind whether the months average is slightly positive or slightly negative lol. You accidentally arrived at the point that the OP was trying to make in this comment chain.

The frequency alone is not the same as average. Average includes both frequency and magnitude. Shouldnt a statistician know this? The probability of red Sept is about 56, and its actually the only month with red above 50, and the only month with negative average. And if you look at previous pullbackcorrection from peak to trough instead of just first days of the month as your timeline, those corrections typically all occurred around Sept or Oct. Also, the other guy didnt make any comments at all. You are the one who attached the word trivial difference to the data. So you also inferred what he meant.

The frequency alone is not the same as average. Average isnt really a hard statistical term, its a colloquialism, and generically applies to any situation where you are dividing a set of data by the size of the sample I.e., if you split months by a binary such as positivenegative return, and divide by the number of months, thats an average the frequency would just be a raw number, like 13, the average would be 56. The probability of red Sept is about 56 ... right, barely above 50. I dont even know what were talking about at this point. Who cares youd need a subgroup analysis to make this predictively meaningful anyways.

replies.text: My main account is with Schwab but I opened a HSA with fidelity. The fact that fidelity sweeps your cash balance into a money market is reason enough to pick fidelity. I havent switched because of the headache and I just actively manage my cash in a money market act with Schwab but if I was starting from scratch Id pick fidelity.

Fidelity allows for partial shares of ETFs and Stocks. Schwab only allows partial of some stocks on the SP. The source of the funds can come from your brokerage or directly from your bank account. Fidelity allows automatic investing of any stockETF. Schwab only has it for mutual funds. Edit I switched all but my individual stocks from Schwab to Fidelity for the above reasons.

I am planning on moving my managed accounts out of Schwab since they like to use their ETFs over better performing Vangard, etc. I will leave my trading accounts with Schwab just because of TOS.

You couldnt sell covered calls or cash backed puts with the ap. You had to call in and phone trade. Fidelity and Vanguard I think are the only 2 that didnt cut off options trading. Vanguard is no leveraged or crypto. Fidelity also no futures. I keep a couple of accounts due to potential fraud or and or systems crashing. Judging by your list, fidelity wins on that metric. Also, Ive had all good experiences with their customer service. I only trade on PC because Schwabs app will just freeze up every time I try to do a trade on my phone. Also Schwab has locked people out of their accounts twice this year already which never happened to me before on any other brokerage. The only reason I am using Schwab is because I really liked TD Ameritrade and they were purchased by Schwab this year so I didnt really have a choice. I wanted to give them the benefit of the doubt and you can still use the ThinkorSwim platform with Schwab so that is something that I dont want to give up. I am crossing my fingers hoping they will get better because I would really rather avoid switching brokerages and having to learn a new skill set for trading. If I were to move I might choose Chase, but I have heard that Fidelity is also a good choice. Good luck with whatever you decide! Edit I wanted to add that another thing I do like about Schwab is that you can trade in afterhours premarket, set up as many automatic orders as you want with no fees for equity tradesnot options, and I can spend twice as much money as I actually have if I want to not sure if that is a good thing or not...lol.

I have accounts at both. I was switched to Schwab when they bought TD Ameritrade. After the switch, I was extremely disappointed with Schwab performance. Here are the things I did not like versus Fidelity 1 Fidelity auto sweeps my cash to a money market account paying 5. Schwab does not and pays a paltry 0.35 on this cash. 2 Fidelity pays out dividends to customers the same day companies pay out. Schwab holds this cash for an extra day and pays out a day later. 3 Schwabs site experienced 3 crashes at the open when I was looking to trade. Never had a problem with Fidelity in the 10 years I have had an account with them. 4 My account contacts at Fidelity are great and take care of things within days of requesting. My account rep at TD Ameritrade was awesome and moved over to Schwab. He is super frustrated by them due to their poor performance and inability to compete with other brokerage firms as they are not competitive. 5 Schwab only allows a single phone number for two factor authentication. Fidelity allows two phone numbers to be set up to access an account via two factor authentication. I want both my wife and myself to be able to access accounts in case something happens to the other spouse. I ended up moving a multimillion account from Schwab to Fidelity due to Schwabs poor performance. Fidelity paid me an incentive bonus of several thousand dollars to move the money to them. replies.text: IBM is surviving on financial engineering. They are repumping their 90s software, cloudifying it or containerizing and calling it hybrid cloud. Since the Watson fiasco, they have lost all their credibility in AI. To pump their stock, they have sold their soul. Its an empty shell of what was once an innovation powerhouse.
Its got about the same PE and a higher EVEBIT than Alphabet owners of Google.

I worked for a competitor of IBM for years, so I acknowledge my bias. That said, I found IBM to be a kind of cult to many customers in the 80s and 90s, and a few even now. At first, enterprises looked at IBM as the Cadillac of computing. They locked in many places with their mainframe computing the IBM 360 was a staple of business. The biggest places had sales staff with personal relations to the C level of enterprises and sole sourced the equipment. UNIVAC, DEC, Tandem and others to a lesser extent. As the 80s and 90s rolled around, Big Blue kept high prices on their Cadillac and although they rolled out their UNIX AIX and virtually invented the PC, the pricing was high, proprietary in an open source minded world and they lost market share. For one retail company, the Bd of Directors required competitive bidding, and even though any competitor could provide less price and equal or superior function, IBM would be awarded the work because we are used to them. Finally others stopped bidding the pointless exercise it was just to press IBM to keep their pricing down. When the old guard retired, and the enterprise realized the premium they paid for obsolete proprietary systems it was too late. They still used the IBM OS2 PC into the 2000s. They went from sales of billions to bankruptcy. I am convinced their cult belief in IBM and failure to modernize contributed. I did a study for multiple companies that illustrated if they moved off the bloated AIX systems to competitive systems, they would save millions. The paradigm shift always seemed risky, but those that moved were well rewarded. In the last 15 years, where IBM competed against Dell, HPHPE, Fujitsu, Amazon, Microsoft and others for data center refresh, cloud and other updates, they rarely stood the test, unless it was from one of those cultist enterprises who had decided before the bid. They still have a mainframe market it is expensive to migrate but not impossible. Their database product , PC, AIX and others are considered by most to be old iron. Even their cloud is a bit proprietary and pricey iron cloud. Watson has been discussed Their quantum computing research is admirable but given their history of trying to make things proprietary so they can keep price and margin high, I wont expect it to play well with others. It is vaporware somewhat. All said, their sales and margins and employee count are down to 23 of the numbers 10 years ago. The legacy of arrogance. I vote thumbs down. FWIW.

Enterprise Value is usually a better metric for the cost of buying the business than market cap because it takes into account the companys debt and its cash. Enterprise Value Market Cap Debt Minority Interest Cash. If a company had a 500 million market cap and 500 million debt and 50 million annual income, it wouldnt be any better value than the company with 1 billion market cap, no debt and 50 million annual income. The first company would have a lower PE ratio but both companies would have the same EVEBIT ratio. Because it also adds minority interest, you should divide by EBIT rather than earnings because EBIT doesnt have the minority interests share removed. Plus, its available in most stock screeners, including TradingView. TlDr EVEBIT is a better measure of value vs other metrics such as PE.

He said that wrong by referring to 50M income instead of 50M EBIT. What EVEBIT does is strip out the effect of how a company is financed. Say you have two companies both with the same EV 1B and the same EBIT 50M. One of them has no debt, so its 1B market cap and pays no interest costs its net income will be 50M minus whatever taxes it pays. The other one has 500M market cap and 500M debt, so its net income will be 50M minus interest costs minus taxes. They may have different PE ratios based on the interest and tax regime but the important thing to understand is that underneath they are the same operating business just financed different ways. So you have to evaluate the two things separately quality of the business how the business is financed.

The dot.com bubble was very different. Not to say that valuations could be stretched at this point. I was old enough to do the dot.com. Right around 30. I know way too many companies that were basically three card monty. Sucking up VC money. Padding sales data when they showed up at the offices. Pipeline stuffing. Also, essentially we will buy X or advertise c on your platform if you do the same with us. Just shuffling VC money around the room to look like platform had interest or their was sales. I wouldnt doubt there are probably some companies like that now. But that was so much about infancy. This is not infancy. This is massive corporations with massive earnings and cash hoards throwing that cash at being first movers ... its that important. It would be idiotic for the meta nvda msft types, downstream chip players and fabs, software value add players, to be burning through their cash as they are. They know history. They know what is playing out here. Having used ChatGPT for a myriad of things, my wife the same. I have been learning prompts, she just learn as you go, we are stunned at the impact on our lives and then I read and see what else is happening that makes what we are doing silly. When companies like msft are throwing down 125B on a single datacenter as an example. You just dont do that on hype. This race is critical to corporate survival and global balances of power. Hell even China is creating a regulatory body to ensure we dont end up AIing wwiii with all of it. Tech companies are readily letting people go, hiring at lower salaries bc AI is changing the landscape for standard computer science guys. Just look at the silly things your person at home is doing on social media with AI tools. And then imagine what the players are doing with the best minds and engineers in the countryworld. We havent even started to speak to timelines on healthcare and processing data regarding studies and time to insight on drug candidates. Learning is going to be accelerated by magnitudes and at speed we cant fathom. Things will be needed. Necessity is the mother of invention. It doesnt not fail. Power sources will be uncovered. People had been far and happy for a while. No more. Another anecdotal cliche, publish or perish...translation keep up and get it done or disappear.

I would disagree with that. The current promise of AI is that it will revolutionize the back office processes in basically every company. Companies will become thousands of times more efficient when all of those millions of dollars they spend on paying employees to readwrite spreadsheets, PDFs, Microsoft Word docs, etc will no longer be necessary since AI will be able to do it in a blink of an eye. This is almost certainly technically possible and will happen to one extent to another. The unknown is to what extent will entrenched processes at these companies slow it down or stop it from happening altogether, but the potential to revolutionize how business is done is equal than or greater what happened during the rise of the dot coms, since that mostly impacted how companies communicated. This has the potential to automate everything else.

So its not accurate to say cava stock is more expensive than chipotle. If anything Cava is wayyyyy cheaper than chipotle. I bought cava a while ago at 35share. Love the stock, love the brand, and I love the food. Its not for everyone though. More people will like chipotle because overall Id say people are more likely to eat Mexican than Mediterranean. But tons of people LOVE cava. My wife and I are both obsessed. Reasons I like the stock tons of room for growth. They are growing organically they are not a franchise so your average Joe Shmoe cant just open up a cava franchise. Theyre carefully selected by the cava corporation so that they dont negatively affect other cava locations. I also enjoy this part because of quality control if some Joe Schmoe opens up a location and does a bad job managing it, the product will worsen. Just like tons of subways opened up and plenty of them were in bad locations or were not managed that well out of bread etc. Hopefully wont have this problem with Cava. There are also so many areas around the country that dont have a cava. Huge growth potential. They could open up near every college in the United States and be successfully most likely but theres only about 300 locations total. They plan to open up another 700 in the next 8 years. Theyre already profitable and the margins are good which I love to hear. Revenue year over year is increasing, same store sales is increasing year over year even with new locations opening up. All these things make me bullish on the stock. And most importantly, my wife and I really enjoy the food. Its healthy and refreshing. People that care about health will eat cava and not feel guilty.
Comment cava ?
I thought CAVA was Mediterranean food as opposed to Mexican food for Chipotle. Its like comparing KFC with Burger King.
All the people saying I bought at 40 when everyone said it was overpriced! will be the same people selling it for 50 when it falls from 134.
Bought in at 64, but looking for my exit position now.

I learned a while back that food service sucks are tricky bc the customers are fickle. People may love cava I do too but after a few months may move on to something else and eat there less. A lettuce or tomato or other external factors type recall may also have huge immediate impact, for me personally, not worth the risk
I have shares 34 average cost, sold about 14 at 70 and another 14 at 125 and a leap put. I think long term itll be fine, but currently its over priced.
youre correct. being lenient, its a 65 dollar stock. and thats with a premium over CMG.
This sub called CAVA overpriced when it was 40 per share but I bought it anyway. No one actually knows, if you want the stock get it! Just dont buy into a company you dont really believe in.

I love Cava and will never eat at Chipotle again if I have the choice. I really like the stock. Its already cash positive and has phenomenal growth trajectory. With that said, I hate the price and there is some competition in the Mediterranean casual world.
deleted
Its overpriced bad food with hype. It wont last and the crash will be brutal.
Good point. On the inverse, Ive had a friend tell me he stopped eating at Chipotle because he likes the taste of CAVA much more.
People love it so much that the PE of 342 is justified?
304x PE, 221x forward PE, yikes

I would expect some meanreversion to take place To go from a 320x forward PE to a 20x forward PE would be a 93.75 reduction Is their stock really in a position to go down 93 to match normal valuations or do normal valuations just not apply?

How in the hell is this upvoted? Whether or not a stock is expensive is obviously not just determined by the share price. By all actually relevant metrics like PE, PS, price per location... Cava is way more expensive than chipotle stock.
Genius.
What is your issue with Chipotle?
Yes but conversely its what 15 at McDonalds? Shitty fast food is the biggest loser in this environment.

Its a different cuisine and restaurant, chipotle is a fair comparison in some respects but not in all. I tried it they arent in the area I live and thought it was delicious. A chicken bowl sounds pretty standard and unadventurous to me personally, you can get a million varieties of that anywhere. Cava long play isnt about how good their chicken bowl is, its about how many hundreds of locations theyre planning on opening up over the next few years

As of June, 2024, there are 3381 Chipotle restaurants in the United States. These restaurants are located in 49 states and territories and 1738 cities. There are 337 Cava locations in the United States as of June 05, 2024.

Basically their domination of the fast casual space is guaranteed with the stock price. They would need to start selling AI falafels to justify any gains from here. But I personally think Chipotle stock is also overpriced so who knows.

Youre proving my point. OP was saying chipotle is cheaper stock based off price alone. I was saying thats not the case. The current number price of a stock doesnt dictate whether or not its cheap. Just like some BS penny stocks arent necessarily cheap just because theyre less than a dollar. Were agreeing with each other. OP edited his post but he was referencing current stock prices to determine that cava is more expensive than chipotle

I think cava is that much better. Between the toppings, sauces, and the protein is much more diverse. Chipotle to me is fine, but you can also get burritos and Mexican bowls everywhere. I also kind of agree with everyone that theyre stingy now . Have you tried CAVA?

Shitty fast food and a 206 billion dollar market cap.. People like shitty fast food with lots of grease and salt.. Have you heard of the obesity epidemic.. People love that unhealthy food.. At least its expensive.. LOL

Your headline is that cava is way cheaper than chipotle so we are not saying the same thing. Whether or not you are bullish on the stock also has no bearing on whether or not its cheaper or more expensive than chipotle.

nah havent been to one. In general I hate these trendy, fad restaurants. I even hated the idea of Chipotle for years until I actually ate it. My issue with CAVA is range, I just dont think it will have the same broad customer base that CMG has. The menu does not look like something that would draw me or my family to, I am a meat and potatoes eater. But things I originally thought were stupid and would never make money include...NFLX, CMG, AAPL, TSLA. My investing decisions have definitely evolved because of lessons learned. Now when I see people running towards something I think to myself....if this many people like it, would it be a good investment? Even if I think its stupid!

content.text: Thoughts on CAVA?

replies.text: Success is slow and steady, it allowed me to retire early 10 years ago and now I live the good life. I first got into investing in the late 1990s after a work colleague would talk incessantly about HON. I decide to join the DRIP program contributing initially 100 month and changed to 500quarter and occasionally added extra cash. I have only sold once during Covid to redo the kitchen. Today it is worth high six figures coupled with my 401K and about 10 other stocks FBMETA 19, AMD 2.50, LLY 60, GE 6 pre reverse split and few others it has afforded me a comfortable life.
Yes. I know someone that bought 100,000 of Nvidia stock in 2016. Hes retired now at age 50

No. It added to my wealth but i had to make a lot of money first to funnel it into the investments. I feel like once I got near a million the jump to 3, 4 was so much faster than climbing that initial hill. Investing is slow. It is a much better investment to hone a very good career or learn skills that are marketable and open a business or get a really good job.... My portfolio could sustain a simpler lifestyle now roughly 100k a year in dividends but lifestyle creep is real and I do enjoy some of the finer things. So i will work and continue to let it compound for another 10 15 years. But the joy is having options, I made the choice to keep working and i have the option to not to if i want to make some changes. The best thing you can have in life is freedom, idle time is not my goal. It took me 24 years to get here, i am 41 and started my roth when i was 17.

Im an hourly worker in a paper mill and Ive grown my net worth to 1.7 million. Ive gotten very lucky, getting in on GME, NVDA, and ASTS early. The only reason I cant retire now is because I have advanced kidney disease and need the health insurance.
Define rich? Everything paid for and zero debt plus retired early? Then yes. Some people make 250k yearly but spend 300k. Those people are quite poor.
I have actually become much poorer from investing thats mostly because i am terrible at it with a reversemidas touch!.

It is like home appreciation taking years if not decades. But many treat it like slot machines. I started retirement accounts very early I think I hit fire at 15 years. My secret is invest in very boring stocks. Consumer staple that people use daily. Diapers, bandages and junk food. No news other than splits. It works for me.
Maybe a bit nitpicking here, but what do you consider rich? Being among the top 10 of your country, or 3, or 1? To me, rich means you can live very comfortably off passive income.

No but its hard to get rich without investing because inflation will at some point eat your savings faster than you make money from your job. Your focus should be in this priority roughly 1 Growing your income significantly investing in your skillscareerbusiness 2 Reducing your expenses to save more 3 Investing your savings into stable investments broad index 4 Diversifying your investments beyond stocks into other assets

Well yes but it took a lot of time. Thats how most people who are millionaires become millionaires. Work, save money, let time pass. Ive been putting money in the SP 500 index fund at Vanguard since 1997. My 401k and IRAs are way into the 7 figures now, as are my brokerage accounts. Ive been a W2 employee my whole career. Im going to retire next year at age 54. Money will not be a concern for me no matter how long I live.

30 years. Mixed assests, not just stocks. Vested pension plans. The thing about investing is you will almost always get a better return than leaving the same money in the bank. So if you do basic, conservative, index investing you are routinely beating your bank even after taxes. As to getting rich remember the Wall Street aphorism, Bulls make money. Bears make money. Pigs get slaughtered.
Unless you have 1,000,000 2,000,000 invested, youre likely not living off your investment dividends.
Rich guy here. What I found is friendships are the real riches.
If you can afford chicken nuggets everyday that is rich
Working on it

I bought 550 000 shares in Pilbara Minerals 3.6c and sold 500 000 almost 2 years ago at 5.50. I think my original investment was 20 and I sold at 2.7mil. I got lucky with a lithium explorer that turned into a major exporter to China.

Personally I would suggest taking like 12 of your portfolio for higher volatility plays that have the potential to moon. Dont rely on it, but at least you bought your lotto ticket in case something explodes. Thats the only way youll have the possibility of getting rich from investing total market ETFs and blue chips will generally give you growth over inflation, but as you said it will be a slow and boring grind. Its ok to have a small percentage of your portfolio dedicated to more exciting stuff.

Youll get rich investing by taking a lot of risks. Either trading very often for incremental gains or bet the house on a few instruments that will gain a lot at the exact right time. Why is it risky? Because youll get things perfectly right only 3 or 5 times in your lifetime. But youll make a true fortune out of these things. So a lot of what investment is about.. to me... its about waiting... waiting for the opportunity and waiting for the investment to be realized before cashing out. But everyone is different so whichever method makes you money will work.

To become rich quicker you will have to make some high risk smart investing decisions and also be lucky. Which obviously is not for all. Otherwise I think of investing as a way to keep my savings from a job that I will have to work for decades, grow for my retirement. If you want better faster results you will have to focus on how to make more money at your every day job.

Not rich, but I opened my brokerage account and started investing when I was 22 and I would have had a much harder time buying a house in 2022 at 29 if I hadnt started investing when I did. Paid my 20 down payment entirely with capital gains on investments. Of course I paid taxes on selling those stocks, but its wild that Im almost back to where my account was in only 2 years due to DCAing frequently and making some good stock choices. I dont see it as something that will ever get me rich, but as a relatively high earner Im definitely building wealth a lot faster than my peers who steer clear of the stock market and investments outside of high yield savings accounts and the like.

Has anyone on here actually become rich just from investing? yes Specifically, how long did it take before you felt your portfolio could sustain your lifestyle without the need for additional income from employment? look up rfire and the 4 rule if your investments are x25 of your annual expenses, you can are good to go in theory depending on age, max 33.5 of annual drawing off your investments might be more appropriate than the 4 rule tho, which is for a 30y time horizon so as example.. imagine you have 100k total expenses gross a year and you want to live off investments you would need 2.5m in cashflowing assets equities really, e.g. rBogleheads style with the 4 rule, for a more conservative approach e.g. in your 30s, you would prolly need 2.853.3m i.e. 33.5 annual draw

You wont get rich by investing in the entire SP 500. You will secure your retirement and likely a very good one at that, but you wont magically get rich. Its slow because its relatively safe. Getting rich with stocks, from a starting point of not being rich, requires taking risks and investing a lot of time into research unless youre just very lucky to pick the right stocks over a prolonged period of time.

Not yet! I started investing in 2022. With 5,000. By early this year, I was down to 2,000. And I eventually sold everything at a loss and put everything in AST Spacemobile when it was 7 a share. Its now at over 30 a share and my 2,000 has turned into 9,000. Im a big stonks guy
Nobody gets rich just off stocks except the lottery ticket winners from Wall Street bets that are 1 In a million or working at a startup that gives you the options

Ive invested but I only worked for a few years and got unemployed from covid. I got some money from unemployment and covid laid off money. If youre smart about it and wait a while, yes it will keep snowballing but it takes a few decades. But its not going to be a comfortable life and the passive income wont be anywhere close to a salary unless you actually have several million invested. You really need to combine investing with something else if you dont have a salary. Employment can be great because they can match your stocks in a retirement package, but if your industry doesnt give those kinds of benefits its worthless. As little as a million can be used to retire but that will only generate minimum wage in passive income, which will be spent mostly on food and living expenses. If guarantee most would not like that lifestyle. If you can get more money its better. If you dont mind a snowballing analogy, I noticed that after 10 years the snowball grew and started rolling by itself but still could be stopped. But after 20 years the snowball started growing out of control. When I look back those same stocks 20 years ago were really cheap and grew that much in value. I think it really does show the importance of just entering the market early.

It hasnt replaced work for me but it allowed me to make career decisions based on what I wanted to do and not what I had to do to make money. I work in film and a lot of people struggle, especially starting out, with making enough money to just pay rent so they are constantly taking jobs that are not rewarding or enjoyable or valuable for their longterm goals and it exhausts them. Investing allowed me to take financial riskssacrifices to work with the filmmakers I wanted to learn from, allowed me to do jobs for free or little money because I wanted the connection or the experience and knowledge. And now all of those things are paying off as Im starting to get paid really well to continue to work on top level projects with great people while also taking that experience and knowledge and confidence to help my friends make their projects and raise them up. We sold our first completely independent film to Warner Bros Max last month. Its pretty awesome. I started out with 500 from saving up all my money from last semester of working in college and in 15 years turned maybe a net savings of 65,000 around 100,000 deposits minus 35,000 withdrawals into 350,000. Took 10 years to get to the first 100,000. The first 5 years I didnt think about the money, I just thought about making good decisions. The next 5 years sometimes I thought about the money and realize Ill be old by the time I make 1M or 2M at my current incomepace. By year 10 you realize investing is just part of your habits and you dont think of the time it will take to get rich and retire because youve already created a fulfilling life as you are. Now I manage friends portfolios for them About 200,000 currently for free and its very rewarding to see how amazed they are by how much money you can make by just being smart about where you put it. The great thing about investing is to manage 5,000 is not much different than managing 50,000 and it wont be much different managing 500,000 or 5 Million.
Generally stocks are for slowly growing wealth you already have. If you want to get rich quick go buy a business, or a lottery ticket.
Knowing people earning 20M per year. They also dont need to pay taxes as their country does not have capital gain taxes.
removed
You become rich by spending less than you make. Investing helps, but at the end of the day, spending less than you make is what will make you wealthy in the long run.
A friend of mine turned 130k into 5m in GME calls I still feel horrible whenever that thought comes into my mind

I have been in a unique situation as a SAHF and WFH for almost 17 years. I took my small managed account from a job I had 30 years ago and also a large to me chunk of cash from a home sale and move that netted us about 100k in 2019. All in I took about 130k in 2019 and really focussed for about a month on researching and planning our portfolio for a 10 year period to see if I could make significant difference in our wealth. I also did this because I will have 2 kids in college at that time. While it hasnt always been a pretty chart, I have managed to 4x that initial sum with no additional contributions. So much so that we have also transferred all the accounts into my management. My simple approach of seeking 10 minimum growth annually and rolling all dividends into speculation equities or higher growth potential holdings. If you are up 30 including the last 4 years which means likely your initial investment had a big drop in Feb 20 unless you timed that perfectly. I would say you are on the right track, and as you should be able to start seeing that sum increase exponentially. At an average of 10 growth you would double in just over 7 years. And as you approach 2030 growth you are doubling every 2 and a 12 years. As far as being rich, thats an impossible number to quantify. But I have taken 100k and in less than 10 years managed to have that 100k currently add 100k every year for 2 years straight. FWIW I also lost and grew back 40k in the last 4 weeks so it is not without its risks.

As you go through your career tour earnings will usually increase and so your contribution values will also increase. That makes it take longer for the internal investment return to be bigger than your contribution rate. If you kept contributing the same amount, it would take about 5 years for the returns on investment to beat the contribution rate. But youre doing the right thing by increasing your contribution rate as your earnings go up.
Yes, but it took 40 years.

Investing is like stepping on a gas pedal. You can push it all the way down to the floor, but it doesnt mean your car is at 150 mph all at once. It gets faster and faster. Im at about 400k in investments now and make about 17k a year without getting out of bed. It will be more next year and more the year after that. Keep with it. Eventually you will hit a point where you cant slow down youre growing your wealth so fast.

I imagine you will find people that went from comfortable to wealthy or broke to to comfortable But without an income there is generally a limit to the returns you can make over a couple decades By that I mean in 20 years 200k to 1M is a solid return. 10k to 50k is also a solid return Investment is often very relative to your starting point.
I retired 10 years after I started investing. Are you willing to invest 80 of your income and live on only 20? Thats what I did.
Many NVDATSLA investors have..

Thisll probably get buried at this point, but Im rich enough in the market that my annual gains or losses in bad years exceeds my entire annual salary. This has happened for the last 3 years in a row now, and the gains for this year are already ahead of my annual salary. My stock portfolio is worth over a million dollars. But this despite this Im not retired, and dividends are still just a fraction of my annual salary. I intend to keep compounding my investments farther and farther. Its taken a lot of years to get a portfolio up to this size, but after a certain point your wealth will start to compound a lot faster. i.e. a 10 gain in a 100,000 portfolio gives you significantly more money than a 10 gain on a 10,000 portfolio. Thats how I consistently make or lose more money then my annual salary each year.

Absolutely, it just depends on your definition of rich you wont be flying private jets, renting out entire islands but a few million in your portfolio? Absolutely. 7.4 million Americans are millionaires almost purely from investing alone. Its a slow, and steady game. If you expect to be rich in a year this isnt the game for you, if you are ok waiting 2030 years this might be the game for you, if you are ok with waiting 4050 years this is 100 the game for you. Personal advice, I know many will disagree especially in some subreddits but 70 ETF, 20 high growth, 10 dividend its the most repeatable pattern to becoming a millionaire time and time again.
Who is perceiving that as underperformance?

Accumulated some wealth by working my butt off saving in ira. Bought some individual stocks. Won and lost. Smarter people than I cannot predict the market. So sez uncle Warren Buffet so get thee over to index funds like Vanguard and be patient. Individually I erred on Enron yes Enron. Fannie Mae. A 2000 tech fund. Pfffft! But right on Coke Walmart Home Depot JP Morgan Microsoft Google and lucky right on Costco and Apple. Yay. But Luck is NOT a financial plan. I do not listen to Jim Cramer pump and dump . And no Bitcoin or dogecoin. In my opinion
I got lucky buying Apple in the early 2000s. Its now a massive part of my portfolio despite not buying shares in probably 1520 years, the same way I imagine Tesla is for many younger people.
Investing to build wealth reliable is a long slow process. Getting rich quickly through investing is basically gambling and has a high risk of blowing up in your face

Yes, absolutely. The investments portion of net worth not including home has gone up 500 since I started tracking it 7 years ago. If you include the house, its a 450 increase, but selling our house doesnt factor into retirement plans, so I dont typically include it. The vast majority of this has been stocks. Even getting in early and heavy on some alternative investments hasnt really outperformed a diversified stock market approach heavily weighted in US large cap growth. This is no guarantee of future returns tho, and Ive become much more conservative in my investing strategy recently IE still aggressive by most peoples standards.

youre likely never going to be rich by passively investing unlevered, by definition youre getting the same market return as a very large cohort of other people in your boat, prices for the things you will want being rich will also go up, just look at what happened to asset inflation and things like private school tuitions since the pandemic

Investing in stocks as longterm? Not particularly. I think of Longterm investments as just ways to 1 combat inflation, 2 make stagnant money in the bank earn a little more. Or you can look at it in a way of discipline and delayed gratification good financial literacy which are things you need to be rich.
Ive done well with AVGO, its up about 500 in 5 years but Ive been constantly DCA into it some Im up 143 since starting in September 2020. Just to compare total returns

I just hit that mark this year 2m, after about 25 years of investing. The first 10 years out of college, I was putting away roughly 30 of my pay into an investment account. I knew the faster I could get a good sum accumulated, the longer I had for things to grow. It has been a slow process, but I got here by continuing to diversify and just holding on to virtually everything. Ill sell a loser every year or two to offset income, but that is about it. Buy and hold can be slow, but I bought MSFT at about 27.50, so the value has increased tremendously. Id like to say I do something fancy, but its pretty boring. The part that isnt boring is that Ill be retired by 55.
Most people get richer, very lucky few get rich from investing.

It takes 1015 years to cross the dividend compounding threshold where your dividends may become larger than your contributions. Its hard to become rich with only investing but over time the compound dividends will start to become larger than your deposits.

Yea... it happens. Its really about having the knowledge and being patient. I cannot time the market, but I know that over time certain things will repeat because people are people. Though it has already happened to me, annual passive income is not a good measure honestly. Namely because not everything generates income and since the 80s, our tax code encourages risk taking. Until that changes, most companies will not give out much in dividends but they will have high growth comparatively speaking, to history. I my case, the cash flow from investment got higher than my work income about 5 years ago I think. Dont remember exactly. I started in 2008 so what is that? 11 years I guess. But I could have retired around 2013. I sort of did retire for a few years but then I got bored. Sustain my lifestyle? Im insanely frugal to the point that it even annoys me because I know I can afford to spend more. So I could have retired on my 1st mil back in 2012. But I wanted to make sure there was some leg room in case of medical problems, or some other sort of emergency or if I start a family, etc.
A dad who was busy on stock market is the easiest way to be rich. Todays youth want to be rich quickly, not under 60 years as daddy did.

I knew a guy in highschool who started investing young because he saw that Rich people had the easiest lives and he felt the only way he could gain wealth at such a quick rate was through investing. Hes still my friend today although we have grown apart. Hes doing extremely well for himself and has multiple properties and cottages in very desirable locations. I believe they are all paid off and all from his investments. He worked as a project manager for a big bank last time I heard. Normal corporate job making 80k annually...

I believe compounding is the word you are looking for or atleast whats expected in investing. Initial invested amount is key, though. 10x of 5k in 10 years is 50k. 5x of 1M in 5 years is 5M. Monthly contributions will catch up but earlier the better.

This has probably been said tenfold already, but if not based on your portfolio you should just invest in SPYVOO. It is possible to become rich from investing, which is why more and more retail investors are getting into it. Doing it quickly AND consistently is rare however, which is why you see a lot more loss porn in many of these subs. Those who do manage thisdo so often through callput options !though this usually leads to more loss porn! or through buying an undervaluednonbluechip stock while its super cheap.
Youd have to take on a pretty considerable amount of risk for a while so not many have done it with only their own money.

So much of this has to do with luck. I graduated college with debt in early 2010, no jobs to be found. It took me another 10 years to pay that debt off make a pivot. Im basically 10 years behind people who got into the work force or were able to start at a better time....and I still consider myself lucky.
Prioritizing captital before investing is ideal for growth, I know people with 2k thinking that they will make millions in a few years. Thats just wishful thinking

Anyone ? Yes. But you have to understand the risk involved with getting rich in a short time span. 30 is decent growth but your mistake is that youre kinda aimless in your approach and Im assuming very risk averse. You say you made this portfolio 4 years ago. Depending on when exactly in 2020 you did that, considering the nose dive and massive rebound the economy experienced, you could have been up at least 70 if not more if your money was on something like QQQ for example. And before people start howling about how irresponsible something like this is, its not, if you know what youre doing. Ok maybe 70 is not exactly right since it doesnt account for the contributions spread across the 4 year time frame, but the point is, if youre not touching that money for the next 51020 years, why the SP500 and not the top 100? Its pretty much the same chart with a wider range. Higher highs and lower lows, better long term growth. If youre putting money in the sp and all world and a handful of companies that are so big they have no real room to grow anymore, it paints the picture of someone who wants gains without the risk of ever seeing his investment go red even momentarily. Thats fine, thats understandable, its the right approach for many people, but if you want to maximise growth, then youre not doing it right, rather youre going at it blind. Chasing growth means treating your investment like a time capsule, you do not touch that money for a good long while, you define your time frame and plan a strategy accordingly. Also the alternative of not investing doesnt really do anyone any good. You work, you make money, you save, theres no benefit of having your savings sit and do nothing. Even with modest growth youre still getting free money for doing nothing. You want to hit it big? You can try, but that comes with more risk, and for 99.9 of people, its not worth it. Stick to what youre doing now and it will pay off.
Odd question. Of course there has been many millions.
Money makes Money as simple as that
I started at 31. Slow and steady, a few good years thrown in and have 1.2 mil. Im 60 now.

you have to change up the mindset about this whole game... lets say if you didnt invest at all Im talking about all forms of investments what would happen to your money? and what would you be doing with the money you have made? another point is, what happens when you retire? you dont have a job hence no income, so what happens to the savings you have acquired over your working years? therefore its not necessarily about getting rich, its more about preserving and stretching your hard earned dollars

One of the reasons relatively passive strategies like DCAing is so popular is that it lets you save your time and energy to earn, earn, earn. Doubling the amount you earn lifetime by investing seems like a decent careerlength goal, from what I hear anyway.

There is a miracle called compounding interest, you will either be the victim or benefactor First, you need to define rich as it applies to you. Second, you can make money investing in the stock market. The first 100k is tough but with diligence it happens. The second 100k is almost more because of the first 100k than your additions, after that it is mostly compounding. The suggestion I made to my kids and friends who ask is the following Mostly it is about Market Index Funds and those are about the market, not some foo foo index fund. I stick with SPNASDAQDow via these funds VOOOEFSPY for SP ONEQQQQM for NASDAQ DIA for Dow I reinvest dividends and also have a relatively small footprint in DAX Germany and JPXN Japan all my index funds are green My individual equities story is a very mixed bag for results you just dont have enough intelligence to predict a companies trajectory in the long haul intelligence meaning information. But COST, AAPL, GOOG, JPM are my performers, again I dividend reinvest. 60 in Market Indexes, 30 in individual equities, and the 10 is in TBills 4 week, ATM. Also, if you have debt, pay it off, not before your savings but aggressively before investing. Good luck!
Ive definitely made other people rich just from me investing.
Investing in share is high Risk activity like gambling so if someone can become rich by winning lotto I guess there must be someone becoming rich by playing in sharemarket .. But RARE.

I went from having 26K in the bank to 170,000 in 5 years. 122K is my money26K is savings There is ZERO chance I would have saved up 122K in cash sitting in my bank. Investing has changed how I save and spend.
Took me 8 years of DCAing into VTSAX as a pharmacist to get 500k in my account. I made 1.1m in 3 months with my investment in ASTS. You only need to be right one time in your investing career
To get rich from investing or trading, youre going to have to take risks.
I know a few people who have but for the most part no...investing makes you wealthier, it doesnt make you wealthy.
Investing will not make you rich. You can get rich by trading, but you can also go poor doing it.

The big issue is compounding, so even if youre a good trader. You start running math. If you start with 10 or 20,000 and you add along the way. Youre an exceptional trader, your averaging 25 to 30 of your returns. Doubling your money every 3 years. Its going to take you 15 years of actively being in front of the screen all day and doing your research and doing everything just to hit a hundred grand. Say you out a little along the way and you juice this up to 150. Its also unlikely youre going to be this good of a trader until youre at least 30 years old. You have to build your model, learn your stats, start thinking win loss ratios, get a really good handle on economics, understand technicals, all of it. Now we are 45 years old and we have a couple hundred thousand dollars. It does begin to compound rather quickly up here but the problem is youre getting older. Youre going to be in your 50s by the time you have just 1 million To make real money you need inherited wealth or you need to work in a job that has the potential of paying an extremely high salary so you can compound your wealth at a lower return and still do well. If you can land a sixfigure job and live frugally, your ability of getting your first million by the time youre 40 is fairly substantial. Moving on if we look at people who have actual wealth, 50 million maybe. They only need to take 10 million of that and put it in TLT, 4 a year dividend payment. Thats 400,000 a year they get for sitting around and buying the bottom of the bond market. They still have another 40 million full of property investments, other shares they hold. The rate they can compound their wealth is so far beyond what the average person could ever achieve. This little story right here is why we have such wealth inequality and why its only going to get worse as time goes on. Think about the amount of assets this person can buy. His children can buy, the snowball keeps growing.

Im counting FI as about 25x expenses I could make ends meet indefinitely with 60k a year, so about 1.5M for me. For RE, Id like more like 2.5M. Partly to account for inflation that would happen between hitting 1.5M and 2.5M, but mostly to just have more breathing room so I could do things like blow 15k on a vacation just because. Though Ive been blowing a lot on vacations the last few years while working, so maybe Ill be tired of it by the time I get around to retiring. I have a loose plan in my head to spend my first retirement year living cheap, just to set sort of a baseline and make sure I didnt totally underestimate costs. Specifically, how long did it take before you felt your portfolio could sustain your lifestyle without the need for additional income from employment? 12 years from 100k to 1.5M, 16 years from 100k to 2.5M. The later years are still projected, but my projections have proven reasonably accurate thus far. Real life is more noisy of course, like I came up way short in 2022 but over a fewyear timespan, the numbers are pretty good.

You need some money to make money. If you string together a set of solid bets, you can really multiply your money. I started investing around the year 2000 trying different strategies. Since I work in tech, I invested in tech because I felt like I knew it better than other industries. During the 2000s I held Apple for about 8 years starting from when the iPhone was announced . I also bought some Amazon that in the mid2000s that Ive never sold and still hold today. I bought Facebook back when they IPOed. I bought Tesla when they announced the Model 3 and never sold. There are other trades that Ive made but these are examples of my winners. When I started I used to diversity across a number of different stocks, mutual funds, index funds, etfs. I played with blue chip, international funds, small cap, etc. But over time I realized my best returns all came from tech because its pretty much been the boon to the economy for the last 30 years. So overtime I simplified my investments into fewer and fewer stocks and only held tech. Of the stocks I held, I did still try to diversify my risk. Ive posted about it online and people often will troll me about my lack of diversification but Ive grown my money considerably. I dont recommend it for everyone. But you dont need to be some crazy Gamestop investor or go wild with stock futures. Just keep hitting solid singles, doubles and home runs with decent money behind them, and you can grow your money in a decently safe manner for 12 decades. You just need patient and conviction behind your investments.

Yes. But you have to start early, be disciplined, invest significantly, and let time to the work. Nominally, if you start at 22 postcollege for sake of argument, invest 1kmo in an SP, at 65 43 years of investing, you will have approximately 7.5M. Time, inflation, and individual circumstances is going to necessarily vary your result, but the point is that time will do the work for you. But you have to start, you have to be determined it might be hard to do 1kmo on your first salary, diligent, disciplined, and have a bias toward saving. I didnt start at 22, but I do have a military pension, which offsets some of my tardiness. Also, as you grow in your career, that bias for saving is really important. For me, I determined in my nonmilitary working life to max 401k and other retirement account savings as rapidly as possible. I, and my wife do that now. We make a pretty decent amount of income, but we save about 45 all totaled. Were mid50s now, and well on track to be at numbers similar to above at 65. In fact, 7.5M is overshooting the mark for our purposes to be riskfree and welloff in retirement, so were actually now looking at 62. Retiring at 59 is in the realm of possibility, but at a reduced outlook, though still relatively risk free...just not traveling the world in the way and style we plan. I built a model recently that looked at if Id started at 22 with my current approach, and even with necessarily less investment earlier in life because my income wouldnt support max contributions, I would more likely hit about 20M by 65. That is rich by just about anyones measure, unless we have hyperinflation for the next 9 years. Investment folks out of NY or tech entrepreneurs could swamp that by an order of magitude or two. But for the average dude on the street, working W2 or 1099, thats a pretty good result using a straightforward, uncomplicated approach available to anyone. For most of us, thats all we need. Once you hit accredited investor level, other options may become available that can help you get there more quickly. But, as always, at elevated risk levels. Ive got a few 10s of thousand in a couple of those. But they are really play rather than my serious retirement plans.

Mainly investing in 401ks and some personal investments I was able to get to 2M and retired from my engineering career at 57 with a fully paid off mortgage. Approximately 35 years. As others have mentioned, that first 1M was a long hard road, and then things really soared. I live off of savings and taking some gains back out of the market when I need to make a large purchase. The NUMBER ONE piece of advice I would give to anybody is, do NOT get into debt with the exception of maybe your house. Carrying a balance on any revolving credit should be enemy number one in your battle to becoming financially independent. Carrying credit card balances, for example, will suck you dry faster than you can imagine. If you cant pay for it, you cant afford it. Thats mainly all there is to it from my perspective. EDIT I have worked with a wealth management firm for the past 5 years and has been a boon for my investing. There is no better feeling than being out of debt and having money left over at the end of the month. Life is much less stressful. Slow and steady, the best way imo.

After I started with the HON DRIP, I thought I was a fing genius during the Dotcom bubble I was heavily into QCOM and after Y2K, I lost over 300K in gains and about 80K in principal by May 2000. I realized I knew very little about stocks and valuation getting caught up in the hoopla. After maxing out my 401K and choosing from blue chips BRK, GE at the time sold when Immmelt became CEO. I made sure that I have both an upside side taking profits and a downside mitigated losses strategies. I also learned how to do DCF, read balance sheets and do DD that is when I started my speculative portfolio. Outside my DD, I also have some set opinions on the stocks I purchased. In the case of FBMETA, I thought they just had too many eyeballs to fail. On AMD, the only competitive to INTC had at the time and knew customers would not lets AMD fail as they need competition as leverage against INTC pricing. When they hire Dr. Su, they began to execute. I also thought INTC strategy of branding device name was genius but it would catch up to them as other would enter the market. Same will happen with NVDA you cannot brand name devices. I was in GE early been when Immelt became CEO, I saw him give a keynote address at a meeting and thought he was slimy. I sold it all and brought back at 6 because I thought the company was worth more apart than together. A long dead money span but it now proving correct. These stocks are in my hold and forget portfolio I taken profits and my original dollars are off the table. I have a few others in my speculative portfolio and a few on my watch list. Not financial advise, but I am watching INTC and have a set buy price.

After having success with HON, I started to think I knew about stocks. I learned my lesson during the Dotcom bubble. I thought I was a Fing genius with QCOM and few others from 19982000 and all the Y2K hoopla. In midlate Jan, there was like a 10 drop I am a fing genius, rushed in to buy the dip by mid MarchApril, lost 300K and got out it. It taught me a valuable lesson, max out retirement accounts with low cost mutual funds and save 15 cash of yearly income for emergencies, after that than purchase blue chips names and reinvest dividends. Then and only then develop a 10 stock speculative portfolio that you did a lot of DD. For me, more than 10 are difficult to keep current. Currently only have 6. One of the most important things in investing not gambling is to have both a downside and upside strategy. For my downside strategy, it is simple if I loses 1520 of my original investment dollars, I am out and ask what did I miss or were there any overriding events war, terrorism, ... I will continue to watch but rarely do I average down as I view this as throwing good money after bad. You need to remember if you lose 50, the stock needs to double just to get to even. For the upside makes sure you have a price target based on your DD and actively monitor, I typically sell 13 or 14 if it grows 2550 no harm in taking profits. If it doubles, I sell half and let the remainder ride as I view these as free shares from my original investment dollars. They become part of hold and forget portfolio that I only tap if I need the money for a big purchase car, home remodel, vacation.... Today, my hold and forget include HON 30, META 19, AMD 2, GE 6 prereverse split, LLY 60 Slow and steady wins the race. For new opportunities, I have two approaches for new opportunities I open my eyes what is trending new stores, news items, etc then I google to see if they make sense to me this is how I found Ulta and OReilly Auto Parts started seeing a lot of new stores made nice profit and got out of Ulta when I saw too many stores I got out too early but I never complain about taking profits. Secondly, I look at the smart money like Bill Gates Breakthrough Energy what are they investing in and then look for similar companies this is how I played the momentum game with QS that I am now out with a nice profit. I have my eye on three of their companies just waiting for them to go public. I retired early at 55 10 years ago. Good Luck
