It can be a good way to take chips off the table. But in the long run, you need a really good CFO and advisors to help manage it. The place I work for does a lot of ESOP work and weve seen it go both ways.
It was pretty much determined we are too small12m a year12 people and our key employees are 15 years older than me so it likely wouldnt make sense in the present day.

Ah yeah Im not an expert, but the thing I would worry about with that size is how the employees ultimately cash out. If they arent properly educatedempowered, and dont understand that they need to grow the company to build their retirement share values, they could feel they got a false promise. And if they dont cash out when they do retire that can create another set of issues. ESOPs are pretty complicated and Im always staggered how even large multibillion dollar organizations screw them up

I have a big customer who has one, that company really just mints money, they work in the power distribution field and have the best products, tech, and honestly probably doesnt rely heavily on a small handful of people. It works over time where the new people buy out the existing peoples shares over time, in the meantime dividends are paid etc. it seems to work well but they have like 5000 employees and i think its a lot more sustainable of a business.

Yes that sounds like they have it figured out. In my experience, the ones that struggle are the businesses that dont adequately message the need to sell after retirement. Then they end up saddled with a tranche of shareholders that dont provide value to the firm and start developing conflicting incentives. Also, if youre not careful the minimum repurchase requirements can catch up and strain cash flows. But if you have a competent CFO that has a handle on this stuff and youre patientmodest with the way you leverage the ESOP, it can work out ok.

content.text: Has anyone on here actually become rich just from investing?

replies.text: Its an interesting name and one of the few in this area that actually has something of a moat. I wouldnt go on analysts who probably have had those targets all the way down. If the trials fail, the stock could tank. If the trial were to fail, the stock would probably more than tank. If you are solely a psychedic drug company and a core drug fails a phase 3... probably going to be obliterated. But... thats biotech. The drug trial failing is always a possibility but I think theres still unfortunately a stigma around psychedlics. Not an applestoapples, but a lot of people were disappointed in regards to the FDA rejection of MDMA for PTSD the other day What are your thoughts? To me, this is the kind of thing that I would have a tiny position in and then if it actually starts to get some positive progress that looks like it can be sustained, bump it up from a tiny position to a small or at most medium one and continue to gradually dial up the position if it continues to prove itself. If its a tiny position and it doesnt work out, its a tiny position. I often have 13 of these sort of very earlyearly stage things and some dont work out, some do. So, I wouldnt be against this sort of thing but would really view it very realistically if anything goes wrong with the trial you could find it instadown 2550 one morning if approved, could get a nice boost then do well over time, I dont see it 5xing overnight or something and size the position accordingly.

Early stage pharmaceutical companies are notoriously risky. The burn cash like an incinerator, face more hurdles than an Olympic runner, and if you dont have a biomedical degree you have to take their word about the product. Be twice as cautious when dealing with future business prospects for a tech you dont understand.

I used to follow this space, but I gave up for now. My opinion, if youre not buying to hold for 10 years, dont buy. If you cant convince yourself that the company youre buying has a legitimate roadmap that could be continued 10 years, again, dont buy. This is not going to happen quickly in any universe. Im not saying it will never be a thing, but we are a long way away from both the public and government coming around to psychedelic drugs in a serious way. Michael Pollans How to Change Your Mind came out in 2018, is packed with revolutionary takes, was heavily promoted and marketed at the time, and analyzed across every site that wanted a click. Here we are 6 years later with no substantial changes in the space. Good luck to you guys, but this is a hard one.

Curious takes. One aspect I think about often here is when the clinical trial result speculation being thrown around... when we know these drugs have been used ceremonially for thousands of years for mental health... and I know personally the impact they have had on my life. Based on historical use of these drugs and my own empirical evidence, the clinical trial data has to be promising or at least as valuable as all the BS drugs currently used for mental health treatment. It seems like a very worthwhile risk to bet on something I know has worked well for myself, before clinical trials show the efficacy.

replies.text: This is a python script, courtesy of the Youtuber Finxter, that backtests the strategy of investing in ONLY the top 5 companies by market cap each year from 1990 til 2024. You can see that this has outperformed the sp500 for the past 34 years. Take that as you will.

I just kinda remember what I thought about various stocks, think hmmm I wonder how that ones been doing? and then check to see if my predictions were right or not.

To backtest quickly youre going to need some coding experience. You can test any strategy you want, if you think somethings predictive with python and a dataset you can comb the historical data for each instance that predictive event occurred and check to see the return generated by taking that trade. A simple strategy could be if the high of this bar is higher than the last bar AND the low of this bar is lower than the last bar, take a position based on the directional change of this bar. Or if I buy 0dte calls with 500 every week how much money will I lose in 5 years.

Im surprised nobody has picked up on the 23 year outlook part of your post OP. The stock market is a long term game, longer term than 23 years. Lets say you started investing in SPY in 2000 at the height of the dot com bubble. Bubble pops, SPY proceeds to drop around 40 over the next 2 years. Starts steadily climbing and you finally have a small profit 6 years later and... the 2008 financial crisis happens. Takes another 5 years to get back to breakeven. So 13 yewrs of negative to flat returns. Now this is disregarding dividend reinvestment because I am supposed to be working now so dont want to calculate it, but long term investing is over decades, not 23 years. Over a LONG ENOUGH time period, the market had always increased. But there have also been whole decades that, looked at alone, have had flat or negative returns. Its just up to your risk tolerance, and what you can afford to lose. Im not gonna say what I think the market is going to do over the next few years, but just keep in mind that there is no guarantee that prices will be above what they are now, in that short of a time period in the future.

I am a financial advisor, and while I deal more in diversified portfolios consisting of ETFs and Mutual funds, the following advice holds true for any portfolio its not about timing the market, it is about time in the market. Essentially, timing the market is virtually impossible. You do not know when the worst days are going to come, and you do not know when the best days are going to come. Selling your investments out of fear because of a steep dip in the market can prove to be a costly mistake, because not only will you be realizing those losses, but your running the risk of missing out on potential gains. Using the SP 500 as a benchmark, here is what a 10,000 investment would be worth today if it was first invested in 1994 and you Missed the 30 best days of the SP 500 30,889 Missed the 20 best days of the SP 500 48,874 Missed the 10 best days of the SP 500 83,272 Stayed fully invested all 30 years 181,763 No one knows when the best days are going to happen, but trying to time the market pretty much ensures that you will at least miss out on some of those days. Also, people tend to sell when stocks are low out of fear, and they tend to buy when stocks are high out of greed. That is the exact opposite of what you are supposed to be doing. Now is the time to hold, and buy more since everything is at a discount.

Buy and hold good companies and you wont have to worry about how much it drops. People seem to have a huge misinterpretation of the stock market treating it as a casino. Good companies DO NOT cater when share prices are low. I havent checked my portfolio in weeks. I couldnt care less. Because every share of a company I own are strong companies with solid fundamentals. The case to time the market only works if you have a strong inclination of what will happen shortterm. Its way too questionable right now to make a decision like that. Theres also a strong argument that the market should have NEVER gone up the way it did. Taking profit off the board isnt a bad idea.

Please dont spread panic. Selling right not is a guarantee disaster. You will not time it correctly when getting back in and miss out on any significant gain. Absolutely the worst advice is to panic sell

Its like clockwork. The reason people say to hold through red is because its nearly impossible to time this. You seem very sure that you will be able to sell on Monday and then rebuy on Wednesday at a lower price, but the reality of it is you have no idea what is actually going to happen, and neither does anyone. If it was so clear what the direction was going to be then the price would already be baked in, in fact it most likely already is from last week. The most likely scenario is you sell on Monday and then wait for it to go lower. It never goes lower and then you get fomo and rebuy at a higher price. This is the predictable but boring way in which people lose money by trying to time the market.

You have literally no control of the markets once you sell out, how do you know when its time to get back in? By the time your back in you likely have missed the bottom. Sure, you can get lucky, but the best investors in the world cant accomplish the strategy youre talking about right now.

Obviously you can pick what you want to do with your money but it sounds like you are either inexperienced or you are in a panic about a paper loss. It depends on so many things, and its not at all as simple to do as you make it sound. First, is your motivation to lock in some amount of gains so you dont feel regretupset if the direction does in fact go where you think it will go? Or is your idea motivated more by the potential opportunity to boost your expected future gains by some amount by rebuying half your portfolio back at a lower cost? Would you reinvest the total proceeds to end up with more shares, Or would you buy the same number of shares you had, only cheaper, and take the difference as cash profit? In other words,, shorting your own portfolio Another POV is, what if you could hypothetically freeze the volatility in your portfolio, aka go delta neutral, no losses no gains, until you feel the outlook is sufficient enough to the upside to unfreeze the volatility? One could hedge the whole or part portfolio with a protective Put option on an index such as QQQ. You wouldnt have to sell anything, so no cap gains tax, and your net unrealized gains would be the same as now until you release the cap. Youd need to have the capital to pay the premium ofc. This is not easy and not advice. Just an example. Further, your current net Unrealized gains need to be considered and weighed against the tax event of just straight selling. Also important to consider is that the Fed does not give AF about market prices going up or down. The SP could grind down to 2,000 between now and December and JPow couldnt care less. Instead, what the Fed hates is volatility. The VIX. Thats when the Fed steps in with their own protective Put. The Fed hates Volatility cuz Wall St. hates unusual Volatility. Last I checked VIX was 2 STDEV 36 above the mean 20. The last time that happened was in 2020 and we got the Fed Put QE, emergency rate cuts. You dont wanna get caught in that and you never know whenif its gonna come. You can get caught off sides and chasing. My point is that these things, and about 20 other possibilities, variables and outcomes covered in other comments, reveal that its not easy at all to do this, effectively, in a Risk Adjusted way that returns you proper gains for the risk youd be taking by messing with any of this. Not to mention tax events. Weve all tried it. Most have learned the hard way its just not worth it. Others succeeded. Luck? Skill? Sophistication? No one can know unless you do this consistently with reproducible outcomes. But there arent enough crashes for that if were calling this that hypothetically. So one needs to practice this whole Buy Low, Sell High thing, and in reverse as well, and get good at it. But what thats called is Trading, not Investing. If you have the time to put into all that entails by opening bell, or already have, godspeed. But without some really careful and thoughtful planning, it can get real ugly real fast, worse than holding. Esp if you dont plan on needing the capital returned anytime soon. Tbh, if its more of a I dont wanna sit on my hands and watch this go down thing, thats understandable. But maybe consider messing with 25 or 10 or 5 just to see how it goes. It helps feed the itch to take action. But obvs with much less risk of getting into a needlessly risky situation. Cheers

This time it isnt about the stock market its about the currency as well. This is the big risk my economics professors discussed with us more than 20 years ago which is a lifetime market risk not a business cycle depending on how it plays out. This time the risk is the end of the US Debt cycle and the US Dollar being the global currency. The issue is the Japanese have been loaning the world Yen in trade for US Dollars meaning they hold a significant amount of US Debt. This currency move up with the JPY getting stronger is causing the carry trade to get unwound. Many may not know this but the reason that MUFG is crashing is that this bank is at the heart of vendor financing programs globally. GE Capitals vendor financing program which included not only GE but Honeywell, and many other large industrials went to MUFG since they are the ones who for years operated the sale of the bonds in Japan. A vendor financing program is one in which there is a payment term of say 1 at 15 days net of 60 days. Behind this is a bond and vendor financing program on the buyer side and a factoring program on the seller side of companies. If this issue can not get stopped, the risk will spread from a market risk to a currency risk where Japan, China, UK and other large holders of US Debt sell the US Bonds and there is no one to buy. If this happens the value of the US Dollar will dramatically drop. Then the risk becomes not a stock market risk but a stock market risk in terms of the US Dollar. GLD, SLV, GLDX, GLDXJ, SIL

If you are not a trader with a definable edge this is important and I ended my almost 2 decade professional options trading career when I no longer had a legitimate reason to think I had a definable trading edge over the general market, but an investor, and you cant fight the urge to sell, then your portfolio is either too large for your risk tolerance or is composed of the wrong investment vehicles. To your first point.. A great financial columnist, Scott Burns, argument against timing the market was the fact that market timers often have their money on the sidelines on the big gain days. He had some statistical evidence to support it. And when that occurs, you cause way more damage than just riding out the losses. This is because the combination of all movements gains and losses always work out to be gains over any material time span. I think most people know this, but some lack the discipline to sit idly by and watch their portfolio value drop 10. When I was younger, I tried to time the market because I thought the market was overpriced and poised to pop, and I looked at my account balances way too often. I also paid way more attention to the financial news and the SP movements than I should have. I liquidated my investments to cash. I was so smart!! Of course I was wrong, the market went up, and I waited and waited for the market to slide so that I could reinvest. The right time never came, and I missed out on a lot of gains. I DCAd back into the market over a years time. It was super painful, and I lost a lot of future value. HUGE mistake. HUGE. Today, I dont read financial news, and I only look at my account balances quarterly when I update my balance sheet.

Once you are out on the sideline, you will always wait for a lower point to buy back, 1. Stock goes back up higher than your original selling point. You screwed up and refuse to buy back since its already higher. You keep waiting for lower entry and miss the entire run. 2. Stock keeps going down, news still negative, you have no source to determine if it is the bottom or will go down another 5. You have no choice but stay out and keep waiting. There will be a point it hit the lowest and start coming back, you are used to it go dead cat bounce and keep crashing down. But this time it didnt go down and up like a rocket, you of course missed it and start debating if it is over or just another bull trap. News still lag behind, negative everywhere. You keep waiting and waiting for more negative until it almost back to the price when you sold. You buy back and wasted the entire time. People didnt even touch their stock sitting at the same position. So if you set a rule to buy back when break even, you cant make gains. because condition 1 you lose, condition 2 you break even. If you set a rule to only buy back if 10 or 20 down, the more greedy you are the more risk you are taking if the stock never go down that much and the buy back never triggered, you miss the entire run up. You make 25 gain if you wait for 20 down to buy back. If it happens, you make 25, if it didnt happen, all it take is once and your loss is infinite because you never buy back. So repeatedly betting big down to buy back is a lose play in long run. So what happens is exactly like casino, every time you make a safer small bet to buy back to with only a small down. You did it 10 times and thought you beat the system. You are winning so you will never quit, until one day stock fake down and keeping going up never come back, and you are still waiting for a lower entry after 5 years because you refuse to accept the reality. Plus sitting in IVV VOO will get you dividend, you missed that for years as well. Timing market is exactly like gambling. I learnt from 20212022. There always will be casino winners and day traders flash their winning money and selling courses. But 99 other losers take their losses quietly and go back to regular jobs. For most people it takes actual big loss experience to understand that gambling psychology in trading stocks.

My approach to technical analysis combines the study of crowd behavior, and whether fundamentals could allow the valuation to get to the projected possible outcomes. It also emphasizes the use of Bayesian probability. Science, math and technology often look like magic to the uninitiated. But hey to each is own. I also believe fundamental analysis alone can still yield great results.

Thanks for the feedback! I agree, my approach could be rather time intensive when you first start. It took me a while to get to the point where I can get my ongoing research done in 12 hours per day. Do you have any tactic or aspect of your investingtrading style that really defined it?
Not a fan? Do you mind expanding on that constructively? Do you want to share your approach to investing? I was hoping to spark discussion by expressing my approach the best I could in a brief way.

They mix in good picks to maintain some semblance of competence. Of course never assign malice for what could just be incompetence. Regardless its the contrarian life for me. There is no best strategy, however there are best strategies for individuals. Regardless the majority should stick with buying mostly ETFs based on SP500 and not attempt stocks individually. Did not mean to be overly flippant your post was fine, and you put effort into it.

Markets behave within a general spectrum and capitalizing on it is fairly easy. Of course black swans come in and thats where everyone gets burned. For real fuck RSI, look at how the broad market moves away from the 200 and go by percentages and back test it and you can see how overbought things were before a correction. Use this as a confirmation with all your other analysis that you are surely using.
I stopped trying to be perfect. An 85 solution was more than sufficient, and trying to get to 95 was more likely to result in paralysis than in optimal results. Good luck!

Dont expect a lot of fanfare. I do what you do and get downvoted all the time. I love seeing the cyclical buy ins when smart money and insiders buy and you can see usually bang on when the diversions hit in technical analysis. The other thing that I do is analyze how far in an uptrend price action flies up in exuberance away from the 200 and make my sell orders accordingly and buys of course. All of this is on a strong foundation of fundamental analysis. Without the fundamentals, technical analysis means literally nothing. I would say all technical analyzers would agree unless, of course, they are day traders and thats entirely different and not applicable to this style of trading.

There is no best strategy, however there are best strategies for individuals. This is so true. Every person will have the personality or cognitive habits that mesh well with a particular strategy that might not work out well for another. I also agree that ETFs based on the SP 500 are a best practice for most people. I think it takes an unparalleled enthusiasm towards the process for someone to benefit from stock picking and even more for market timing. You gotta love the process.
That sounds like a good use of mean reversion. Like you said Id need to compare to all the other signals for confirmation but I like this longer term signal.

I like this, no such thing as a perfect setup. Thats why I like using Bayesian probability. I think looking for a perfect deterministic setup can indeed cause too much hesitation. As long as youre hitting probabilities that allow for profit with your rewardrisk ratio then youre likely to make money over the long run.
I like what youre putting down my friend. Id love to hear more about this 200. Are you using Bollinger bands to give you perspective on this exuberance?

You are optimistic about peoples general ability. Im less so, at least 70 of all people would never be able to conceptualize applying any guidelines to new situationsstocks, the learned traits area of the brain is in direct space competitionright next to the section for conceptualizing. Of the 30 whos brains are wired for it how many can do it better then the market? The number becomes very low of the population very quickly. This sort of talk tends to piss people off for whatever reason. I had a few very simple questionsmetal puzzles during interview process that would let me know. owned an engineering firm Based on the results I would hire people without a degree over someone with a engineering degree. Innate abilityhow a person brain works cannot be taught. Flip side everyone I hired were the worst spellers with terrible grammar, smaller learned traits portion of the brain.
Yes I am unaware of a technical analysis tool that does this calculation so I do it manually from the highs and the lows off the average.

No just percentages away from the 200. You can see it like clockwork when it swings up too high with the usual vicissitudes and exuberance. Lets face it, you can do the same with the EPS daily or whatever but I prefer using the 200MDA. You can get a real feel for how overbought a stock is and make a reasonable assumption of a natural pullback.

I like your first principles approach here. I do agree that some people have significant cognitive advantages. They can learn quicker. They think faster. They have better analogical reasoning. Better pattern recognition. I recently had seen some anecdotal evidence to the contrary though. I know AI and human brains arent equally comparable, but I found this really intriguing. Open AIs ChatGPT has parameter counts rumored to be in the trillions and llama 3.1 has around 400 billion parameters. Even with this vast difference in size Im looking at this like brain power llama is competing quite well because they found that if they just spend way more time training the model it magnifies its ability. I think these findings are probably having an effect on the development of GPT5 or whatever they plan to name it. This leads me to hypothesize that anyone can do anything if you have enough time and effort. This still brings you to a fork in the road. How much value will you get for the extra time and effort put into learning the craft? I dont think this will change many employers minds but it could give confidence and motivation to people who want to improve themselves.

The general rules is anyone above 115IQ can learn any career. However I was not talking about IQ, just areas of the brain that helps with certain tasks. Nasa did a study many decades ago trying to find out why some of the smartest aerospace minds in the world could not spell aerospace. Brain scans revealed the space competing parts of the brains next to each other. The general rule is you cannot teach someone to be good at troubleshoot new things if they dont have that innate ability, its not a direct IQ indication but rather a brain thing. You have a method and can do it because that is how your brain works, thinking of a box in your mind one side of it is red, can you rotate the box in your mind and seeknow where the red side of the box is even when its on the otherside of your perspective eyes 70 of people cannot do that and you cannot teach them to do it.

I admit a might have a bias here. As I was reading your comment I was flipping around a box with a single red side in my head, simultaneously thinking Where is he going with this?. Then youre like 70 of people cant do this. Im like oh . But this is why people should go the SP 500 route long term and paper trade till they feel confident in what they are doing. Then run their plans by multiple financial advisors and experts before making any detrimental decisions that could affect their lifestyle. Even if someone never makes it out of paper trading I think its a rewarding experience. I think Im in love with the process as much as the end goal.

replies.text: Youre missing the difference between causation and correlation. The rate cuts themselves dont cause bear markets. The reasons for the rate cuts do.
The ground is always wet when it rains. Therefore, the ground being wet causes rain.

Feds doesnt overlook the global market, only the USA side. Global economics do affect the US market since international trade is part of the economy. Meaning you cant selectively look at rate cuts vs. US BullBear market without understanding the macroeconomics of the entire world.
Fiscal surpluses or near surpluses predict recessions and bear markets. Rapid rate hikes predict bull markets and a switch to trickledown economics.
If anything, as yields drop, it may cause money to flow into the stock market seeking higher returns.

I think its entirely possible the fed and gov will simply accept societal decay as they gear all policy toward keeping corporations and even the government itself from blowing up due to their debt levels. For instance, are we going to be cutting rates because of a recession, or because a ton of corporate debt comes due in 2025? Im not sure what the real drivers are anymore.
So Rate cause is Recession? Recession is the cause that will make market crash? Then rate hikes are caused due to inflation. Inflation is the cause that will make market crash?
Rate cuts come during recessions to help spur the economy. So you see rate cuts in bear markets because it takes time for those cuts to have an impact.

And we are hitting a plateaupoint of diminishing return with our current training strategies. Its whoever monetizes these LLMs is whos winning that war. OpenAI is already losing ground to anthropic and Gemini. Fwiw goog is a great investment if thats what your trying to get to. But just pointing out that it isnt the only alt player in the ai chips race.

Efficiently. You missed this important caveot. Only Google TPUs and Nvidia today. AMD probalby soon. But Amazon can NOT run LLMs efficiently on their own silicon and stuck using Nvidia. This gives Google a HUGE competitive advantage over everyone else.

replies.text: Look at all your essential expenses per month rent, car payment, food, etc. Essential. Add it up. Multiply by 3 or 6 to be safer. Keep this amount in cash in a highyield savings account. You do not have this money. This is your safety net. You are walking on a highwire in life, and something may happen lose your job, get injured and cant work, your parent is dying and you decide you must care for them full time, etc. This money catches you when you fall. Some bad shit will happen in life. Hopefully not permanentlylifedebilitating, but some really turbulent times are almost guaranteed. Walk the highwire of life with a net.

To answer your question about waiting 13 business days for emergencies. There are very few true emergencies where you absolutely need thousands of dollars CASH right this second. A credit card can be used for everything truly emergent, then the HYSA gets transferred into the Checking to cover the CC bill later. However, having truly liquid cash in a local bank or credit Union still isnt a horrible idea. Even if its just 500. Some people carry like 3k in their local bank for this reason.

Everyone keeps their emergency funds in money markets or I bonds. 36 depends on risk tolerance, job stability, employability, etc. Personally, I lived through 2008 and watched really smart people stay unemployed for two years. My emergency fund is larger.

SPAXX is a great place to put your emergency fund, especially if you have a cash back credit card from Fidelity. Thats where I keep most of mine. I also keep a a few hundred to a couple thousand in physical cash in case of an emergency where my cards are inaccessible.

You can keep your emergency fund in a money market fund like SPAXX Ikeep about half of my emergency fund there. Investing all of it in the market is highly risky even in a dividend ETF like SCHD. With my personal experience, I keep a years worth of salary as an emergency fund, so I would go with the 6 months because it can take a while to find a job.
deleted

Read the FAQ here first A few of your beliefs are inaccurate. getting 5 or so interest Bear in mind that interest rates change. The shortterm rate at 5 is considered unusual so you should not assume that it will stay at 5. It likely will be lower. Fidelity has only broken the dollar 3 times in history No Fidelity money market fund has ever broken the buck. See discussion of what that means in the in faq. money market like with an ETF like SCHD or is that too risky for what should be a stable nest egg? You are comparing a ultrashort duration bond fund which typically holds treasuries, government obligations, investment grade commercial paper, etc in heavily regulated asset structure with an equity fund. There are lots of other asset class inbetween a cashequivalent and an equity fund. should I be closer to the 3 or the 6 months of the 36 months range? That is a personal choice. And depends on your personal situation I.e. do you have a steady job? do you have access to credit? can you rely on support from family and friends? Etc. etc.
Find a bank with better rates. Capital One, Ally, Sofi, etc offer above 4 interest rates. The purpose of the emergency fund is to be able to grab cash out quickly if need be.

You should have accessible cash, I personally use spaxx because anything really expensive is usually not due same day and you can use a credit card while money transfers. So, 6 months in spaxx and then a taxable brokerage account buying voo or something, that way you can sell and pull from that as well if something happens but its a lower risk investment that can still grow, hoping you dont have to access it.

Emergency fund is the answer to the question what do I need to pay for my lifestyle for the next 6 months if I lose my job or if the economy goes to shit?. You dont want to have to sell stocks on short notice if you lose your job or the market has tanked, so its good to have money market savings or other short term treasury style investments that you can access in that time. If you dont have a high limit credit card, youd also want to have some balance in your checking account to pay for unexpected expenses like car repairs. And going down the prepper road, you could add in cash to deal with the case where you lose your wallet or cant access electronic funds for a couple weeks, like if theres a fire, earthquake, or hurricane. Going further down the prepper road, add in physical gold that is in your possession to deal with the case where the entire financial system collapses, inflation skyrockets, currency becomes worthless, or you need to pay people to help you flee the country.

Everything youve written is pretty much spot on. Not sure about the downvotes either. Here are some answers The most common purpose of an emergency fund is to cover your personal expenses in the event your main source of income suddenly goes to zero. The recommended 36 months should depend on the expected time for you to secure a new job. For example if you are a fast food worker it may be shorter vs. an executiveCEO it may be longer. It will also depend on the job market in your industry. One risk is that the sudden loss in income can come during a recession when many others are also looking for employment. In this case it may take longer to find another job. The US would pretty much need to default on their debt for SPAXX to tank. Very low likelihood in the next 10 years and beyond. This is fine to invest in as you say you would then only need to cover the 13 business days for the money to transfer to your checking account. In my opinion a cc is a perfectly reasonable short term source of liquidity that can be paid back with your emergency fund.

Having your emergency fund in any liquid investment is okay. Dont put it in real estate that could take weeks or months to liquidate. Its best not to have it in certificates of deposit or retirement funds that would penalize a withdrawal. Any other kind of bank account or stock or mutual fund should be fine, because you could get the cash into your checking account within a few days. You might want to leave room on a credit card or keep a balance in your bank account to tide you over while investments are being sold and the proceeds transferred.

For my emergency fund I like to keep it in different levels of liquidity. In my checking account that I use every day I keep about a months worth of expenses. At the same bank I keep another month in savings. In a high yield savings at an online bank I keep another two months. With liquidity, hear me out, even 3 days can be too much. I have everything set on autopay and once or twice when I wasnt watching my checking too closely it went negative. For every transaction that hits after that the fees will add up quickly. If Im not able to transfer money instantly Id have to pay a ton in fees.
SPAXX is fine, and the size of the fund is a personal choice. You want peace of mind, and you dont want to be forced to sell a stock at a bad time because your car got totaled, or you got fired.

I keep 6 months expenses in SPAXX because if I lose my job I want to have some time to find a new one. To me a money market like SPAXX is fine. I keep about a month of expenses in my checking account and I also have credit cards. I also keep a few hundred in cash just in case of the kind of emergency where the power goes out for a long time.
If you are a single individual then three months is okay. Especially if you are working to pay down debts if you have CC debt then work of that first. But if you have a family then 6 months is better

I know youre basically just out of school, but you dont need to overoptimize all your money. Its ok to have 36 months of money not making interest. Its just insurance. And, trust me, when it rains it pours. When I first got out of college, not only would my car need new brakes, but also, the turning belt would break. Or I would need new tires. Or there would be a leak under the sink. You really should have this money easily accessible. Could it be in a spaxx or bonds, sure. You almost never need the money right now especially if you have a credit card with a high limit. But I wouldnt put it in any real etfs like SP500, etc. Because itll just be your luck that your emergency coincides with the next recession and there goes all your money.

It means you take what you spend in 1 month and multiply it by a number between 36 and keep that much in the bank for emergencies. The exact number depends on your risk tolerance and circumstances. For example, if you are in a career field where layoffs are common or it may be difficult to get a new job, you are probably closer to 6. If you are confident you can get back on your feet quickly, 3 is fine. It really does not matter where you keep this money because it should not be a significant part of your nest egg. I know it may seen like a lot of money when you are starting out, but in the grand scheme of things its really not, and the interest you make will not make a difference in your life. What is more important is that you can access this money quickly in the event of a emergency. Now if you MUST make some interest or else you cant sleep at night, you can put it in a HYSA or even a money market or the any interest generating fund. No one said it has to just sit in the bank. It is true that not that many emergencies require instant liquidity.

It means whatever you want it to mean. Its purpose is to make people think about keeping a stash of money for unplanned expenses. What those expenses are and how much you should put aside for them are entirely up to you. Given the current job market plus the fact that my employer started laying off people in small batches a year ago, my focus is on income replacement in case I get laid off! Before then, my emergency fund was more for a tree falling on my house or my cars engine exploding. I do regular maintenance and inspections on most items, so a surprise dead furnace or AC unit is unlikely. There is no consensus of what exactly an Emergency funds is , how much it should be, or where you should keep it. if you ask 10 people , youll get 20 different answers So figure out what unplanned expenses concern you, then how much you should put away for them, and finally where to keep the money. In the end, the fund is for you, and you should design it around your needs.

Dont take being down graded personally. Often times I find people on investing are snarkyrude in their response andor downgrade questions if they feel like people should know already. Everyone is learning at their own speed. Being thats youve been investing for years and you already have a Roth IRA and IRA, youre in good shape and have a great trajectory.
In case you lose your job you dont want to sell your investments to pay the bills.
Probably 10k

IMO 3 months if you have a very stable job ex governmenttenure, 6 months if you live in an atwill employment state, and 12 months if you have a housemortgage and dependents andor work in a niche field with long hiring processes. There is also debate if it should be essential living expenses, your normal expenses, or gross income. The answer depends on your risk tolerance. Additionally, while many conflate items like repairing a car and replacing a hot water heater with using emergency funds, its often because people forget to plan for semi regular expenses rather than a true emergency. For example, a tree falling through your roof is an emergency. A 30 year old roof resulting in leaks and a burst pipe is a maintenance costs you need to plan for. So sinking funds emergency funds usually results in a smaller EF. Another good rule of thumb is to male sure that your EF is at least twice your max OOP for health insurance so you can have one health scare leftover funds.

The whole idea of recommending a 3 month worth of emergency funds is just an estimate of how much a person would need for any emergency situations or contingencies. This is just like keeping some money aside for any unforeseen expense say you have an accident or say your refrigerator broke down or you have a major car repair to deal with or a health emergency. I think you did not understand this basic purpose of emergency fund. The emergency fund is not intended to earn good interest or return, so thats not a consideration. If you still want to put it in highinterest earning accounts, good for you, but thats not the objective. I agree with your point about having credit card to cover emergecies but thats also how people get in to a debt trap I dont need to explain this you know it. Lastly for some people I understand building 36 months emergency fund is difficult. For example for someone earning 5000 a month and having 3000 a month expenses, the suggested emergency fund would be in the range of 9000 to 18000. Saving 10,000 or more is not easy in the context of high inflation and lifestyle expenses we have today. So the way to get to atleast 9000 is to set aside regular sums every week say put in 200 a week and by end of the year you will reach the 10000 mark. Its not like one day you wake and say I will put 10k in emegency fund, its a slow process. Now summing up all the above the emergency funds is for emergencies its not for optimizing your returns, for that you need to do longterm investing.

6 months of essentials and a little extra. A healthy EF will be over 6 months. Essentials are things you cant live without...food, shelter, utilities, transportation, etc. As your income increases, so does the cost of your essentials so your EF needs to keep up. I always say a little extra because in an emergency you need some relief and escapes for your sanity. So although Netflix, or movie night, or that bowl of ice cream isnt essential...it sure is a reprieve from lifes stresses so build just a little of that into your EF. If you are starting out...HYSA and dont look back to keep it in. As you get more comfortable with your plan and larger EF...you can start to change it up bonds, bond etfs, bond ladders, credit card, etc I keep 12 months in HYSA, 3 in I series bonds, I have dedicated credit card for immediate expenses, and then varying degrees of ETFs for additional 6 months. Remember an Emergency could be a job loss during a market turn down, so if you have your EF in stocks or higher risk securities, that value could be substantially less than what you had planned on.

An emergency fund is simply money set aside and untouched, not to be circulated into your regular savings or accounted for whatsoever. For a lot of people, this is money to be used solely in the event of job loss, or for big, sudden expenses lets say a new roof not covered by insurance that you would otherwise go into debt. 36 months is a fairly good measure. This figure is based off your fixed, necessary monthly expenses. Housing, food, utilities, insurance, etc. then multiply it and save it. Most importantly, and why you may have gotten downvoted, the money needs to be liquid. A HYSA is the best place to hold it. Its not an investment. It needs to be accessible at a moments notice. It shouldnt be subject to any kind of market volatility. And should only be used as a last resort, aftwr exhausting all other forms of savings and monies available.

You can keep your emergency fund in a money market account. For all intents and purposes, that is a cash equivalent. Nobody is going to be hit with a 20k bill that they have 0 days to pay it off. The real meaning of this is if theres job loss, a major car repair, injury, or natural disaster. You can even use CDs or ibonds for your efund. It doesnt matter much if you take a small interest rate hit to use your money. It probably doesnt matter if itll take a week to get to all of it. I have about 68 months of cash on hand I keep most of my cash in a HYSA. In my mid 20s I kept about 34 months. It may feel bad to not have that money in a real investment, but it is also important to have this money saved in a nonvolatile, zero risk place so it is always available. The interest youre getting from these is going to counter inflation so your cash isnt wasting away doing nothing. I would recommend that your checking account has at minimum 1 full months expenses in it at all time and some extra buffer. My CCs are on automatic payment and I dont want an accidental 700 to cause an overdraft from my checking account. Having some money in a place where it isnt earning interest isnt a problem 5 interest on 1.55kyear is not going to make or break your existence. The next lesson to understand is that there is in fact a value to convenience. You dont need to keep every penny you own socked away in a 5 money market account.

I do the basic expenses plus however much COBRA would be for health insurance and have that be my guide for one month of expenses to save. That way, I also make sure my medical expenses are addressed as well.

I opted to go off my income rather than my expenses cause it was easier than nitpicking what expenses to consider. Now Ive got X months of income to cover the loss of paychecks. Plus, if you save X months of income itll def last longer if you do have to buckle down on expenses. I put my emergency fund in a HYSA. Agreed you dont need it instantly most anything can wait for a transfer. I wouldnt overcomplicate that one. Its job is to sit untouched for the most part anyway. And you should have as much as you think you would need should you end up unemployed. Depends what you do and what that job market looks like. In 2024 it sounds like that answer is more time is needed than less for most people...
Hide a few ounces of preferably fractional gold around your home.
Whats ur budget for 36 monhs
If I have an emergency Ill use one of my lines of credit. Hasnt happened yet, so that money has been making me money for 10 years.
What was the last unexpected thing that happened to you that cost you a lot? Well, something like that is going to happen again. Be ready.

I do it simply 3 current salaries kept on a savings account with interests close to inflation. It is available immediately and doesnt lose value, it doesnt make any significant profit either. Thats why anything saved above 3 salaries goes to ETFs, stock and such. It is still available in an emergency but not immediately, but generates profit, at least I hope so.
36 isnt enough. You need 1224 realistically.
You have 23 and dont know what expenses are?

Traditionally I recommend 3 months of expenses in a HYSA at a local credit union. The other 3 months in a brokerage account money market fund or SGOV. Anything past the 6 months of living expenses should go into a brokerage account and invested for future big ticket items like a car. But that future big ticket investing is only done after you are out of debt, and have your retirement funds established, so no student loans, car loans, credit card debt, medical debt, or personal loans. Mortgage loans are different and not considered bad debt. Student loans are not considered bad debt but they can spiral into bad debt. If youre in debt, get out of it quickly so you can build for your future.
Emergency funds are indeed necessary. After all, you never know when you will get sick or have a career. I mean that kind of special situation.

Go for 6 months if you can. The idea is to be prepared for if your income stops coming in or you have a major unexpected expense on your home or car. The money should be enough to cover rent, utilities, food and other regular expenses.
How much do you need to have in liquid savings to sustain yourself if you lost your job? How quickly can you find a job that pays what you need to live on.

We used the mid point between the bare bones minimum and our average monthly spending for a realistic amount. We have 6 months because my husband works in a highly volatile sector of the economy. Its in a high interest saving account. Weve had to use it before so we see it differently than some people do. This isnt just an item in a list of things I should do. This is a level of security for when something goes wrong. The last time we dipped into it was for a new AC system for our house. It kind of functions like a line of credit to ourselves. But it would see us through a sudden loss of income major illness etc.

Yeah. You dont have to have the money in a checking account. I keep my cash split between bank account. Fidelity cash management account US Treasury Ibonds. My Amex has something like a 20k credit limit if I have a major expense that I cant cover from my bank account. Then I can liquidate some other sources to pay off my bill.

It is funds you would need to pay for your essential month to month expenses. Mortgagerent, groceries, utilities, insurance, etc. Subscriptionsleisure isnt included. Those should be axed in the event of an emergency. I would argue the world is more volatile than it was before and 36 months wont be enough. 612 would be much safer. First hand experiencespeaking with others in my life finding a job nowadays takes a lot longer than 36 months.

Many young professionals out of college just got started get their unemployment experience even on first year. Not well established. Not experienced and able to find work even past 6 months when reserve quickly ran out. That applies to civil service workers. Can you use credit car to pay your rent?

You job covers most of your day to day living expenses with a bit left over for other things like vacations, repairs to car home, or investing. But at the end of each month most of that is gone. But every once in while something happens and you need more money. Credit cards and personal loans are expensive due to high interest. A savings account is cheeper. But is dont have to be in a bank. You could set up a taxable account at a brokerage such as fidelity. They offer money market cash accounts. so you can put a few months to a full your of money in it with decent interest to cover unexpected cash needs. And they can issue you a debit card to give your easy access to the money. But you do have to pay taxes on the interest. If the interest in your money market account gets high you start being stocks or funds that either dont pay a dividend or pay a very small dividend. like amazon or the SP00 index fund like VOO. You could save several years or more of money this way with minimal to no aditiaional tax. And if thinks go well you get some capital gains which grows your savings even more with minimal or no tax. To accesss this savings you would have to enter sell order to sell some stocks or some of the fund. This at a minimum will fake a few days or sometimes about a week. Once complete the money will be in your cash account. The size of the each or long term savings is up to you. I personally have about 6 months of cash on hand and currently have about 3 years in stocks that dont pay a dividend. Now there is one other thing you can do with a taxable account. Build a living income fund or fire account.Financial Independence Retire Early. In this portion of the account you can invest ins stock or ETF that pay a higher dividend than money market account. Depending on your risk tolerant you can get a dividend yield of up to 10. And this money would go into your cash account so you can use it for living expenses such as food , utility bills medical insurance or anything you want. I have an ETF PFFD that tas a yield of 6 and several stocks that pay a similar or higher yeild. My taxable account currently generates about 4000 a month which covers most of my living expenses. Due to this job equivalent income I have to plan for taxes So I estimate my earnings and either set the money aside for the april tax bill or send pay the tax to the IRS ahead of time.

but it isnt a zero risk investment though very very low I understand Fidelity has only broken the dollar 3 times in history I had to look this up .This was not from the company Fidelity. it was 2 other banks. No Fidelity Money Market fund has ever broken the buck. There have been 2 money market funds in history that have dropped below 1 which happened in 1994 and 2008. 1994 Community Bankers US Govt MM small institutional fund 82 mil AUM they were using derivatives which went against them. Was liquidated at .96 to shareholders. 2008 Reserve Primary MM 64 billion AUM held 785 mil of Lehman Brothers commercial paper 1.2 holding which became worthless. They couldnt meet redemption requests, value dropped to .97 and was liquidated. Basically what happened is that during the normal day to day trading in the money market fund there are many money market funds. And unexpected even occurred causing the interest rate for the day to go negative.Basically when this happened the account was closed and liquidated. IN both cases after the liquidation each account holder got about 95 of their deposit back

The 36 months of expenses in an emergency fund thing is basic advice intended for people who are not particularly financial savvy and need things stated in extremely simple terms. Since this is rinvesting, this deserves a more nuanced discussion than most of the replies youve received so far have contributed. We should be able to understand things here like opportunity cost, max historic drawdowns of asset classes, etc.. We also should have a good understanding of our actual income and expenses, what the risks are to our income sources, what the value of and risks to our assets are, what expenses can be adjustedeliminated over time in the case of a long term loss of income, etc.. I personally regret having followed the 36 months advice too literally when younger. It was money I never needed and never came close to needing and wouldve grown to much greater levels had I invested it instead. People will respond that I was just lucky and what if, etc., but really it just turns out that in those downtimes, you adapt and adjust and find solutions. Besides myself, I cannot think of any partner, friend, family member, or coworker that I am aware of a situation where they ever needed six months of living expenses within 13 days. Never. I cant even imagine a scenario where that would happen. All of this gets down to specifics of your personal finances and situation, so no blanket statement exists, but I dont think it is hard constructing an investment portfolio for an emergency fund that properly balances risk and return, perhaps bootstrapping it with some percentage of buffer above historic max drawdown for that asset allocation. The fun thing is watching it grow over the years past that buffered amount and beyond, eventually getting to the point where even a historic market crash would leave you better off than if you had played it safe by stashing it in a low percentage rate bank account.

This is a very dangerous way to play the safety net. Why? Because you are relying on credit to make all of your bills. You may not be able to use credit for this. Rent or mortgage may not be paid on a CC, or some other needs. It also likely generates interest on the debt, usually at a high rate. And the effects can manifest in other deleterious ways such as FICO fluctuations. The cashHYSACD or iBond Ladder is easily accessible and will NOT generate interest losses. Cash is king, particularly in an emergency. It is uncoupled from markets for stocks or bonds so is impervious to panic crashes and requires no collateral. Someones ability to pay their basic bills or make minimum payments on debts can be stretched. Using leverage of debt products or assets is not an emergency fund. I will say, in an emergency, paying for the vet bill or car repair or whatever lesser emergency that crops up with a CC is certainly wise, if that CC bill can be paid in full from the emergency fund on time for the statement due date.
That is not an emergency fund. That is a recipe for disaster ending in bankruptcy. Just because you got lucky and it worked for you doesnt make it not stupid.

Rather than selling while everyone else is selling, you can use your cash to invest at extreme discounts.

However, you can use your credit cards as a buffer while you sell off stock, and then pay them off afterwards. Heres a thread on bogleheads talking about this exact topic.

replies.text: Ill agree with the comment above that 3 years is too short to be exposed to market risks, unless youre willing to either delay your plans or take a loss. For longer term, yes, global diversification can be a good thing to have. It can both help increase returns and reduce volatility compared to a US only portfolio. Ive collected over a dozen links that can all show in their own ways the benefits of holding VXUS or similar here I always forget which subreddits allow which links other than Bogleheads and Personal Finance, so Ill link you to a recent post in one of those subreddits where I had everything

I know some people will say aha but if the stock market goes down by 70 in 3 years youll be really embarrassed! But, if the stock market crashes by 50 over the next three years your housing plans are fucked anyway and your investment strategy will probably involve how to best eat your belt.
Its not worth being in the market on such a short timeframe. Youre only able to handwave 12 of a down payment on a house when its theoretical. Once its real, youll feel differently.

OP your plan seems fine to me and is similar to what Im doing. Do you have a specific need for it to be exactly 3 years? If not, then if the market has a dip, you can wait an extra year or 2 and ride it out. Thats why Im investing 100 of my potential house down payment into the stock market, with my time horizon being 510 years. Im giving myself time to ride it out if anything happens so I dont have to sell the bottom.

Whatever exposure you have to equities limits both the down side as well as the up side, so the other side of that is a 50 gain in 3 years, which is only slightly optomistic compared to average, only gets you 12.5 more money. The thing about short time lines is that the market tends to go up gradually and down quickly. Its not just whether your total gain over the next 3 years will be worthwhile, but whether youll be in the middle of negotiating a sale and lose 20over the course of a week and then you have to reapply for the loan with a smaller down payment and in the mean time somebody else buys the house. Having significantly more than you need for a down payment does give you a buffer for taking a bit more risk with the money because you can afford not to use any of the money invested in equities if necessary. It probably doesnt actually make sense to aim for such a large down payment anyway. The amount of the monthly payment doesnt really matter, its the interest rate on the loan that determines how much the debt will ultimately cost. Unless you get a significantly lower rate with a 50 down payment vs 20 its not worth waiting. Youre exchanging having less free cash now for more later instead of reducing the total cost.

you typically will lock in a lower interest rate with a larger down payment. Are you sure about that? If youre going to make more than minimum monthly payments anyway youre just moving around when you pay some amount. A larger down payment means financing less and less total intrest IF you only do minimum payments. It also means waiting longer and continuing to pay rent while also saving for the down payment. If you pay a fixed amount towards housing every month and ignore minimum payments on the loan look at total cost by the time you pay off the mortgage comparing buying a house now with 20 down vs waiting 3 years and putting 50 down if you also youth what you pay for rent for the next 3 years towards the debt. Intrest on the debt is comperable to gains from investments, so if your intrest rate is similar to the rate you expect from investing the money youre saving its a wash.

If you are worried about a market downturn and ready to make drastic moves to protect your money based on a fear of a crash this means one simple thing. You are invested way above risk tolerance that leads to rather poor decisionmaking My advise is create a portfolio you are comfortable with , this usually means allocating to some portion of bonds. And yes this will drag performance down in bull markets but hopefully you wont be tempted to do something very dumb like allocate 25 of your fund to a short fund. Also holding a long and short fund at the same time makes zero sense , in your 2 you would be net short on the market by 25 . If you really wanted to do this it would make more sense to just be 92 money market and 8 SQQQ Basically my advise is to create a portfolio something like 75 equities 25 bonds or what ever you are comfortable with and dont make drastic changes, slowly balance more to bonds as you age or approach retirement However going from 100 equities to basically 75 cash and 25 short is a drastic change that will most likely backfire.

So, time in the market is the way to win.

SQQQ is a triple leveraged fund that tracks the DAILY performance of the Nasdaq. So if you have back to back days of positive returns in the Nasdaq, youre screwed. If I were to be honest I would say that trying to follow other investors has cost me more money than it has made me. If you make an investment you have to know why, so that when the situation changes, you know if you should hold or sell. Famous investors usually dont tell you the whole story, and often have different incentives. Take Buffetts investment in Coke for example. He first made this in the 1980s and kept his buying secret until he amassed a huge position. It went up nearly 10x in the subsequent years and was one of his most successful investments and he said all kinds of great things about it like it being the strongest franchise in the world. And he is famous for holding stocks forever and holds it to this day. However if you invested in Coke a few years after he did, you would have underperformed the market for 20 years. Buffett had already made his money, and the increasing dividends paid by Coke helps his insurance companies in specific ways that do not apply to average investors.

Last fall I was trading 0dte iron condors and busted my account so badly that I was at a balance of like 9000. I felt like such an idiot, it messed me up to the point that I barely ate or slept for almost a week. It seemed like a lot of money then, but it taught me an important lesson about the options pin risk, and the responsible use of margin. I took a long break from day trading and built up positions in VOO, VUG, and VTV. Which made monster gains. Since then, I have persevered with my options trading, taking a much safer approach with a better brokerage. My brother whos a finance professional helped me put that loss into perspective, saying that even professionals get absolutely rinsed on spreads sometimes. I still sell options, but I take a much safer approach now and I always close my spreads rather than taking them to expiry
Stay away from penny stocks and buying options and its almost impossible to blow your account, especially in a bull market.

during Covid, there was a program where life coaches offered free sessions. I talked once a week to someone about going back to school, the impending birth of my first child, and what I imagined an ideal scene from life would look like. so rather than therapy, I would recommend coaching. I was able to return to school, got a job, finished a degree remotely, and got a great job. I took 2 years away from the market and studied accounting and finance in school. The first year I couldnt look at a stock chart without feeling nauseous. The second year I began to apply what I was learning in school and paper traded for a full year. I started up my trading again when I got a full time remote job. Being able to apply what I learned from accounting, combined with new techniques and a greater respect for managing risk, I have been crushing it the last 2 years. Have finally made back what I lost, and in hindsight, I will come out more successful in the end from having learned what I did during that difficult period. They will come out ahead! The best advice I can give is that it will take some time to come to integrate that in order to get back to where they were, they will have to work harder than they ever have before. After a few years patience will be key, they can come out ahead and apply everything learned going forward. It will be a time of very hard work.

Blown not only once.. What I needed time to actually get better at it.. to actually understand the markets macro economics.. And no.. you dont need someone to tell you to stop! You may need someone to guide you, but not to stop.. Trading is a beauty, its a biz, its a life.. once you get the heck of it, its freedom really Dont tell anyone to stop, tell them to get back up, get the shit right and make it happen now Gl!

This is the only answer. And if your edge is simply but Im really smart, and Ive done well before, then you have no edge. I was lucky enough to have a true edge for a short time, and I made out quite well. When the edge was lost, I took a few unjustifiable losses. I developed an expectation that I would typically be right, and I overrode my risk management multiple times. The only correct response was to stop trading. I bought a home and rehabbed it, doing manual labor for six months, then went into public service. I helped others by the hundreds instead of helping myself. It was exactly what I needed. It took a while to stop fiending for the market, which was further indication that I was right to stop. I had become a gambler, and I was in recovery. A few later, I traded for a few months. I made quick money, but became obsessive and shortchanged my family and the people I served. I took my gains and exited for good. Quarterly rebalancing of retirement accounts is all Im qualified to do. Lazy, longterm investing is my lot in life, luckily. Im sure this reads like the story of an addict who got sober, relapsed, then recommitted. Thats essentially what it is.

Having a long position in a security means that you own the security. Investors maintain long security positions in the expectation that the stock will rise in value in the future. The opposite of a long position is a short position. A short position is generally the sale of a stock you do not own. Investors who sell short believe the price of the stock will decrease in value. These are pretty basic definitions. Calls are long positions while puts are short

nomeat products are able to emulate the taste of meat. So no moat around a meat products any more. Have you ever had a family member bring home a pack of impossible meat and make some shitty hamburgers or something with it? Or maybe youve just seen a youtube video or tiktok clip of someone eating the vegan meat? Almost every single time ive seen someone consume this novelty food the exact words that come out of their mouth are almost always Well, its okayfine, but i can still totally tell its fake meat with a happy they tried it, never will again look on their face. Call that not having a moat.
One thing Ill throw out is not necessarily vegan but allergy free food. Been seeing this increase last decade or so, many conditions now need alternatives for food

It would go in the category of thematic ETF. Meaning there is no real existing category for it yet. Cannabis stocks are like that. I dont think investor are willing to bet their retirement on it.

replies.text: Fractional shares arent a new concept. Its been around for at least 2 decades. Theres really nothing shady about the idea. Its not really particular useful investing tool imo there are better ways to invest small sums of capital. ... hearing about DRSing your physical shares ... There is no such thing as physical shares thats just misinformation from conspiracy theorists and people that dont understand how the stock market works. DRS is not a useful investing mechanism.
Leave the cult. Dont worry about lending of shares or shorting. Who gives a shit. Invest to maximize your own wealth. Its not hard to do
Why are fractionals shady?

I see that you added a few new questions so lets go through those If a share can be lent out multiple times doesnt that mean the value is inflated? Not necessarily. It will place some downward pressure on a stock. In a public market, the stock price will also adjust to what is perceived as fair value. There is an old maxim that in the short run, the market is a voting machine which discusses the value of the stock based on the thencurrent markets future expectation of the value of a company. The quote come from Benjamin Graham and one of his books is suggested in the wiki. If I have a fraction of a share do I actually have a claim to the share? Yes its a contractual claim between yourself and the broker. That is because the broker offers fractional shares services for equities. However that said if a longterm investor cannot afford the funds for whole shares its usually simpler to use mutual funds which transact in dollar and penny increments so that fractional shares are irrelevant and contributions to the fund can be done anytime regardless of share price. What are you really paying for if a broker can resell the same security multiple times? A broker cannot resell multiple times. Thats not how share lending works. In a security lending program a broker is legally required to put up cash collateral everytime the share is borrowed. Lets take for example the GME that you mentioned. The stock is currently considered HTB or hard to borrow at many brokers. So if I shorted 1 share of GME for 21. I will receive 21 in proceeds from my broker. But because its HTB there is a daily borrow fee that is accrued that I have to pay to the broker. The 21 in proceeds is goes into margin credit balance. And if the price of GME goes to 22, I now also have a margin fee of 1. The share that I borrow would have come from the brokers security lending desk. And some brokers will split the lending fee with the customer lent the share. The counterparty to my short sale who bought the 1 share can then lend the share again and the process repeats itself. Security lending is just one small component of the revenue stream that a broker can receive. What do you mean by what are you really paying for running a brokerage business means having employees, technology, etc. etc. As a brokerage customer you are paying the broker for custody services, bookeeping, customer services, access to the capital markets, etc. etc. In the US the services that a retail investor receives from a broker are incredibly high relative to the fees. Brokers in the US are very competitive and the access to the capital markers for investors are easier and more affordable than in previous decades. For example when I first started trading and investing the average transaction cost was 49 per trade today there is 0 commissions and exchange fees are literally pennies per transaction. Also data was not free getting realtime data meant paying a monthly fee. Also odd lot trading meant an extra commission brokerage systems in the past mostly support whole lots a lot is 100 shares. If someone wanted to buy only 10 whole shares a different exchange mechanism was required and that usually meant an extra commission. Also because the cost for a broker to support accounts was higher brokers used to have account minimums usually 2k iirc.
Interesting, so there is no way to validate that your ownership in a stock is not loaned out?

Well I guess I wanted to see if I could understand it more. Intuitively, you could say in the event shares are being sold in excess of the outstanding shares for a specific company then that companys valuation might be inflated.

What do you mean? And why would you care? Rehypothecation is a common practice and its how retail investors are able to get low cost brokerage services. If you dont want your holdings to be rehypothecated dont open a margin account and just use a cash account.
No thats not how fractionals work. Fractionals dont trade. Its a brokerage service.

Well I plan on investing in the near future and Im just worried that if I buy stocks or invest in a retirement account that the underlying investments are being devalued. Unless Im wrong in my understanding and thats why Im asking. So if a company has 1,000,000 shares and the books of a broker represents that 10,000,000 accounts hold those shares then the problem arises that the valuation may be off and the price I paid for a share is largely inflated correct? Or do I have a fundamental misunderstanding of whats going on?

Retirement accounts are cashonly by default. Its not clear what your concern is about. ... underlying investments are being devalued The use of fractional shares doesnt impact the value of a stock price. So if a company has 1,000,000 shares and the books of a broker represents that 10,000,000 accounts hold those shares then the problem arises that the valuation may be off and the price I paid for a share is largely inflated correct? No because the broker can only hold whole shares. The fractionals are aggregated together and bookeeping is done by the broker. I.e. if 2 accounts hold 0.5 shares that equals 1 share and the broker has 1 share. do I have a fundamental misunderstanding of whats going on? Yes you are misunderstanding.
correct, youre making shit up. you have a fundamental misunderstanding.
Okay so if I only do a cash based account I wont have to worry about not having a claim to my ownership? What happens if the bank goes under? Will my account just go to 0?

ok let take a step back. I assume you are in the US based on your questions. In the US brokerage accounts are not at a bank. Banks and brokers are different type of financial institutions. Banks are a type of depository and work very differently than brokerages. If you are asking about a retirement account it is always cash based. By law brokers are not permitted to extend credit to a retirement account I.e no regt margin. A brokerage account retirement or otherwise is never on the books of a broker. So if a broker becomes insolvent the account simply transfers to another broker. That is one of the roles of the SIPC they will ensure that the brokerage accounts ar protected. All the assets in the accounts continue to belong to the account holder. Brokerage insolvency are exceeding rare. And account holders losing money from a brokerage insolvency I am only aware of one or two which are futures brokers where there was widespread fraud. Even when FTX failed from huge crypto fraud account holders in the stock brokerage portion of FTX did not lose value in their accounts. Brokerage accounts are incredibly well regulated. Even if securities in an account is lent out which I believe is your concern by law the lent securities must be pledged in cash so a broker going bankrupt would not cause account holders to lose money. There would need to be a catastrophic failure in the checks and balances of a brokerage for account holders to be adversely impacted. fwiw Where are you getting your information? There is so much wrong about how you think investing and brokerages work.

Thank you! I was nervous about investing in a Roth IRA because I didnt want to lose the money and my mind was conflating the reserve banking and lending out shares as the same thing. EDIT as a kid I heard of people losing retirement accounts to financial markets in 08 and I am trying to educate myself about finances now and this whole world of investing is a little new. I saw the GME thing when it happened but at the time I wasnt investing in anything and I think Ive picked up some poor beliefs along the way.

The reason why people lost value in their retirement accounts was because people were over invested in the capital markets. Or that they had concentration risk that can happen. It wasnt because the brokerages became insolvent. It was because the investors invested poorly and took more risk than they probably should have. For example some people may have overly concentrated their retirement into one company stock or only in equities. During the 2008 GFC equities lost a lot of value. Re GME if you are getting your financial and investing information related to GME that is the absolutely wrong place to learn about the stock market. The vast majority of the GME related information is wrong and based on conspiracy nonsense. If you want to actually learn see the recommended material in the wikie Books Podcasts and videos

Ignore the GME thing. Its all conspiracy nonsense. Nobody lost their retirement accounts in 08. Retirement accounts lost a lot of value in that market crash, just like all investments did. But the market recovered within 5 years. Anyone who simply held on and didnt sell in 08 did fine.
