replies.text: If you want safe money, the best option probably is either short term Treasuries or short term TIPs. Look into SHY, VGSH and VTIP. Defensive stock are still stocks, so theyre still risky and theyre still highly correlated with the stock market. My point is, theyre safe relative to VOO, but theyre not the safest thing in the world.

If you are fearful of a rate increase or a stagflation scenario, you might consider putting that money into something like SGOV. If your forecast is wrong, you can easily sell your shares and shift the money to another investment. With VDC, youre still getting equity risk, so prepare for the possibility of a significant drawdown in the event of a recession.

If the goal is to reduce volatility of your overall portfolio investing in a single equity isnt the best idea since the value of that equity is going to be correlated with the wider stock market. Assuming this is for a longer timeframe youre better off going with a cash allocation or similar bond fund but it really depends on your time horizon, goals, and risk tolerances for the overall portfolio

Defensive stocks would probably yield better returns in the short term because of these cuts while still retaining a low degree of risk. High inflation is also going to continue which historically has benefited stocks more than bonds. A good idea might be to split your low risk portion of your portfolio between defensive stocks and bonds but a higher proportion in stocks. For example maybe a 70 split in stocks and 30 in bonds might be a good idea.

I dont understand the idea of individual investors investing government bonds, mutual bonds, and any and all corporate bonds. The basic idea of bonds investing is your long term bet on a government, a municipal, or a corporate. Why do you bet on a government if you are a tiny potato?and a corporate? r u trying to gain the voting rights? if not, why bonds? collecting the yield to hedge volatility? option can do that better. NO, Absoltely no.

The basic idea behind bonds investing is that they theoretically offer returns uncorrelated with stock and exhibit lower volatility. The basic idea isnt to maximize returns but to lower the overall volatility of the portfolio and the consequences of a large drop in the value of equities. Alternatively fixed income products such as bonds or annuities can be used to ensure income for people who cannot manage their own portfolios for whatever reason or as insurance against short term market fluctuations.

As I said, there R 2 major reasons to invest in bonds, to gain a say, or to gain stability. However, if your portfolio is small en, you dont and cant have a say to anything As for stability, most advanced investors chose collar options to achieve that and its shorter duration and less costly due to inflation not a factor. Again, absolutely no unless you are an elephant and can negotiate bond terms, and thats called origination in private equity. It absolutely makes no sense to invest in bonds as small investors Oh, one more, bidens wife has tons of TIPs, voz shes rich enough as a rich heir to NOT worry about money. if you are in the same shoes, go do it

I think bonds have a lot going for them as volatility hedges. Theyre a very cheap asset class to invest in and they are relatively simple compared to other alternatives. Theoretically you could use other vehicles for that but what are the alternatives that are simple, cheap, and easily accessible to a retail investor?

First, bonds dont give you voting rights. I dont know where do you get than from. Second, options definitely are not less costly. If youre selling them, youre just either taking unlimited risk naked options or limiting your upside without eliminating the downside risk covered options. If youre buying them, youre paying a premium, which has negative expected returns.

Makes no sense to me over a treasury fund atm. Simple and cheap. There are tons of good short term options. Some also may just use a gold ETF for hedge as well and added diversification. Nowadays you just have a ton more options that are pretty accessible and even return more than most actually reliable bonds. I tend to go with much higher return options than bonds. They just havent been worth it imo over other options and until rates actually drop low enough I personally maintain that opinion.
bonds arent cheap. the lack of growth made it very costly for investors. ive told you Do not invest bonds. feel like to do so if you refuse to listen

some bonds can be issued with bond holder priority and decision making rights. you definitely dont have finance experience and you dont even understand what I am talking about. feel free to invest in bonds. period. this certainly again proved my idea using redditors down and upvotes as a reverse index.

A bond can be cheap or expensive but theres nothing about bonds that arent cheap. Bonds are not about growth, nor do they act as growth assets in a portfolio. Thats not their purpose. There are all sorts of reasons to invest in bonds, depending on the need.

True, every one has a definition of cheap or expensive. Bonds coupon , yield and face will be the only way to tell if its worth the risk. I just dont think any individual investor has the way to figure out the risk reward premium of bonds. replies.text: At the end of the day, you have to decide. If everyone boggles and the economy collapses, everyone goes down 40 on small cap is a big tilt, but thats your risk to tolerate. Whats wrong with VTI and VXUS? The classic? IMO you can consistently make what you think are good plays with smaller bouts of your portfolio, invest in the whole market, capture other assets, make a small business, buy crypto, buy gold, trade currency etc. Just remember, you are not one of the largest companies in the world doing this and they count on you doing the math correctly just like them. Reading and investing can be a full time job, or not, you really have to decide what you want to do. Risk is somewhat calculable, but nobody should tell you they have a crystal ball. Why do you like the funds you listed? Lets start there perhaps?

Thanks for those points. The reason Im looking at AVUVAVGVCGGO are because they are actively managed, global funds that should have lowish correlation. I started investing about 3 years ago learning about the passive indexing that you reference, which I think is why the market seems so overpriced. I guess Boggling with actively managed funds feels less risky. Also, I dont really see the risk in splitting equally between growth value. I used to hold total market indexes and then do SCV tilts, which actually seems more risky to me, because I was betting that SCV would outperform. Since I realistically dont know what will outperform market can remain irrational longer than we can remain solvent kind of thing I makes sense in my weird mind to hold LCG SCV in equal proportions and rebalance with contributions. One could even use VT to keep exposure to other areas of the market in a portfolio like VT 20 CGGO 40 AVUV 20 AVDV 10 AVES 10 CGGO has a high expense ratio, but its a true growth fund and still has a PE ratio below 30. A fund like VOO seems to really be a large cap blend fund. A true growth index like VUG has a PE ratio in the 40s and its just hard to buy that. Although now Im seeing that according to stock analysis, SCHG has a PE ratio of 12, which sounds like a mistake... I agree that you can consistently make good plays with a small portion of your portfolio, but it also seems that combining strategies can be like shooting yourself in the foot at times. From what I gather, the way you accumulate wealth in a portfolio like I have illustrated above is by rebalancing your set percentages. Maybe the answer is to use different accounts for different strategiesgoals? For instance, another accumulation portfolio might be highly leveraged with things like 3x SP 500, 3x long treasuries and managed futures contracts. Even just maintaining a set allocation, the fluctuations in the marketinterest rate cycles will always tell you what you need to buy. Nothing is wrong with VTIVXUS, its just that Im open to a little more volatility and perhaps higher returns by favoring a portfolio of essentially polar opposites, if that makes sense. Id be interested to hear your thoughts. Thanks!

I dont like a high expense ratio, pretty much ever. I think at the end of the day if you want to tilt like this you gotta be ready and have a plan for if it goes sideways, or even up! I get where youre at, Im there with you. NonUS and small cap look to have more value at this point to me but we both really have to admit, we dont really know. Shooting yourself in the foot while the market tumbles can be good. Im all about diversification but I dont know your goals, etc. Worst that can happen is you take a healthy slice of pie, write an investment policy statement for it, know it may go up or down, and stick to your plan. I dont really want to comment on all the funds as I am not particularly familiar with one or two you listed but I hold a small tilt toward AVUV, I just hear of a tilt as 510. I dont know your net worth or goals, only you can do that math.

Actually, I take the bond comment back if you simply want to get used to seeing them in a portfolio and how they interact with equities. Might make it easier to increase as time goes by too. Regarding international equities, they are roughly 40 of market cap so the better question to ask yourself is why exclude them? They offer diversification, the only free lunch in investing, and there are plenty of products you probably own that arent made in the USA. Why limit your exposure, and possibly risk, to one single country over a 60 year investment horizon? Material I would also personally combine your large cap growth with total stock market since they have a pretty similar exposure. Rapid growth is an interesting term to use since theres no way to guarantee rapid growth from one sector to happen. I would think more about dividend investing in a taxable brokerage too theres a good chance youd be paying more in taxes than something that wasnt spitting out as many dividends. Lastly, small cap would be a good hedge against large cap stocks as well and might improve overall returns if you have the conviction to stick with it and it makes up more than 15 or 20 of your US equities since anything less wont move the needle too much. I would make sure it either tracks the SP SmallCap 600 Value Index, or is an actively managed but well constructed fund such as the AVUV ETF from Avantis.

This is an entirely personal question which only you and your wife can answer. Whether its weird or not is entirely dependent on your own family relationships and dynamics. If you want advice from someone about your portfolio allocation you can either get it from 1 someone you trust, 2 from a stranger on reddit, 3 a financial adviser. Each of these 3 options have pros and cons. If you trust your fil thats great. But are you sure that they actually know much about portfolio construction. Being wealthy and successful in business doesnt translate to actual practical knowledge about investing. In some cases, they may have a narrow viewpoint about investing or not. Getting advice from reddit is hit or miss it depends on who is answering and responding and their level of knowledge and experience. Getting advice from a financial advisor also requires trust. While an investment adviser and financial advisor may educated and provides investment management services for a living you have to trust that firm or individual that they understand your financial goals and situation. And just because an IA has a fiduciary duty doesnt mean that they know what they are doing. There are some really sketchy and bad investment advisers out there.

replies.text: Long term investments in ETFs like you mentioned are the safest way to ensure solid returns actually bonds would be the safest but the returns are not so solid. Are they the best returns? No, but theyre solid. Youd make more money investing into the companies that do the best over the coming years, but its very difficult to determine which companies those will be and therefore riskier. No you generally wont want to cash out your entire retirement funds the day you retire. Youll ideally have enough money to live off of for several years, so youll only take out what you need for a year each year. But you will, as you get older, transition more and more of your money towards bonds and other safer investments than ETFs like the SP.

1. Yes 2. You never cash out. When you retire you can live off the return every year. 3. For short term goals you probably dont want to invest money. If you were saving in a taxable account in order to retire early you may start spending that money before 59.5.

Everyones goals are unique to their situation. You can act accordingly based upon the position you set yourself up for. The tools that you use to determine where you are and where youll be help. I use the free one on InvestingTE. Maybe something similar will help you get your bearings.

If you have funds that fluctuate the law of compound return will not help you. But a low risk bond fund issued by US Treasury the law of compound interest works to its best. Not have to pay interest tax until redemption with no consequence on state income tax. The only reason suggesting invest in a stock index long term is in the event of a market correction there is enough time to recover during growth cycle. It also assumes past recession frequency and returns data are similar. It is also tied to life style, expense, health condition.

Youre kind of looking at it backwards, throwing money at investments and wondering when you can use the money instead of saving for specific goals and investing appropriately based on the timeline of those goals. Equities being long term investments is based on the value increasing on average if youre invested broadly enough, but volatility means it wont necessarily be worthwhile in the short term. If youre saving for shorter term goals, including approaching retirement, you want to shift the money into investments that you know will be worthwhile in that time frame. Stuff with little to no volatility like treasuries and bonds. Everyone contributes a bit at a time toward savings for future goals if they have any savings at all, its like a bill for a cost you havent had to pay yet. Most people will have multiple goals with different time frames, so theyll have a mix of different types of assets. Freeing up money when its time might look like cashing out because youre reducing your total so youll most likely be selling volatile assets to bring your allocation back in line. I think a better way to look at it is that your fixed income assets are like a buffer. Years before retirement you sold some stock and that locked in the gains youd had so far. You put it in bonds which have lower growth but cant lose value like stocks. When you retire you sell bonds to pay expenses,, but the you need to sell more stock as well to refill the buffer.
I see, I appreciate the reply!

Im actually not totally sure what living off your investments or living off the returns every year means. Is it just cashing out a bit if profits every year? Could you shed some lights on this for me?

If you have 1 million dollars invested in SP, the SP averages 10 returns over time. You will average 100,000 in returns every year, enough for most people to live on, without your total investment ever dropping below 1 million

You can eventually reach a point where you have enough money invested that you take out only as much or less as your accounts increase each year. You are then living off of the returns that is, the money that your investments grow by each year. Its quite possible to reach a point where your net worth continues to increase after you retire as long as you spend less than your investments return each year. Keep in mind that you always have to contend with inflation, so as the years go on youll probably need to take out increasing amounts each year.

Here is how I would do it In your preretirement years, build up as big a nest egg as you can. Upon retirement, switch to an incomefocused portfolio and live off the dividendsdistributions. Dont chip away at your nest egg by selling shares because you could eventually deplete your assets and you thus risk outliving your assets, which is a bad thing. IMO investing for growth and investing for income are mutually exclusive. A lot of people like JEPI and JEPQ for income and I like GOF. For growth, if you can tolerate the volatility there are QLD and SSO. Remember that volatility cuts both ways upside and downside, and that the overall trend of the stock market over the decades is UP!

replies.text: The answer is, hypothetically, when the increment falls below the risk free rate of return So when the annual increase is lower than about 34

You need to consider the time value of money. This involves accounting for factors like inflation and the opportunity cost of not having the money available to invest immediately. The present value of receiving N in N days is calculated using the formula PVN N er N 365 N is the number of days you choose to wait. r is the annual discount rate. er N 365 is the discount factor accounting for the time value of money over N days. To find the optimal N that maximizes PVN, we take the derivative of PVN with respect to N and set it to zero dPVdN er N 365 1 rN365 er N 365 1 rN365 0 Since er N 365 is always positive, the equation simplifies to 1 rN365 0 So N 365r Now, plug in your specific annual discount rate r to find the optimal N. Lets say we select a 5 discount rate, r 0.05 N 3650.05 7300 days 20 years hey, that was one of your examples! So, you should wait 20 years to receive 7,300 to maximize the present value at a 5 discount rate. Things to consider A higher discount rate leads to a smaller optimal N. Money today is more valuable due to higher opportunity cost. A lower discount rate results in a larger optimal N. Youre willing to wait longer because the opportunity cost is lower. Your personal discount rate reflects your individual opportunity cost, inflation expectations, and personal financial situation.
Breakpoint when discount rate times 365 t 365 So t 1 r If r 10, t 10 years.

Ok, anyone who said youd never need to know the quadratic formula, heres the proof that youre wrong. It will be time to quit when the daily interest is greater than the dollar youre being given. To determine whne this will be, we need a daily interest rate and a way to calculate how much money youll have at a given time. Im going to assume that whoever is giving you the money is trustworthy, so our interest rate will be the annual riskfree rate divided by 365. Im assuming the annual rate is 5, so r .05365 Our money is accumulating at the rate of 1day, so the total will be the sum from 1 to the number of days until were done. This sum, S, is given by S nn12 where n is the number of days. Our breakeven point is therefore given by Sr 1 nn12.05365 1 n22 n2 7300 n2 n 14600 0 Now we get to use the quadratic formula to find the positive root, 1 1 414600.52 120 days At that point well have 1201212 7,300. Our daily interest rate is .05265 0.0137, which multiplied by our stake of 7,300 gives is 1. After one more day our interest will be more than our daily gift and we can say goodbye to our benefactor edit at day 121 our interest will be MORE than 1

Ok, basically you have to calculate what is the return of the 1 per day in regard to the money already generated. If the is higher than 8 per year, you should continue to take the 1 per day. If its under 8, you should stop, cash in and put all the previously generated money in a SP ETF and generate the average 8 per year from it. 365 reaches the 8 of the capital when you have 4500. It just seemed like there should be something between the HYSA bond market and the double digit swings of market or sector type funds Thats the beauty of asset allocations it doesnt have to be all or nothing. You dont have to be all shortterm cashHYSAmoney market funds, bonds CDs Treasurys etc., or equities stocks. Traditionally, something like 20 equity80 bonds is considered conservative in its investment objective. So, hypothetically, if you had 20k in a savings and would like some potential upside for a portion of it, you can allocate 4k into a wide market index like VOOVTIVT Id pick one and leave the other 16k in your HYSA or money market fund. Of course, youd have to rebalance it, say one a month might be enough, so it stays within the target asset mix and you dont overexpose on one end or the other too much. Of course, theres plenty of mutual funds and ETFs that will do all of this for you at the cost of a bit of higher expense ratio. And if 2080 is too aggressive, then adjust as needed.

One thing Ive done is look up higher yield bonds on the secondary market that pay a coupon and are maturing soon. For example, I bought a 10year bond that paid a 6 coupon but the 10year was maturing like 4 months from when I bought it. That way I was getting a higher APR running somewhat less of a risk than locking up my money for 10years on a shaky bond. Its a more handson approach because you then need to roll that investment into something new, but thats actually what youre looking for in terms of liquidity.

Your own personal risk tolerance should be considered. However, as a rule of thumb, theres no real benefit to paying off any debt early when the rate is below 44.5, especially a mortgage. One of the most important things I learned back in college when I took personal finance is that low is basically free money. The tax adjusted expected return from most investments would be higher than the rate you are paying. As long as you have emergency savings and a stable income, I would invest the extra into a fund like VTVTI.

Seems like you have a big enough fund that you could potentially do a rolling CD plan. Invest X every X months on a rolling basis. So if you take 12 of your fund and invest 1 every month into a CD, you can slightly higher rates than a HYSA. After a while, depending on the length of the CD, you will always have that 1 maturing monthly to maintain some liquidity. The drawback being if you have a bad emergency, you will have to wait for the next chunk to mature before you can use the funds, but if you do 6 month CDs, its not terrible, but it is essentially risk free since theyre FDIC insured and all. I do it with 6 months, so at least if I have an emergency that depletes my emergency fund, I can just use credit to pay for it temporarily until the CD matures to pay it off. With enough time, you could set it up for yearly, every 5 years, whatever, so that you always have some chunk maturing monthly.

As a 14yearold investor, youre already off to a great start! Its awesome that youre thinking about investing strategies at your age. Here are some thoughts on your options 1. VOO VXUS This is a solid, diversified foundation. VOO gives you broad US market exposure, while VXUS adds international diversification. For many investors, this combo is enough. 2. Adding VGT While it would increase your tech exposure, its worth noting that VOO is already techheavy. Adding VGT might lead to overconcentration in one sector. 3. Individual stocks LMT, RTX At your current investment level, individual stocks might introduce unnecessary risk. Theyre less diversified than index funds. Regarding diversification vs. consolidation With smaller amounts, keeping it simple with 12 broad funds like your VOOVXUS combo is often recommended. Its easier to manage and still gives you good diversification. As your portfolio grows, you can consider adding more specific sectors or individual stocks if you want. My advice At this stage, stick with VOO and VXUS. Focus on consistently adding to these positions over time. This approach gives you a diversified base to build upon as you learn more and your portfolio grows. Remember, the most important things right now are 1. Developing good savinginvesting habits 2. Learning about investing 3. Giving your investments time to grow One last point to consider Given your young age, you might want to lean more towards growth investing rather than dividendfocused strategies. Growth stocks have the potential for higher returns over the long term, which could be beneficial given your long investment horizon. Your current VOO VXUS combination actually aligns well with this growthoriented approach. For more information, you could look into a subreddit like rgrowth_investing.
Just keep putting money in VOO. Aint nobody beating 20.57 YTD!! I wished I did. Even XLK is only 17YTD

Absolutely diversify. You can blow accounts for years, you have no actual risk right now. Buy a company for reasons, learn more about it, maybe sell and get something different. If you want to stick with etfs, at least take a look at bonds so you know what a riskfree investment is, learn a bit about reits... after you have 2k you can learn option hedging on a cheap stock or etf. There is so much you can do, congrats for starting early

Good work ! I started my son into investing with 25 in ninth grade several years ago, and when he was a freshman in college with a 5000 portfolio. Its grown 38 and he has kept adding to through work savings The best strategy is to continue to dollar cost average into VOO and VXUS. Which means buy smaller chunks each month for the next forseeable future and the laddering strategy will pay off over time. You could contribute a smaller amount to VGT but tech, albeit a secular growth sector with great runway, is over valued valuation wise because its so popular and overbought and if it drops you will see volatility in your values. Investing in individual stocks is useful if you have some intrinsic knowledge about the business, the company is in , or rhe stocks value ie its super undervalued. Otherwise its a gamble on potential growth. I dont reccomend it for young investors at all. Once you study and learn financial valuation of businesses aka stocks in the future, you can try your hand at stock picking. And then the old adage of buy low is the true wealth generator. Keep it up!

Well done as others shared! Voo is awesome and can be a core position such as 90 percent of the total due to being so diversified and a great long term hold. You could also add the others to diversify further but not super necessary but could have 50 voo 30 vxus and 10 vgt for example. I would 100 percent vote to add some individual stocks, and lmt and rtx are rock stars! At your age, spend some time learning about stocks, check out website investor relations pages, so lmt ir in google, and invest in what seems promising! You may have some loses as that happens with stocks, but more importantly you will learn amazing investment lessons. And investing in individual stocks can be one of the most rewarding and profitable ways to invest long term! And there is no better way to learn than to try, fail, try, succeed and keep trying! Good luck!

Good luck! Sounds like you shouldve asked this question before investing with them? What made their strategyconcept appeal to you? Because their website looks pretty bogus.

Theres a lot of private REIT offerings that often label themselves as some variation of a unique opportunity previously only available to rich people! But they generally wind up being worse than a REIT and also more complex to own, are illiquid entirely illiquid or limited opportunities to sell and some in the past have gated withdrawals for temporary periods. This seems like it framed itself differently but seems very gimmicky in terms of the kind of things you got and has the same core issues limited liquidity, etc. Never heard of the company mentioned but crowdfunding, EREITs which feel like what were previously nontraded REITs an asset class that lead to a lot of complaints over the years in a different wrapper, stuff like that I just really dont recommend. Edit The site is kind of underwhelming. It focuses on the message which is nice but who is running the operation and what is their background? I see some people listed but no biographybackground. It shows the number of properties it owns in Atlanta but no examples that I can see. Apparently this is some sort of RegA nontraded REIT theres just very little information from an investment standpoint on the website, which is focused entirely on the message really. Id have to really go through filings to try to have a better understanding of the investment yes the message is nice but what do these houses look like? who is running this and what kind of qualifications do they have? the CEO of this was apparently previously CEO of some sort of automotive company?, which imo shouldnt have to be done. What are the specifics of withdrawals, given limited liquidity? Is there the ability to gate withdrawals? It doesnt really say on the website. Looking at one of the filing offerings, theres a long list of risks including our manager and its affiliates have no prior experience managing a portfolio of assets to comply with REIT requirements and detailed conflicts of interest between the manager and the sponsor. Edit finally found it after looking through filings. They intend to limit the number of units to be able to be redeemed during any calendar year to 5 of the weighted average number of units outstanding during the prior year. The manager can gate withdrawals at any time, without notice, for any reason or no reason. Theres a lot of other specifics, but its like all the other nontraded REITs yes there is quarterly liquidity, but not if a lot of people try to redeem at once. Again, not really familiar with this beyond just starting to look through filings, but I just think that anything investmentwise needs to have more information than this does on its website. These kinds of offerings sell themselves very basically on their websites but imo theres a lot more to it I mean, just looking at one of the offering filings its nearly 100 pages and theres a lot of noteworthy thingsrisksconsiderations on these filings that should be under an FAQ section on the website itself, not something that people have to go through a filing to find when considering this sort of investment.
The ROOTS program is aimed at a poor demographic in the Atlanta area.

replies.text: Not a fan of the expression since it basically implies that every public firm with multiple product lines is like an ETF. But I get it and it makes sense. PG is good they just trade at a high valuation due to their predictability and sustainable growth. So when you buy them with those same expectations, you arent getting very far.

Funnily enough about 25 years ago I had a similar thought about Philip Morris before numerous splits into more focused entities like PMI, Altria, Kraft, etc.. The company made everything from cigs to chips to beer how could it fail? Well, it didnt fail but it also didnt grow enthusiastically compared to say Big Tech and by proxy a broader ETF that had tech exposure. Even when the economy tanks these more defensive consumable stocks in mature segments dont rocket up with the same enthusiasm as tech has in a relatively new segment. So you may limit downside volatility as people will continue to buy PG products no matter what but you miss out on the upside by putting all your money there. I inherited a small IRA with PG about five years ago, watched it for several years, and nuked it this year for standard broad ETFs and Im not looking back. I get the idea, though.
Look into the Tyco International scandal and you will understand why conglomerates diversification. Youre not wrong that PG often holds up countercyclically, just dont mistake it for an ETF.

Im not sure any stock is crisis proof. some hold up better than others, and consumer staples tend to be very slow but steady good longterm performers. but there are different types of crisis events that might cause different problems in various industries Dave Ramsey has talked about helping a woman who worked for PG and her entire portfolio was PG stock IIRC. then there was some problem at the company and the stock crashed by 50, when the overall market was down only like 10 that year also IIRC. I cant find the video right now, but he used it to illustrate the risks of getting too concentrated in single stocks.
Look at GE

It is my favorite stock I dont buy because it is too expensive But now that I have a child. They have the best diapers by far Best dish soap. Best detergent. Best tissues. Then Braun,Oral B, Evax, Olay... Id love to see them be FWD PE of 18 or 20
I think a better holding would be a real ETF which holds assets such as PG while having low MER. I was kinda hoping ppl on Reddit could suggest a few of those ETFs.

replies.text: Depends on how much risk you want to take. 5 years is not really short term. Have a look at some Vanguard funds that list what they invest in as well as suitable time horizon and risk potential for the investments all listed out You can use different funds then Vanguard to do that, the above just gives an idea of different bondstock allocations along with suitable duration and risk for each allocation.

510 years is not short term in my opinion. But it looks like your risk appetite is low for the 510 year time . Which is fine. I suggest you invest 50 in index fund such as VTI, 25 in CD or short term 1 year bond and 25 in Gold .

replies.text: What matters is total return. Aside from possible differences in tax treatment, dividends and capital gains are both components of total return.

You dont have to be 100 dividend or 100 growth. Lots of people try to pick a single strategy because it seems simple and easy for them, many others invest in growth because the math is better on paper. For some, they recognize that having a relatively steady stream of income feels better than having gains on paper theyd have to sell to realize. Lots of different risk appetites, goals, and education levela when it comes to investing, and theres a strategy for all of them. For example, some investors may chase growth in their taxadvantaged accounts, and qualified dividends in their taxable account, effectively getting exposure to both strategies while trying to be somewhat tax efficient. Investing isnt onesize fits all.. and what works for someone with a high risk tolerance and many years until retirement may not look the same to someone nearing retirement who needs a somewhat predictable income stream and fears loss of capital more than they want big wins.
SP500 index funds also pay dividends. In fact dividend reinvestment is a huge part of its growth year over year.

Many people are attracted to dividends because, it correlates pretty highly with value stocks, and historically, value has produced a better total return than growth. If you only want to look at the last 15 years, then absolutely, dividend investing has underperformed, so the performance chasers give up and move to growth, which causes further under performance. Just dont expect the growth party to go on forever, especially from the current valuations. Just ask circa 1999 Qualcomm.
Its for people who like money more than math.

Youre correct, dividends are just one form of returning value to the shareholders, its exactly the same as selling except you dont get to choose when it happens. Overweighting dividend paying companies to generate income while youre still contributing to the investment from your income is just moving money from one hand to the other, and using the dividends as income is just slowly spending your savings. It may be at a rate thats less than growth, but youre still extracting funds from the investment.

If you can make 300 an hour at work, concentrate on that. You cannot predict the market, so just put that money in something broad like VOO and do not worry that something else might give you a little better return.
Dividend investing only attracts people with a lower understanding of investing

The idea that there is 1 and only 1 correct path or the rich do it this way and the poor do it this way is all overthinking things and chasing ones tail. Specifically define your investment goal, research the available options, and choose those that meet your goal. Its as dead simple as that. FWIW, Im generating a projected 30K of div income on less than 100K and have a significant retirement portfolio in growth funds. Educate yourself.

Bingo...lol...dont tell anyone in the dividends Reddit that, exactly why I sold my entire Schd position at the beginning of the year, saw how much I was missing out in pure growth. If you dont have over 500k to invest purely in dividends for income...Im talking using this money to live off of...its not worth it for the long haul investor, especially if you are young. You got to pay taxes on it too, which is a pain. A lot of people go chase dividends are seeking a quick answer to a lack of income and honestly probably dont understand the math behind it and how much money they are missing out on in a 1020 window if they just invested in a SP ETF. Im 32 and dividends dont make sense to me unless Im retiring and want to create income to ACTUALLY use. I can always allocate later...

I have quite a bit of dividend income because I have a very large nest egg built up in VTI. I didnt do that trying to get a dividend income. I did that because of diversification and low expense ratios. Dividends were an end product and a small part in any diverse portfolio. Not because dividends are a pillar themselves, but they represent a portion of many decades old companies who are stable. And I think you need better sources or to stop making things up to read from. Where are people saying dividends are free money? No where an adult should be pulling information from.

Warren Buffet likes dividends. The thing is, these are not suited for the gamblers who populate the market. If you buy and sell constantly and look for the hourly gain or loss, dividends are not for you. If you hold and reinvest the dividends over a long period, you wont do too bad.

Not necessarily low income, but it does appeal to people who want a sure thing or sort of guarantee. It isnt always consistent though, and I dont like the tax drag. Dividend payers are great for compounding in tax efficient vehicles, like a Roth. In general it takes too much capital to be worth it outside of that. Just my opinion.

Prior to that it wasnt so and nondividend payers had much more downside in crashes. There are also legal issues like in trusts where spending income is OK but distributing capital is not. A dividend on reliable equities is a selfadjusting safe withdrawal rate that you dont need to argue about which may come into play with varying interests. Like one person gets paid from income but heirs will inherit. If it prevents someone from nervously selling in a crash then its served a purpose. Dividend investing is one component input of fundamental indexing.

Or do you want gamble that a stock will go up, but risk losing what youve invested.

The subject of dividend investing has been debated in this subreddit many times for years. I sometimes drop in to comment that there are some quirky reasons that people invest in divident stocks or ETFs Some trusts operate such that the beneficiary a person, persons or perhaps a charity are examples will receive the dividends from investments. Sometimes they receive the money monthly or yearly. One way of maximizing these payments is to place the chunk the corpus of money in dividendyielding stocks or ETFs. That is one reason some people like them. It is a selfgoverning way of keeping a beneficiary on a budget. The corpus is never touched by the beneficiary. This is one way of taking the guesswork out of the question How much should the beneficiary receive in 2025? They get the dividends, whatever they might be.

This is just a logical fallacy of people who dont get it. A dividend is just a forced sale. Want a bigger dividend from your investment in the SP500? Sell more of it. It is no different. People love the feeling of getting that dividend, but ignore the fact that on the exdiv date, the share price drops by the same amount of the divvy plus regular market moves. Otherwise hedgefunds would just buy before exdiv, hedge their position, and sell the next day, and print the free money. Doesnt work that way. Dividend stocks can expose you to factors like lowvol, value, or profitability which ARE good and can improve longterm returns this is why total return for dividend strats is often cited as higher than the market, but the dividends have nothing to do with it. By targeting dividends instead of those factors directly, investors end up with less diversification, and a higher tax bill. Great relevant piece here

Ive always looked at it like this. If a company has a vision for growth they wont pay dividends because they can use that money more effectively than you can. If a company has no plans for growth but is generating income then they will pay dividends so you can invest that money how you choose. If a company enacts a successful growth plan they are always going to outperform a company that is just treading water, but if the growth plan fails then the dividend stock will outperform. Simply said, its higher risk higher reward with growth oriented companies and more steady growth with dividends. Over time growth will typically win.

Some companies have no real potential for growth, so pretty much all of their profit goes out as dividends. ATT was that way for a long time with like a 5 dividend. Thats a really sizeable amount coming in. But, the obsession with dividends passive income is really silly in my view. The growth of the company is what makes my portfolio grow. The one advantage of dividend stocks is that it limits your capital gains over time if you are in the 0 bracket. Its like gain harvesting over a long period of time. But, that is also a downside for higher income earners. If you want a bridge account to get you from when you retire to when you can draw for 401k IRA, then you can control what your income is during early retirement. If you were a higher income earner, then youd be taxed on those dividends the whole time. If you were instead invested in pure growth companies, then you wouldnt pay any taxes on the growth, and when you retire and your income is 0, then you can cash out the gains with the first 120k married filing jointly of capital gains per year tax free. In my tax advantaged accounts, I dont care whether they are growth or dividend, as long as my portfolio value is growing like I expect.

When you say income, do you mean taking the money to pay bills or whatever? It never makes sense to take income from the investments while simultaneously contributing to those investments from your actual income from working. Dividends are capital gains, both are gains from investments, and both are taxed either at your income tax rate, or your ltcg rate. The only difference is in choosing when and how much gains you realize. Investing is a complex topic, so its important to be accurate with the terms you use. In asset allocation, fixed income means stuff like bonds, buying debt so you get the interest and theres little to no risk on the principal. The opposite of fixed income is often referred to as growth, but it just means equities. Thats completely unrelated to growth value, which refers to what a company does with excess revenue. Schd holds equities, so its growth as far as growth vs fixed income. On the value factor scale within equities, dividend paying companies tend to occupy the value side of the spectrum, but theyre still equities with all the risks that entails, and its not comperable fixed income investments. You want growthequities for money you can leave invested long enough to mitigate volatility risk, and fixed income when you are approaching needing to be able to spend the money youve saved. Shifting from growth to fixed income, selling equities to buy bonds, is locking in the gains youve already had ahead of your need to actually spent the money so you arent risking loss due to volatility right when you need it.

The only thing that necessarily compounds from DRIP is number of shares held. Ill take your scenario from the other exchange. You have a 100k position in company A, it pays 3 yield. Your mistake is thinking this means that you have 103k at the end of the year, but dividends come out of the share price, at the end of the year, you have 97k in shares and 3k in cash, for the same 100k total. So you DRIP that, and at the end of the year, youve bought 30 shares with that 3k, so now you have 1030 shares worth 100k. Year after, same thing, you now have 1060 shares worth 94.09. Those are still worth 100k, the only possible way that you end up with more than 100k is if the share price increases on its own, the dividend does nothing for compounding your actual wealth. Its simply acting as a very small stock split. People with large accounts who started from scratch have just seen positive total returns, thats where the compounding comes from. In a welldiversified portfolio, some of that total return is dividends, but a larger part is share appreciation.

There are two issues with this. Some investment strategies, like dividend investing, are more a form of psychological selftrickery than an actual way to avoid psychological mistakes. If dividends lead someone to hold a falling stock for longer than it is rational because its still paying out the dividends or I cant sell, my yield on cost is really high, theyre making bad financial decisions based on factors that do not matter. Similarly, people can get hung up on number of shares held as a false indicator of a growing position. The biggest one, of course, is that cash hitting your account means that youve made money, or that you increased your net worth. They would be tricking themselves into doing a generally good thing, holding shares instead of churning, but the tricking could itself produce bad results by creating excessive focus on something that doesnt matter. Second, I wonder how true it is that these strategies actually produce the behaviours that get touted as benefits. Do we know that dividend investors react less fearfully to market downturns? What about dividend cuts? People say its true, but is it? Any look at rdividends shows the usual amount of nervousness found in investing subs around share price and future performance. If a strategy is presented as more appropriate for less secure investors, its only logical that we would want to know if it actually does what people say it does. Finally, when we say that there are different strategies for investing, we have to set a bar that these strategies are at least equivalent, in that theyre designed to produce as much riskadjusted return as possible. If someone is only investing in dividend payers because of wrongheaded ideas, theyre taking more single company risk for possibly smaller returns looking at you, KO and JNJ investors. Its a choice someone can make, but I wouldnt call it a strategy. Itd be like a race car driver prioritizing the condition of their tires over going fast enough to win the race.

I agree that dividends are an indirect way to gain exposure to the profitability, conservative asset growth, and value factors. But there are some reasons why dividends are a good means to do this 1. Funds that track factors usually either have higher fees than dividend index funds, or they do a poor job at tracking factors. For example both Fidelity and Vanguards Small cap value funds had 2 well known meme stocks as their biggest holdings during the 20202021 trend companies that were unprofitable and trading at very high valuations. Finding a fund with both a solid methodology and low fees is exceedingly difficult. As a result, it is unlikely investors will achieve the same level of excess returns that academic literature suggests. 2. Dividends provide a psychological benefit that can help investors stay the course during market turbulence. Even if a proper value investing approach provides slightly higher returns, if dividends help prevent an investor from selling off during a crashbecause the cash flow provides comfort, it can enhance actual returns. 3. The value premium tends to lead to investing in companies with high capital requirements, due to its reliance on book value. This leads value funds to firms with low return on invested capital. Dividend strategies, however, mostly track the profitability factorbecause generally, only profitable companies pay dividends. There is a lot of argument to be made that companies with high return on invested capital perform better.

Reinvesting dividends is critical. When a company pays a dividend, that money is no longer available to the company to fund future growth but, on the other hand, you have a share of the profits today. If a company doesnt pay dividends, on the other hand, the profits are retained and, in essence, reinvested in the company to theoretically fund future growth. As an investor, reinvesting dividends equalizes this to some degree. Youre not actually giving money back to the company unless you have a DRIP with the company itself, which are less and less common but you are increasing the number of shares you own essentially for free. Check out some online DRIP calculators to see the difference in total returns with dividends reinvested vs without. Its astronomical.

As are capital gains. The difference is when those taxes are due When you receive a dividend you pay taxes on that income in the year the dividend is paid, but capital gains only occur when shares are sold. Typically, stocks with higher dividend payouts see their share prices grow more slowly so it roughly evens out in the end. So youd have to pay taxes on something that youve reinvested ALA dont have the proceeds to pay the taxes anymore. This is a fair point at least in theory. Since you have to pay tax on the dividends each year, you have less money available to invest. If the tax on a 300 dividend to use OPs example is making or breaking you, though, perhaps you need to reexamine your broader financial picture. The uncertainty of future tax law also must be considered when dealing with capital gains. We have seen the longterm capital gains rate and even the definition of longterm change multiple times over the past 50 years, and while Im not too worried about some of the wilder proposals being adopted I could certainly see the environment become less favorable for capital gains in the future.

With DRIP you own more stocks of the company, with buybacks you own the same amount of stocks with fewer stock in circulation. Both have the same end result, you own a bigger percentage of the company and its future cashflows. The only difference is that with buybacks you avoid the taxable event. Think about Boeing stock when it was 400 and Boeing bought back 40 billion worth. The stock price actually decreased even before all their issues after that which means not only did the buy back not improve the investors holdings, it decreased. Where as if Boeing had spent that 40 billion in dividends and the stock owners DRIPed it, they would have more shares in total actually lessening the impact the stock decrease in price. Not the same thing. If they distributed those billions and people DRIP them, they would own more shares, but they would own the same percentage of the company. The Market cap would remain constant in this scenario, and both portfolios would have the same value.

In both cases market cap goes down. 1 year later when the company generates cash for another dividend andor buyback, the market cap at what the market values the company will be the same in both cases, leading to a higher price of the company that does buybacks because they own a bigger share of that cash. For your example of Boeing to be true, the market cap of the company should be lower when they do buybacks. Why would the value of the company be lower if the future cashflows are the same?
Then show to us he doesnt clearly prefer dividends in his investment

First, dividends and capital gains are absolutely taxed at the same rates assuming they are qualified dividends. And if you are following the DRIP methodology you will not sell those dividends until they are considered long term gains. The tax increases as incomes does just like capital gains. Second, when a company pays a dividend the total market value doesnt decrease the same amount. And you are making the assumption that total market value of the company directly drive stock price which it does not. If it did, Apple being one of the largest companies in the world would have the highest stock price which it doesnt. Market cap doesnt change with buy backs because the total number of shares in existence hasnt changed. The owner of the shares has changed and the availabiiity to those shares. Total number of shares remains the same. Thats why when a company does either a split or reverse split, the stock value changes but the total market remains unchanged.
He clearly prefers buybacks over them. Theyre effectively the same, one is just more tax efficient. If you cant see that already than you simply dont understand what a buyback is.

First, dividends and capital gains are absolutely taxed at the same rates assuming they are qualified dividends. Not every dividend is qualified and the tax with buybacks is deferred until the moment you sell the stock. This gives a higher compounding effect in the long term. Second, when a company pays a dividend the total market value doesnt decrease the same amount. It does go down as the assets of the company goes down. If 1 day you have a company that is valued 100 and 3 of those is cash, why would the company be valued at 100 if they dont have that 3 in assets anymore after the dividend payment? The exdate or exdividend date represents the date on or after which a security is traded without a previously declared dividend or distribution.1 The opening price on the exdividend date, in comparison to the previous closing price, can be expected to decrease by the amount of the dividend And you are making the assumption that total market value of the company directly drive stock price which it does not. If it did, Apple being one of the largest companies in the world would have the highest stock price which it doesnt Completely missunderstanding my point. The important thing is the value of the company, the price of the stock is derived from that depending on the amounts of shares outstanding. Thats why splits or reverse splits dont change the value of a company only the stock price and number of shares.
Or you dont understand dividend

His own audience, and his investment products, are also not geared entirely towards the older retired crowd, again, hes just too afraid of risk and volatility and, like most money managers, he is ultimately likely to produce net returns that are lower than the broader US market. He tilts to small, value, and profitability factors, why do you think he is more risk adverse and would underperform the market? That makes no sense and does not show a proper understanding of the approach he uses. You appear to simply be comparing a global portfolio to the US market over the last 15 years and are presuming because the US won, it always will. Nonsense. As to the SWR, how would it be telegraphed out? You got a crystal ball? Nonsense. Personally I plan to aim for somewhere in the 3 range but each year if my portfolio after withdrawal still outperforms inflation, I will ratchet up. For example say I have 1M at retirement, so I can withdraw 30K. Next year I only have 750K, and inflation is 2, so I withdraw 30.6K inflation adjust per usual. The following year the market goes crazy and I have 1.5M, and again inflation is 2. Instead of withdrawing 31.2K, I pretend I just retired that day and withdraw 3 of 1.5M, or 45K. If I get a bad sequence of returns, Ill be safe and ready for it. If I get a more typical sequence of returns, Ill be able to meaningfully increase my spending over the years.

There are 15 year periods where bonds beat equities. Is that a reason to go 100 bonds? Of course not. You have to go where the odds are best. Furthermore sequence of returns matters. 20002009 small value did 10 CAGR, market did 1 CAGR. 20102019 small value did the exact same 10, market did 14. Diversify and avoid boombust cycles and the likelihood of looking back in 1545 years and being glad you picked what you did will be highest. Looking backwards you should judge yourself on your strategy, not the outcome.
Bond,SP 500,small value are all market, Felix fund is just an individual portfolio. I wouldnt treat Felix portfolio as same as bond market just like I wouldnt treat BRK as same as VOO

Bond,small value are market. But once you decide how to mix them, its your personal choice, its no longer market
Small value is literally a subset of the market based on many ruleschoices. To imply that isnt a personal choice, but asset allocation between funds is, is nonsensical gibberish.

Congrats on building such a strong financial foundation and the exciting news about expecting a baby! Its great that youve been maxing out your HSA and thinking ahead about how your strategy should evolve with more medical expenses on the horizon. First, its worth weighing the benefits of staying on a highdeductible health plan HDHP versus switching to a plan that might offer better coverage for a growing family. If you anticipate higher healthcare costs with a baby, a traditional plan with lower outofpocket costs might be more practical. However, youll lose the ability to contribute to your HSA, as you mentioned. Your current HSA balance of 40k is a fantastic cushion, especially since it will continue to grow taxfree. One option could be to keep paying for smaller expenses outofpocket as you have been, while saving the HSA for larger medical expenses or longterm retirement healthcare costs. Another approach would be to start using the HSA for qualified medical expenses once your family grows and healthcare costs increase, while letting the remaining balance continue to grow taxfree for retirement. It sounds like youve already done the heavy lifting with your other retirement accounts and emergency funds, so continuing to max out your HSA until you possibly switch plans could be a smart move. And even if you do stop contributing, that 40k will still serve you well over time. For health insurance choices, its all about finding the right balance between premiums, outofpocket costs, and what will give you peace of mind for your family. Id say focus on what gives you the best coverage for your needs now, knowing youve already set yourself up for success with your HSA.

If you plan to have a baby in 2025.. then switch your health insurance to the most expensive plan assp one that covers maternity with the lowest deductible. Delivery and 1st few years are most expensive. Having a better health plan actually saves you After a few years..maybe 3 years, then you can switch back to High Deductible with HSAa again.

Congratulations on your baby in the making. My suggestion is upon having the birth of your happy healthy newborn you start whats called an ugma account. This is money that is set aside for your child for later in their lifetime and theres significant tax advantages it varies depending upon the state where you live so you can call your accountant you could call the IRS you could call hr block or anybody similar to that to find out what the benefits are for yourself and your specific state.

No baby yet, but hopeful for one in 2025, or at least the beginning of deliberate trying, which should yield one at some point! Instead of investing and not touching it until retirement as a pseudoRoth IRA?

So even without the HSA you think PPO is worth? 10s of thousands seems crazy but I get it. Are you all on one plan? My wife has her own through work so were debating keeping my high deductible to max HSA and hers as the PPO that the kids roll under

This isnt universally true though. My employers HDHP plan is significantly better than their PPO plan for both low and high health care users. The HDHP deductible is only slightly higher but the copays, coinsurance etc after hitting that slightly higher deductible are MUCH lower than the PPO plan. When you add the lower monthly premium and the tax benefits of the HSA its a no brainer for me. This just shows that you cant generalize and you really need to look into the details of lyour specific plans.

She works and we both have insurance through our firms. This will likely stay that way through the birth but thats an area we need to explore. We file jointly, does that still allow one member to claim the baby?

Personally, I max out contributions to the HSA to maximize my taxable income reduction. I keep enough to cover the max out of pocket in cash in the HSA, I spend from this for whatever my healthcare expenses are. The rest is invested in the HSA for future healthcare expenses.

It sounds like what youre really saying is that you want to limit your exposure to megacaps, not the SP 500. The top 10 companies in the SP 500 make up 30 of the index, and 8 of them are tech companies. I have also been looking for ways to invest in diversified funds or indexes without this huge weighting. I dont want to avoid technology completely because I think its still a great business long term but I want more exposure to the other parts of the economy that are strong. One way to go is an equally weighted SP 500 ETF such as RSP, it has the same 500 components as the SP but in equal weighting. This does mean that you have a larger weighting for small companies like Zions Bancorp but even the tiniest companies in the SP are pretty big. Another is to find a well regarded mutual fund that doesnt invest in technology like the Smead Value Fund. This isnt a recommendation and there are many others but a long solid track record, high Morningstar rating and low exposure to technology works for me.

My fixed income portfolio 60 of my overall portfolio, Im retired is comprised completely of corporates bonds and treasuries. Over the last 23 years I loaded up on 4.5 to 5 yielding instruments. My bond ladder is 12 years out and overall the fixed income portion is giving me about a 4.9 yield. I do have some Ford SP rated BBB Moodys rated Ba giving me about a 7.4 YTM, maturing in 2047, but Im keeping an eye on that in terms of business conditions at Ford. Thats propping up the yield a bit. Ive simulated included inflation interest rate risk over the next 12 years by assuming yields dropping on 1015 year maturities to the 3.25 range included some BBB rated bonds in the mix. And assuming a 3 annual return on my stocks in addition to dividend payments yielding about 1.4, which Im currently reinvesting, Im still ok. What I mean by that is at the end of the next 24 years, my IRA is still healthy. Ive dabbled a little in derivative based ETFs JEPI included. It occurred to me that I was trying to get fixed income security I use the term loosely with the benefits of owning equities and it wasnt happening. When treasuries popped over the last 2 years, I said forget that stuff. So my stock portfolio is now SPY, DIA, FTEC, XLC, VOE and VOT. The last two are a total of 5 of my overall portfolio. The bulk of it is in the first three. The FTEC is an IT ETF but it contains all subindustries of IT e.g. software, software services, hardware, semis, materials.... The FTEC position will probably move to QQQ as I sense the AI hype comes down to earth and hopefully manifests itself in real benefits outside of tech itself. That along with the Ford bonds are the only market timing aspects currently in the picture. Pretty basic and nothing fancy. But it works for me.

The US accounts for 50 of total stock market cap in the world. 2. There are other popular indexes, like Nasdaq, Dow, Russell, but really for all intents and purposes SP 500 is the one. Why? Because it has the most consistent history. Dow is hand picked, Nasdaq is very tech focused, etc. 3. If you really want to own the entire entire market, youd buy VT, which buys 99 of all publicly traded companies in the world. 4. Yes, QQQ has down well, but so has AAPL. So why not just buy that? Because the point of buyandhold setitandforget it investing is picking a lowcost diversified indexlike VOO, and buying consistently over time. If you buy consistently also known as dollarcost averaging big swings like the dot com bubble, 08, COVID, mean nothing in the long run. Look out more than 20 years and youre looking at absolutely amazing returns for doing nothing but buying the top 500 companies in the US. So Im not sure what your counter is? VOO and chill works better than 90 of actively managed funds, who do this for their day job. Thats sure good enough for me!

Not concerned, quite the opposite. The resilience of this market is unprecedented in my experience. Every time it is on the ropes the buyers rush in. I manage risk based on price of my investments, not on my amateur opinions of how macroeconomic conditions might unfold and affect the stock market. As of now, price is very loudly stating that we are in a very strong bull market. Whether it is justified is irrelevant to me, because my investments are rising in value, and that is the goal. IMO, sitting on the sidelines when the market is making new alltime highs has opportunity cost. I will change my opinion when the market changes its mood, which could be in a week, a month, or a year. While I was cautious coming into this event, thinking the market might sell the news and gap down today, the market proved me wrong. I dont argue with the market, even if I believe it is irrational. Greed can take it much further than we expect.
Ive never seen a market like this before SPY is up 37 for the past three years. The three years before that it was up 57. Making up exagerated, fictional universes is no way to approach investing.

How are you navigating this market environment? Same as usual, focusing on mediumtolong term themes and maybe a little dialing updown tweaking to certain parts of the portfolio. So, some tweaking, some additions but netnet havent really added much in a while. Are you still finding value in specific sectors or stocks, or are you shifting to a more defensive strategy? Not shifting more defensive. For me, I tend to have a good sense of my investment risk tolerance and spend most of the time near that level. Some times Ill dial risk back a little but the only time Ill have large scale sales is when I want to dial back a theme materially or remove it entirely. Then reallocating those funds elsewhere might take days or weeks. There are still some compelling values and am finding some small new ideas but nothing major. You have a market imo where if you look around, there are parts of the market that look like theyre in recession already and maybe you find 12 things in that pile where the decline is excessive, there are parts of the market that are doing well and have strong tailwinds but are overcrowded and where everyone wants to have the same playbook and theres a lot inbetween those extremes. For those who have been through similar market phases before, how did you manage your portfolio during such times? I think people have to really focus on their best ideas. You have people who own something and then its down 1 and theyre like WHAT IS GOING ON!?!?!? What are names you can own where you are confident enough in the 691218mo outlook where your first instinct when its down is not to hit the sell button but to consider whether to buy more? If you were told you couldnt sell any of the stocks you owned for a year would you be bummed with anything you own being stuck with it for a year? Peter Lynch said this and I think its very true And the single most important thing to me in the stock market, for anyone, is to know what you own. I am amazed at how many people own stocks, they would not be able to tell you why they own it. They couldnt say in a minute or less why they own it. Actually, if you really press them down, theyd say, The reason I own this is the sucker is going up. And thats the only reason. Thats the only reason they own it. And if you cant explain Im serious, if you cant explain to a 10yearold in two minutes or less why you own a stock, you shouldnt own it. And thats true I think of about 80 of people that own stocks. If youre concerned, go through your portfolio with a strong filter and get rid of anything that sounded interesting at the time, youre soso about, etc and replace it with ideas that you have more confidence in andor build on existing best idea holdings. Do you think this rally is justified given the macroeconomic conditions, or are we ignoring potential risks? Peter Lynch again Far more money has been lost by investors trying to anticipate corrections, than lost in the corrections themselves. Can one have an opinion on macro? Sure, absolutely. IMO though, too many people prioritize their personal view of the macro in their universe and the result is them constantly looking for justification to sell. Most of the time not all, but most these discussions go into the category of the above quote.

While you might be theoretically better off timing the market, leaving cash on the side in order to strike when the market is down, the odds of pulling that off successfully are quite low. If you invest today and the market crashes tomorrow, youre still in good shape for when the market comes back to highs that are higher than it is now.

Stay invested, regardless we are in bull or bear. As long as you have a balanced and diversified portfolio, in the long run you will be better off than to time the market. The market is no longer rational. 90 of all equities are held by the top 10 percent of the wealthy. And almost none of the money invested in the market today will ever be needed for actual living expenses. Its just there to grow. Unless theres some event that effects the wealth of the top 10 an actual civil war the market will continue to go up, because the market remains the best place to put your money to get a return. Inflation doesnt matter. Recessions dont matter. There may be occasional corrections, as the most clever and savvy of the top 10 try to eek out tiny advantages over the rest, but the global trend is clear, the market will continue to go up and the wealthy will stay wealthy. Now, some people in the top 10 who are invested will get chased out by fear and a stubborn belief that the market is rational. They will miss big gains. And over time, this timid portion of the top 10 will lose their place and they and their bloodline will be consigned to the eternal peasant class. Dont think. Dont sell. Keep buying.

More than a decade.
To be fair they probably just started investing and have no idea what is normal.

The market has just about doubled from 24 years ago By what metric? The SP is 5700 now. Its already doubled since the dip in 2020 or since 2018 before that when it was 2800. It was 1500 in the year 2000, so its almost quadrupled from 24 years ago.

What index are you looking at? Nasdaq peak was just above 5000 24 years ago and it has increased more than 300 from that high. Same with the Dow and SP. Just stay in the market and buy with every paycheck.

Lol. Do you mean you are one of those doomers sitting on the sidelines and watching this rally go by? If so, you are the absolute definition of why timing the market always, ALWAYS, fails.
Thats why you dont try to time the market

What made you feel this way? A year ago the markets were just starting the recovery from 2022 lows. The economy was shaking off the COVID weirdness, and the job market was good. Inflation was high, but that makes market investing a no brainer just to keep up. I was super bullish to the point I stopped eating out and cut my discretionary spending so that I could invest heavily.
Lol whaaaaa?

Yes, thats me exactly.

Ya, listen. Buy and hold isnt a bad strategy. Its easy to miss the big moves, up or down. And, at the same time, and maybe because of that, it takes a steel nerve to make a big move. So, sure, you left some gains on the table this year or two. But, you didnt lose money. And, in the long haul, youll be fine.
