replies.text: Have you considered simply combining VOOIJRIJH into VTI or ITOT or SCHB? These 3 funds are all total US market style. Theyll hold all 3 market cap segments at their respective weights. International Exposure? Ive heard mixed advice about adding international stocks. Im currently 100 U.S.focused. Is that okay for a Roth IRA, or should I be looking to diversify more globally? US only is single country risk, which is an uncompensated risk one that doesnt bring higher expected long term returns. Uncompensated risk should be avoided whenever possible. Compensated vs uncompensated risk Bold mine Uncompensated risk is very different it is the risk specific to an individual company, sector, or country. Many people try to use the excuse that SP 500 companies do lots of business overseas, but that isnt the international coverage that actually matters. Companies will act more like the market of their home country, so foreign revenue isnt the international exposure that actually matters The purpose of the international holdings is to be covered during the orange periods of the graph here Plus thats true of large companies in most countries. There are many market sectors where foreign companies are some of the key players and do lots of business within the US, but that doesnt mean we can go 100 IXUS. Going global can both help with returns and volatility.
70 VTIITOT, 30 VXUSIXUS or 100 VT

Personally, Id backtest it. Look at periods before just 2011 to present. Specifically 1998 or so through 2011. Assuming fed printing forever and US outperformance for portfolio allocation is shortsighted IMHO. Especially given where we are in the market cycle. And consider adding in foreign VXUS, VEA, EEM and the like.
100 VOO, reevaluate in 15 or so years.
Worse than 100 VOO most likely
And all these folks who are but VOO outperforms, so just do that 100, well, history has some news for you about volatility.

content.text: Feedback on this portfolio? 43 yr old 0 in Roth IRA, starting out

replies.text: its a bad explanation of why roth is good. both sides are tax free on one side of the equation.

On top of the other comments. You want a combination of Roth traditional funds in retirement accounts. Roth allows for tax free withdrawals, meaning you could withdrawal lump sums without affecting your yearly income, whereas traditional will increase your taxable yearly income. This means that you can control your tax rate in retirement. This isnt a rule, but my own personal preference 70 roth, 30 traditional.

Do you think taxes are going up or down in the next 25 years? Are you going to make more money later in your life, or earlier in your life? If you think taxes are going to go up and youll make more moneybe in a higher tax bracket by the time you retire, you have the answer why Roth is better for most people that are not near retirement An example of when a Roth isnt better would someone who makes like 300,000 as a W2 employee, is a year from retirement at 65, and their average spend is going to be like 100,000 in retirement. Roth would be worse than standard IRA because their post retirement marginal tax bracket would be lower than what it is when they are earning income. That being said, no one knows what taxes will actually be in 25 years. No one knows if theyll make more money near retirement compared to 25 years before retirement. My personal view is that with a huge deficit and national debt, taxes can basically only go up and most people are going to earn more money they older they get. This makes a Roth superior for most people until they reach some arbitrary inflection point near retirement.

As youve noticed, when the tax rates before and after are the same, there are no differences, you end up with the same amount. However, you are not taxed at your marginal rate in retirement, rather progressively from the lower brackets up, so your effective rate is lower, meaning you would end up with more. Roth would benefit you if your tax rate in retirement is higher than when you originally contributed.

Thats not the only benefit. No RMDs allows more flexibility. Roth withdrawals also do not count as income and you can use that to your advantage in retirement. Also if you chose to leave Roth money to a beneficiary they will not have to pay any tax either and have 10 years to let it sit before they must withdraw. Finally no crystal ball here....but does anyone really think taxes will be going anywhere but UP considering our current debt obligations?

Lots of good answers here. One thing I think people overlook for the average person investing in a retirement fund is mindset when choosing what contributions they can make. If they go into the example you provided where they can only afford 100 reduction in their post contribution earnings then in really comes down to tax expected earnings and tax rates currently compared to retirement as many people have noted here. However, I think practically that is not the decision making practice that a lot of average people are making. They are contributing x of their income from their paycheck typical for a work run retirement account. Or a set dollar amount, such as 100 in your example. Then deciding which one it should go into. If the person has this mindset then in reality a Roth is an effective way to end up saving more money. Instead of contributing 100 into traditional or 75 into Roth as your example provides, many are choosing an option of 100 or 100 in their rationaledecision making process. In this case you are taking 25 more in tax burden in the current year, but effectively saving an additional 25 for retirement that will also get interest taxfree. And for the average person that will result in a much larger retirement fund with Roth than traditional. I like advocating for Roth for this reason. Clearly you dont fall into this category, as you are thinking about these things and reducing Roth contribution to counteract the tax burden in your example. However, I will say dont underestimate the benefit of Roth not falling under required withdrawals that a traditional has as others have noted. The flexibility that it provides can be helpful.

Here is a really good rundown of why most people should stay Traditional The exception being people who have pensions, or multiple big retirement accounts, or people who want to use their retirement accounts as inheritance vehicles.

You have it exactly right. That said, there are some other things to consider. The main one is RMDs starting at age 75, you will be required to pull a certain percentage based on age from your tax deferred accounts 401K, traditional IRA. This has two impacts 1. Roths are not subject to this, so in a sense, that money is protected. That money can stay in a taxfree account until late in your life. 2. If you do well, RMDs will force you to withdraw more money than you need to live on and may very well push you into a higher tax bracket e.g., 32 than you might be in now. The other is the actual tax brackets. If you are working and are in, say, the 24 tax bracket. If you will be in a lower tax bracket say 12 in retirement, the taxdeferred is actually better than a taxfree Roth. The reality is, its completely dependent on your own situation.
The hope is that youll be in a higher tax bracket when youre ready to withdraw than you are when you pay in.

Either Roth or Traditional retirement accounts can end up being better in a set of given circumstances. Some distinct advantages for Roth in specific situations that obviously dont fit for everyone Roth does not have to have RMDs taken Roth is tax free for heirs Roth contributions can be taken out tax free Roth locks in the tax rate paid and removes risk of tax rates rising if youre worried about that. In a way, Roth accounts let you invest more in the retirement account because while the contributions are the same in dollars, with identical investments, the fact that Roth taxes are already paid means you will yield more after tax dollars later compared to a Traditional disbursement that taxes will have to be paid on. OTOH, Traditional accounts have a large advantage in reducing current taxable income. Many if not most advisors believe there are retirement tax planning advantages from having some Traditional, some Roth and some nonretirement accounts.
I like Roth because you know what youll get at the end. Taxes may fluctuate in the future.
removed

Use your actual tax net rate after deductions in your math. Even with a standard deduction your rate should be less than 25. Also, your adjusted gross income from a pretax contribution would have to be accounted for as well in your math. That, of course lessens your tax obligation.

Your math is correct, but your premise includes a couple of assumptions that certain things remain constant 1. Tax policy Even if your income remains constant, changes to tax policy will affect the relative aftertax perfomance of a traditional vs. a Roth. In this case its a question of what you think will happen personally I find it hard to believe as someone in my mid30s that tax rates will be lower 30 years from now compared to today. 2. Tax bracket Even if tax policy remains the same, where you fall in the tax scale absolutely can change. Most people have lower incomes in retirement but this isnt always the case. These factors are almost certain to change over a timespan of a few decades, so the question is which way do you think they will go. Traditional IRAs have the advantage of providing an immediate tax benefit, whereas with a Roth you have to hope that Congress doesnt change the law over the next 3040 years unlikely, but anything is possible. The way I see it, Roths generally make more sense for people with lower incomes because they can take advantage of the lower tax rates they currently enjoy and have that money and its earnings never be taxed again. For higher income earners, a traditional IRA is the way to go as the tax benefit from deducting the contribution is much more valuable. Each situation is different, though, and a Roth can still make sense if you dont expect your income to decrease much in retirement.

Not sure where youre reading that Roth is always better. Either they have no idea what theyre talking about or you misunderstood the context. If your tax rate is the same now and in retirement then theres no difference. If youre early in your career and you expect your earnings, and corresponding retirement income to substantially increase, then its likely your tax rate is lower now than in retirement, and a Roth is preferable. If youre mid to late career, its more likely that your current marginal tax rate is higher than your planned retirement income tax rate. In this case, tax deferred retirement accounts are preferable to shift realized taxes to your future lower tax rates. A general rule of thumb is if youre in the bottom two tax brackets us posttax Roth accounts, otherwise use pretax tax deferred accounts.

Do you pay capital gains or income tax when withdrawing from a traditional IRA? Because if its capital gains you are going to be paying a lot more than the income tax on your initial contribution. I dont have a traditional though so I dont know a whole lot about it so I could be wrong.
Traditional IRA withdraws count as income, which if its too high, may make some of your social security taxable as well.

The tax situation is equivalent only if your top marginal rates today is the same as your anticipated averageeffective rate in retirement. When you withdraw assuming nominimal other income such as SS or pension you fill up lower tax brackets first. So youre better off with a trad account until your effective rate in retirement is more than your top marginal rate while working.

I get what youre saying, and thats how I look at it. Id rather put 100 in a traditional and defer the taxes entirely. Tax rates will always be fluctuating so long as theyre deciding factors in elections. But Id rather make the gains with the taxes I didnt pay yet, over the cash I already paid taxes on.

If someone says that, they dont understand the difference between roth and traditional. All tax advantaged accounts allow tax free growth, thats what the advantage is. I think a lot of people get thrown by the fact that all the money is taxed as income in a traditional tax advantaged account because they ignore that it was never taxed to begin with, so they think the growth is being taxed where roth isnt, but like you said, its mathematically equivalent regardless when the tax is applied, so all that matters is the rate.

Re Taxes 80 years of tax policy suggests that if you are middle class, your taxes wont grow nearly enough to worry about it. Were talking swings of a handful of compared to rich and poor peoples larger swings. It turns out raising taxes on the bulk of your constituents is wildly unpopular and fortunately your federal politicians realize this. If you check the rates prior to 1985 and were appalled at that 50 tax rate for SF making more than 84,510, thats 250k in todays dollars.

As others have pointed out, the value of the Traditional account is that you can avoid a 25 tax now and spread it out over lower tax brackets later. If your net effective tax rate is 15 in retirement, youll have saved an extra 10 over a Roth contribution. That does come with assumptions, and they may not hold true in the future. Tax brackets may change, their tax rates may change, the standard deduction could change, etc. You have to take RMDs at a certain point which I personally think is no big deal. You could go from married filing jointly to single which could definitely change the calculations. If youre maxing out accounts, you have to take the excess tax savings and invest it, which comes with potential tax drags that are often ignored for simplicity and doesnt do you any good if you spend it now. You potentially have impacts to your SS taxation, ACA subsidies, etc. All of those assumptions go away with a Roth. You dont have to worry about RMDs. You dont have to worry about future tax changes. That money will not be taxed again and does not count as income if they dont change the rules. As with many things, its often ideal to have a mix to give yourself options. Contribute to Roth early when youre not making much and in a low tax bracket. Contribute to Traditional when youre making lots of money in a high tax bracket. If you max it out, shift the overflow into a taxable brokerage.

You are correct that without something else, the math works out so Roth and traditional are equally good. Many people esposing Roth dont understand this well. Things that can make Roth better 1. Higher tax rates in retirement 2. Roth maximum contributions are effectively higher than traditional contributions in the same type of account since they are in after tax money 3. Roth contributions can be pulled early without penalty growth can not 4. Roth contributions can be made when your income is too high to deduct traditional contributions backdoor Roth Unfortunately for most people, tax rates while working are higher than in retirement. At least they have been, historically. So for most working people, Roths are not that great. At least, they have not been in the past.
If you contribute post tax to a traditional Ira should you back door since youve already paid taxes?
You understand it better than most. You want a bit of both or Roth and taxable so you can fill lower tax brackets, then use Roth beyond that.
your math is wrong on the Roth. If you put 100 in a roth account but pay 25 tax then it cost you 125 but you still technically get 975 before inflation.

Roth is good because of its taxfree nature. If you think that income taxes will be rising in the future they will, then a Roth may be a good solution. I stopped contributing to my TIRA six years ago. I could see the writing on the wall when Congrss changed the inheritance laws regarding TIRAs. Beware ...
If you are able to max out the account, roth is better.

Not necessarily better in terms of 401k, but if you max out your traditional, you can add to your Roth IRA, which is preferable to a investment account, since the Roth IRA does not result is Capital Gains Tax when it increases. Thats why they cap it.
Taxes always go up in time. Why not pay tax upfront and not worry about what the tax rate will be in the future?

7,000year into an IRA is 583month. Some people cannot afford to contribute that much, and perhaps send maybe 100month. It all depends on if you need a tax deduction now, or when you retire. Most people imagine that they will stop working at 65ish and then retire, perhaps occasionally draw some money out of the IRA to pay bills, and since they are living off of Social Security, they are bringing home 12 of what they normally make from a paycheck. This means that they will be in a much lower tax bracket. Perhaps 12 instead of 18, as an example. There are many factors, but if you feel that you would be better off getting the tax deduction when you are in your 40s when you are making high earnings and pay high taxes, then do so. Some people are struggling and hope to find some way to buy a house someday, but...My cars are paidfor and my house payment is low. This means that when it comes to my monthly expenses, I can easily put large amounts in my IRA and I dont need a tax deduction to achieve my goals. For me, it boils down to this...If I put 583month in an IRA its maxed out, whether its a traditional or Roth. When I get past 65, pulling money out of the IRA means its taxed even though its at a lower rate, as we said before, and the Roth is not taxed when the money is withdrawn. If you need 3,000, a Roth draws out 3,000. A Traditional draws out 4,000, and sends you 3,000...withholding 1,000 to cover potential taxes in April. Therefore, the remaining balance continues to grow from interest and stock growth, but the Traditional has less money, and it gets smaller faster when withdrawing, compared to Roth. If your IRA will have a significant amount in it by the time you reach 65 or whenever you retire, The Roth seems much better for the retiree, even though it cost you some federal taxes when you were younger. If you can afford to put the max 583mo in an IRA, you may be able to reach a tipping point where your IRA grows faster than your withdrawals. That might be somewhere around 300K, where a 10 bump in the stock market equals 30K Of course if you will only have 10K in an IRA when you retire, the difference between a traditional and Roth is pretty small. So, the answer is...it depends.

Its also a matter of when you derive the benefit. With pretax IRA401k you get an immediate benefit lower taxable income. With a Roth, you get the benefit on the back end. In other words, you have to live to get the benefit of taxfree Roth distributions. Theoretically, Roth is the last you should spend. No?

Your Roth IRA is where you take risks. Imagine an outlier case where your 100,000 shares of a penny stock becomes a 30 stock, i.e., youre up almost 3M. Upon withdrawal from a traditional IRA you owe taxes on the almost 3M gain, whereas you owe nothing if it were a withdrawal from a Roth. Thats just good luck, though. Normal luck and you still have the advantage of no forced Required Minimum Distribution RMD. That means you can control your withdrawals if any to minimize taxes by not stepping up to the next higher bracket. Not just Federal income tax brackets, but also Medicare Parts B and D IRMAA brackets. These determine your next years surcharge for being rich.
Use the taxable also. It doesnt have the protection from creditors but the liquidity and current long term capital gains taxes are worth something.
Personally. I think an HSA is better than a Roth if you have it available to you.

Ignore all of the do you think taxes are going up or down? Nobody can predict that. Its simple really. Both Roth and Traditional IRA contributions are maxed per year at the same amount. If you max out a posttax Roth IRA at 7,000 versus maxing out a pretax Traditional IRA at 7,000, when you go to withdrawal from it in the future which one will give you more money after all taxes are paid? Honestly, it doesnt really matter if youre not maxing out the IRAs.
I intend to make a lot more each year, after all I tend to increase my hourly rate a nice 25 every 1 or 2. Thus, I prefer todays rate. Ive been saying that for a long time, its still true.

So this is viewing Roth vs traditional in an isolated vacuum. Which is good for just comparing differences and use cases. But I think retirement is often executed as a multi prong strategy that utilizes all possible methods and accounts. Retirement is like chess, and 401krothhsataxable brokerageetc are like chess pieces. When you have more pieces, the depth of your strategy increases for making optimized moves. One move I can think of is using Roth withdrawals to supplement your 401k withdrawals, which would put your taxable income even lower in the future. So now instead of at being 25, you might be like 18 or 14 whatever the lower bracket might be 30 years.
Because youre more poor now than in retirement?

When you are early into your career, you are earning less generally speaking, so it makes sense to pay taxes now fed tax increases the more you earn. Later in your career when youre earning like 100150k, it makes sense to use traditional 401kIRA, This is because you are paying relatively higher taxes when you earn that much. To put it another way, if you think you will earn more in retirement than you earn now, Roth is the way. If you think you will earn less in retirement than you do currently, go traditional.

Its more to do with your income level at the time of contribution. If youre in a high er income bracket than you anticipate youll be in retirement, contribute to tax deductible. If your income for the year is equal to or lower than what itll be in retirement, you want the tax free contributions and save the taxable for higher earning years. Both are always better than a taxable brokerage account.

If you do the math like you did they are exactly the same...but there is something youre not considering. In a traditional you are deferring taxes and have more money now. So those extra taxes you would have paid can also be invested. You will pay taxes when you withdraw, but years of compounded growth will make up for that and much more if you investment horizon is 10 years. So example A. Invest 1000year in Roth and pay 25 tax now, let grow for 10 years and withdraw tax free. Example B. Invest 1000 in traditional, save 250 in taxes and invest that as well. Now youre putting in 1250 year and you also get the compound growth on those taxes you didnt pay. So at the end those 25 taxes you compounded will be worth much more. Granted this required you invest the tax savings...but it is objectively better. Not to mention savers credit and other benefits to lowering your tax bracket while working.

Not sure if others have made note of this or not but... Youre correct that all else held equal, it should result in the same spendable cash. With that said, if you have 100 in pretax, you have less options to avoid breaking through to higher marginal rates in the future. For example, required minimum distributions could force you into higher brackets. A distribution to buy a car, or take a nice trip, etc. They all become taxable events with marginal tax consequences. Having after tax dollars in your portfolio allows you more flexibility to stay under bracket limits. After tax also dont have RMDs and heirs wont have to liquidate inheritated IRAs within 10 years. In short... yes... If you have perfect knowledge of future events and know tax rates and spending stay the same, there may not be much of a benefit. If you assume your tax rates will go down in the future, it probably doesnt make sense keeping mind the current brackets are favorable compared to much of US history. However, degrees of freedom and increased optionality have value when theres uncertainty. There are strategies to convert in low income years but you probably dont want to convert all... Filling up the lowest tax bracket with taxable dollars is a good strategy. Recommend spending time to research and plan it out.
If you deposit 100 into a Roth IRA, you deposit 100 not 75. Youve paid the tax before getting that 100 to deposit.

The limit is the same for roth and traditional, so your equation isnt really true. Traditional you can put in 7,000 Roth you can put in 7,000 and pay the taxes. So if you only have 7000, better to put it in traditional so you can hit the max. If you have 8000, put 7000 in the roth and then use the other 1000 to pay the taxes. this is hypothetical and isnt true for all tax situations, just an example to explain the concept.
Both accounts have a max which is the same value. If you can invest the max in the Roth, then its like you get to invest 25 more in your example. Thats one of the reasons I think its superior.
Its all about lowering your effective tax rate in retirement. I think a mix of both types of tax advantaged accounts is prudent if you can afford it.

Youre not taking into account that tax rates can go up and youd be in a different tax bracket paying more. With Roth you simply lock in your current tax rate and move on. It isnt the best no matter what so anyone that says that is an idiot and I wouldnt take advice from them. It all depends on your individual situation and beliefs. Most people are probably better off having a little mix to play around with. One argument that can be made is your tax ratecash flow needed in retirement can be significantly lower, because you may now have a paid off house, kids grown, more settled down, etc. That actually could be a case made for traditional for example. Another case can be made if youre already in a higher tax bracket might make more sense to hold off. The opposite for Roth. In very low tax bracket typically folks starting out in careers probably makes more sense to lock in the low tax rate. Learn to think for yourself here and not just say well, one is always better hurr durr, because that way you can make an educated decision instead of listening to whoever that doesnt have a clue.

Its tax free growth, so in retirement its all yours, dont have to give any to the IRS, and dont pay taxes along the way like you would with a brokerage 401k is also tax free growth in that particular sense. Roth has advantage of being tax free upon withdrawal, so probably higher social security benefits less tax on the benefits in other words, and you can maybe qualify for ACA subsidies, also no RMDs and some benefits for your heirs. I put my growth stocks in my Roth so I can keep all those gains long term and any conservative assets like a bond tent or international positions are in my 401k.
Because tax rates change every year and are likely to be much higher in the future than they are now.

You are correct. If nothing changes and you stay in the same tax bracket and tax rates remain the same, its a wash. BUT... a few things to consider. Tax rates change. Tradition IRA deductions count as income, but not Roth... so withdrawing a lot in one year could push you into a higher bracket. Also, things that look at your taxable income Medicare, low cost senior housing, other benefits do not count Roth withdrawals. If you move to another state it could make one a more attractive option. Think traditional and not paying state taxes on investment then moving to a state that doesnt charge state income tax and you never end up paying any state taxes. Or maybe youre a high income earner in a high tax bracket now but later in life you marry a deadbeat with no retirement, pushing you into a lower tax bracket at retirement, maybe the Roth doesnt look so good in that scenario.

Post tax dollars have more value than pre tax. Also most employers 401k match is traditional. I use that as the hedge on how taxes will fall in 30 years. Plus there is just the thought of having money I earned had had grow that Ill be able to utilize without a tax implication on the back end
Since traditional is taxed as ordinary income, a portion of it is effectively never taxed when you account for the standard deduction.

It depends. Roth tax incentives are so awesome, the IRS only allows people that make below 128k and maxes it out at 7k per year. If you invest 7k at age 18, that 7k would be 750k by 65 all tax free. If you invest 8k pretax, that approx 850k would be subject to income tax rates. Give me the 750k all day tax free.
The math is better over time if the taxes are paid on the front end. That being said, taxes paid on the back end is still good, so after maxing the Roth go for the IRA401K.

Roth is not better than Traditional because tax free growth. Both Trad and Roth have taxfree growth. That is, realized gains inside the account are not subject to capital gains taxes. This is not the case for a taxable brokerage, so there is generally some level of tax drag for money in a taxable brokerage that is absent in Trad or Roth accounts. Youre correct if your income tax stays the same, Trad and Roth work out to be equal. What often happens is your Roth contributions get taxed at your marginal tax rate, but youre pulling the money out of Trad retirement accounts at something closer to an overall rate in retirement, which usually makes Traditional look better than Roth... though itll depend on your particular assumptions about withdrawals, tax rates in the future, etc. The other exception assuming equal tax rates is that Roth accounts have functionally higher limits. For instance, 7,000 is the most you can contribute to an IRA. If youre contributing 7,000 Roth, thats equivalent at your theoretical 25 tax rate to 9,333 in Traditional contributions. But you cant make more than 7,000 per year in IRA contributions. And with IRA accounts in particular, there are income limits that change how things work. For instance, you lose the ability to deduct Traditional IRA contributions at around 72,000 filing single which makes Roth strictly better beyond that limit... at least up to the cap for Roth IRA contributions 150k ish at which point, backdoor Roth would be the way. End of day, it usually makes sense to have some money in both buckets then you control the income you show by Rolling Trad money into Roth accounts, and live off Roth money which doesnt impact your income. That way you can play tax games, smooth out income shown and avoid crossing some barrier for medicare subsidies, etc. But for most people, the majority of the money in Trad accounts is fine.

Ill put this concept out there think of a Roth as a place to keep your emergency funds. Why? Because withdrawing principal is always tax and penalty free. Using a Roth to save for emergencies treats your principal deposit and withdrawal no different than a savings account, however you can see much greater returns than the small amount of interest a savings account will pay. The major benefit to this is that, most people wont have a true financial emergency, or if they do, its rare and infrequent. If it happens, you can access the money as its needed. If it doesnt, you will have a lot more available to you in retirement than had you kept it in a savings account. For this advice to work however, it needs to be part of a larger retirement and investment strategy that includes a traditional IRA, a pension, 401K, social security, and a taxable brokerage account. The Roth is one piece of the retirement puzzle that can work for you before retirement, but should only be drawn up on for true emergencies loss of income, major unexpected repairs to your principle residence, unexpected medical expenses, etc. and not to be used for discretionary spending like a toy or vacation.
Roth is good because you can withdraw contributions without any taxes or penalties before 59 12
The ROTH might also have inheritance benefits. Plus there is no forced withdrawal.
You are correct in your assessment. The tax free growth crowd are just repeating stuff they heard somewhere and dont really understand what they are talking about .
Because you arent paying taxes on the gains, long term you will have much more in gains than you will in contributions. You can also pull out your contributions at any time without penalty.
Withdrawals from Roth accounts are not taxed as income. There is also no Required Minimum Distribution.

Math is wrong... the idea is that you still put 100 in the Roth To put 100 in the Roth, youll be out 133 so that you invest 100 after tax. Now it grows to 1000 in your example all tax free. Now you have 1000 for your initial 133 instead of 750 for your initial 100 in the traditional.

I was in the 32 marginal bracket so for every dollar I put into traditional I would have only been able to put 68 cents into a Roth. Assuming that your investment doubles every 7 years on average then in 28 years the extra 32 cents becomes 5.12. If something happens that crushes your ability to earn, that extra investment is insurance. If not and you end up with so much money that you pay a lot of taxes, you still win.

The Roth not being subject to RMDs later in life is a big benefit if you plan on your accounts being large. Family member of mine has quite a bit in a traditional IRA. All was going well while both were alive. One passed away and now the person remaining is subject to compressed single tax brackets. Thats causing the effective tax rate to be much higher than when they filed as married, and the RMDs continue to grow as the market goes up and as they move through their 80s. A partial Roth conversion has helped.

Your Roth contribution in the example is not 75. Its 100 as a posttax contribution after earning 133.33 gross. You are putting the same amount of money into both types of account. However, when 1,000 comes out of the Roth account down the road its free and clear, yet its fully taxed from the traditional account, both basis and earnings. Only the initial contribution a much smaller amount is taxed in the Roth example. Compound this over many contributions and a lifetime of growth and that is why Roth accounts are amazing. Many people seem to misstate the comparison as youre doing here.

A simple way to look at it If you think youre going to make more in retirement than before, or if you think taxes are going to go up in the future, then a Roth makes sense. If you think youre going to make less in retirement than before, or if you think taxes are going to go down in the future, then stick with traditional. If youre not sure, then do some of both, which I think is what a lot of people end up doing.

You wont know for sure what is better because we dont know future tax rates. If you retire on a lower bracket then traditional is better and if you retire in a higher bracket roth is better. What we do know, however, is that contribution limits are the same so maxing out a roth will be worth more total than maxing out a traditional because you are contributing a higher percent

Im specifically asking about the point I always hear about Tax Free Growth. I believe youre confusing retirement accounts IRA, 401k, 403b, 457, etc using Roth and traditional funds to a taxable brokerage account. A taxable brokerage is only funded with your after tax dollars and you will need to pay yearly taxes on growth, like a dividend. So compare putting 7k per year in an IRA that grows tax free to putting 7k per year into a taxable brokerage
Id rather pay taxes on the thousands going in than the millions coming out. Its really that simple.
You can cram more money into a Roth than you can a traditional. 7500 after tax 7500 pre tax.
With the way our current debt is growing I bet Roth IRAs are over certain value will likely start getting taxed in the next 1520 years.
Compound growth at year 3040 tax free is crazy.

There are two instances that would still make a ROTH account better. 1. You are going to be in a higher tax bracket in retirement. While usually the opposite is true, this can still apply to low income earners who really have a glow up in life financially. 2. You believe tax rates are going to go up. The OPs example assumes tax rates are going to be the same forever, which they most likely wont be. So they can find themselves in the same bracket but paying a higher in the future. In this case it makes sense to pay the taxes now.
removed
Bingo.

Good comment. Also to consider is that if your career doesnt go as well as you hoped, the traditional will probably be more optimal. State income taxes also make traditional relatively more efficient. On the flip side, if you decide to make a major purchase new housecarmajor vacation, the Roth may allow significant tax benefits.

Roth allows for tax free withdrawals ... 70 roth, 30 traditional. Id note that as you can usually roll from traditional to Roth whenever you want, the optimal strategy is to pick low tax years to roll money into a Roth. If you have a high income and are opting for 70 Roth, youre probably paying a lot more taxes than you need to.

One other nice thing about having both is the ability to customize your investments between the two. I have my more aggressive investments in my Roth, and my index ETFs in my IRA and 401k, because thats the one variable that can swing the benefit to the Roth. All the comments and OP have so far been on the assumption that the rate of return is the same in both scenarios and for good reason with the way the question was asked, but if youre inclined to be more aggressive the Roth gives you a good instrument with which to potentially grow more tax free.

its not just taxes go up but lower tax brackets go up, and go up considerably. betting on the standard deduction getting cut in half, the 1012 brackets becoming 2024 etc. given we have a progressive tax system and in retirement your taxable income is probably not all of your income, and you also wont be covering savings when retired, only expenses

One other thing... the 10075 to 750 math you suggested isnt really correct since getting to 750 from those two numbers requires two different times. Youd want to actually plot out your growth and for how long. It will take you longer to get to 750 with the Roth since you started out with only 75. No, hes right and youre wrong. Its simple multiplication. X is the growth over time, doesnt matter how long or at what rate. 100 X .75 .75 100 X. If all else remains the same, it does not matter if you take the 25 at the start or at the end. In reality, our progressive tax bracket system means you pay 0, then 10, then 12, etc on withdrawal of the Traditional funds, so theres a positive arbitrage on the net effective tax rate at withdrawal vs the marginal tax rate at contribution if all else remains equal.
importantly tax free means its not being combined into your other retirement withdrawalsAGI for tax purposes it also has the utility that you can withdraw principal though I would advise against this

If you have a 300k w2, then you are most likely covered by a retirement plan at work and therefore cant make deductible contributions to a traditional IRA anyway. So in that case you would want to max your 401k at work and do a backdoor Roth to maximize retirement accounts.
also do you expect your investments to grow

Compounding is missing though. That chunk of tax free money you put into a pretax account grows and compounds exponentially. So yeah the tax burden can be a pain when you withdraw but substantial compounding as long as you actually invest the tax savings is key. Also will point out theres no certainty Roth accounts wont be taxed down the road. Look at the US Governments fiscal situation, Roth accounts likelier than not to get taxed IMO at least for higher income earners. Especially with the scandals of millionairebillionaires putting company stock into Roths. I have both pretax and Roth accounts to diversify tax risk max employer pre tax 401k and max backdoor Roth IRA.

Ideally you want to have a mixture of traditional and Roth to manage your tax bracket in retirement. Very good video on YouTube by retirement nerds about this where you can get the most benefits by using a combination of both.

The current tax brackets for 32 are 191,951 to 243,725 for single, 383,901 to 487,450 for married filing jointly. I just threw some stats in Schwabs RMD calculator and for a hypothetical balance of 3.5M at 73, the RMD would be 125k. If they didnt raise the brackets at all, I still wouldnt be into the 32 bracket even if I were single. Now, if I made it to 100, Id have to withdraw 1M on a balance of 6M Im not clear if thats the balance before or after the withdrawal but Im assuming after. If they dont raise the brackets in the next 60 years or so, then maybe Im in trouble Ill just have wipe up the tears with wads of money when it comes time to file my taxes. Anyways, point being most people wont come anywhere close to the balance necessary to hit high tax brackets, and the tax brackets will be adjusted higher over time. Unless youre already in a very privileged position, RMDs are a nonissue for 99 of people.

If you are able to save 100mo in a Roth, then you should be able to save 125mo in a traditional. Its the same cash flow same impact to your wallet. Just to be clear, in a Roth youve given 25 to the government and 100 to the Roth. With Traditional youve given 0 to the government and 125 to IRA Now when you take it out in retirement depending on tax bracket you are left with exactly the same amount. Youll have more in the traditional 25 more than the Roth, but will have be taxed on it by about 25... So its a push. What ever the pile grows, both piles will grow by the same . If you double your money then with the Roth youre taking out 200 and nothing goes to the government. With the traditional youre paying 50 to the government and 200 to yourself. Its the same.

Thats the fundamental basis of how it all works, if you dont understand that then everything after is also wrong.

Thats not right. If you want to call it 100 contributed and its 133.33 earned, then that how much youd be contributing to a trad account. Youre comparing different amounts contributed. The end result is that an IRA non retirement savings and Roth IRA after all is said and done is virtually identical.

If youre comparing the two, you have to keep them equal. If youre maxing out your contributions for both, you need to account for the taxable savings of the Traditional and divert that extra balance into a taxable brokerage, otherwise its not a fair comparison. Its not 7000 Roth 7000 Traditional, its 10k taxes 7000 Roth vs 7000 Traditional 2100 taxable.

The IRA contribution limit is 7,000. We dont discount that contribution. We fill it up. The same amount of money goes into either type of IRA. But dont get hung up on that. My point is that the contribution dollars are the same. When you deduct that 100 from taxable income in the trad IRA example, you save 25 on your tax obligation for that year. You dont save anything in the Roth example. However when you withdraw years later, the entire amount is taxed from a traditional IRA. Every penny is exempt from tax when withdrawn from a Roth IRA. Similar thing happens with a Roth 401k. Traditional, the money is deducted from gross pay and put directly into the account without being taxed. Roth, the same amount of money is deducted from my net pay and put into the account. Same contribution. Same dynamic with being fully taxed on years of earnings with traditional, and not taxed at all on years of earnings with Roth.

You cant invest 25 in an ira unless youre low income. Max limit is 7k for both. 7k in roth will outperform 7k in traditional because you wont owe taxes. 7k in roth is like investing 10k traditional which you cant do since its over the annual limit

Typically when that is stated, its in comparison to a taxable account.
I dont expect my tax rate to be the same, but even if I did, I much prefer to have taxes completely removed from the equation when making plans around future balance projections.
any good comparison should be an equal one. ie max roth vs max trad excess in taxable. max trad vs equivalent posttax amount in roth. max roth vs max trad is an unequal comparison.

With tIRAs, you have minimum required distributions that need to start at 72 or 73 and you must draw down the account every year. Thats money youre no longer earning interest on. There is no such requirement on a Roth. You can also pass on a Roth to heirs tax free and they can leave it in the account for up to 10 years accruing more interest, tax free.

replies.text: its really easy to beat the indexes. you just make a bunch of funds with different strategies and close the ones that underperform. also as far as i can tell most of their offerings are really high fee. its quite hard ot beat the index when something as common as 1 aum costs the investor 30 of their growth over 30 years. eg for their growth fund of america Front load 5.75 Total expense ratio 0.63 12b1 0.24 Management fee 0.26

90 of actively managed funds not beating passive investing does not mean 0 beat indexes. It just means you push the ones that did. So probably significant survivorship bias. Just taking a glance at the material, to me 50 of the text on the pages are in footnotes. Which doesnt pass the smell test imo. I bet if you read through the footnotes they cherry pick the fuck out of stats. Id bet my left nut you can find some scammy lawyering verbiage in the footnotes.

Can you link the article? Its hard to critique it without really seeing. But when looking at long term investment performance you have to look at total return, which incorporates fees, dividends, etc. You cant just look at share price. As others have said, its virtually impossible to outperform the SP over a long period of time. Very few fund managers have ever done this.

Be very cautious with someone who claims they can beat the market. Most cannot sustainably do it and when you do best the market there is this negative energy that happens involving you and the fund. It is better to just do the right fund and stabilize it. Beating the market attracts lemmings and then you have the problem of too much capital and then you cant outperform and then the lemmings eat your returns and then when you underperform because they want high returns they go to the next one. Stable growth and the Sharpe ratio are key for it.
I recommend checking out their etfs if youre interested in capital groups convictions.
People who can beat the market are better off investing their own money into that strategy than others.

Its hard to beat the market on a risk adjusted basis not on an absolute basis. Its easy to beat it on absolute terms, for example holding VOO 1 share of APPL would have beaten the return absolutely over the last ten year cycle. The efficient market hypothesis probably isnt what you think it is or means

Ok so I looked at this for 5 minutes and the first obvious thing that jumped out to me was their use of the word benchmark. Notice how they say that word a lot, and how their funds beat their benchmarks, but they dont explicitly say what the benchmark is or they do, but its in the fine print. In 2014, I was foolish enough to invest 500K in gold eagles, buffaloes, Canadian maples, Chinese Pandas, and a few PAMP Suis bars. In 2019, I decided to sell everything. I contacted an authorized dealer who I had dealt with in the past. He contacted a wholesale buyer. The offer I received was for spot price only. It didnt matter if your gold was shaped in a beautiful coin or a beautiful bar, spot price was all you got. I had some older Mexican coins that were advertised by other dealers at 500 above spot, but the wholesale buyer would only offer spot price. After I agreed to sell, I was told to deliver everything to Brinks. So I packed everything and drove to the nearest Brinks. It was a concrete warehouse with no visible signs. You were told to wait in a dark cubicle with locked doors while your package was examined. Shortly after the wholesaler received the package, I received a message saying the price for some coins would be lower because they were not in the original packaging. No choice but to agree to a lower price. The thing to remember is you pay a premium when you buy a gold coin that premium disappears when its your turn to sell.

This is why I have never, and will never buy physical metal. The spreads are insane. Someone I know has worked in that area for a long time and he said no one he deals with handles bullion any more. Theyre all into coins which at least increases the rarity somewhat. But still youll take a loss. Good luck trying to sell fast outside of the ripoff shops with We Buy Gold painted all over their store front. If you must have metal, just buy GLD and call it a day. Even better, dont. This is really a question for rgoldbugs My Dad is a goldbug. He has a number of dealers and brokers he works with, and routinely gets calls to solicit him to sell parts of his collection, or to get him to add to it. Selling coins typically looks like multiple detailed photos of the coin, preferably in its original packaging. Bullion and items made from precious materials are a little harder to move, because fewer people want them, but it works the same way. However, with bar and scrap gold, you can sell to goldsmiths who do custom work, and precious items can be sold to or sold on consignment at jewelry stores. Some brokers provide an escrow service, where the buyer pays the middleman, the seller delivers to the middleman, the middleman verifies the quality or authenticity of the item and releases the money. Other times, if youve been around for a while and know people, and havent stiffed anyone, brokers will arrange a sale between trusted parties as a way of building relationships with both parties. You can also just up and sell on ebay, and depending on what you have that might be the best way to go. Im a silversmith, so I buy silver that way, and the guys I know who branch into gold work often do the same thing.

There are solid reasons why gold is valuable and none of them are mystical. Gold is an element so it cant be manufactured or counterfeited to any serious degree. Thus it is intrinsic basis for a stable money supply without needing to develop advanced anticounterfeiting measures. Gold is physically stable, portable, and malleable which makes it practical as a currency and preferable in those ways compared to barter. Gold is rare enough and difficult enough to extract that it can act as a fairly dense store of value. If it were more common and easier to extract then it would be less practical because you would need a large amount of gold to pay for things. If someone had a job with a similar amount of physical effort as panning for gold, their pay for that job in gold would need to be at least as much as the amount of gold they could pan for in the same amount of time.
In real life you live by whatever means you can. Whether thats selling gold or any other asset. The point is, you would need to find a buyer for whatever it is you own.

Part 1 the prequel I am in my thirties and was born towards the end of the Lebanese Civil War, which lasted 25 years. Before the war, Lebanon was prosperous, and the Lebanese Lira was recognized in major European exchange offices. However, 25 years of civil conflict changed everything. After the war, and for the entirety of my consciousness, a man named Rafic Hariri, among others, attempted to establish a system to rebuild the country. Whether he knew it or not, he was setting the stage for what would become one of the greatest thefts in history. The plan was to borrow large sums of money to build infrastructure that would eventually generate revenue, repay the debt, and put Lebanon back on the map. Many countries supported this plan, given Lebanons cultural advancement and its strong diaspora, so the money started flowing. Hariri had the political power to make this plan legally viable. However, with the influx of money came corruption and foreign intervention. Hariris plan favored one sect over another, creating a deep divide in the country. Since Lebanons sects are almost evenly divided, maintaining political support for his plan required sharing the cake among different groups. But by 2005, one grouplets call them the Axisrealized they no longer needed to share because they had external funding and weapons, giving them the upper hand. Hariri was assassinated. From an economic perspective, the system initially designed to fund rebuilding projects slowly shifted toward benefiting those in power. Public sector jobs were handed out as favors, rewarding supporters regardless of productivity. Instead of investing in sustainable projects, they funded lowquality infrastructure, paying exorbitant amounts for kickbacks. Yet, the banking sector appeared strong on the surface. For my whole life i thought we had a strong banking system. I didnt know anything else. To me you always get intehrest and real estate always goes up.. it was a sure thing. Same as you believe bonds are always good. And SP is safe.. but now I know unless you hold it in your hand. Its not yours. The central bank, backed by government legislators everyone was complicit in this vicious cycle of mutual coverups, worked with banks to acquire more debt. They enticed depositors with increasingly highinterest rates to keep the money flowing. Anyone with a basic understanding of economics could see it was a nationwide Ponzi scheme. Fast forward to 2019 Hezbollah had become dominant in the political scene. The U.S. imposed sanctions on key institutions, and the Ponzi scheme began to unravel, leading to total economic collapse. Part 2 the collapse From 2019 to 2021, Lebanons economic collapse deepened, devastating the banking sector and peoples lives. You would think people would ruch to get their money out. But banks were closed. During closure, only bank owners and the complicit political class took their money out. The rest of the people couldnt do anything. The majority was still politically blindly following their political leader. The Lebanese pound, once pegged to the U.S. dollar, lost over 90 of its value. Hyperinflation set in, and prices of basic goods soared. Banks froze accounts, imposed strict withdrawal limits, and converted dollar savings at a fraction of their value, wiping out life savings. There was a civil uprising. People closed all roads and hit the streets for weeks. But the political main actors refer to prequel where people were handed out public sector jobs.. Well those were a lot who happened to also have weapons donations from foreign countries seeking influence quelled the uprising on one end On the other end the central bank reserve still had USD stores. To control the upsurge they started subsidising fuel and food... and before you think it was a noble thing to do, it was actually another way to pay pro corrupt government individuals since subsidised goods were sold at full price in neighbouring countries benefitting said axis refer to Part 1. The middle class fell into poverty as unemployment soared and salaries became nearly worthless. Businesses shut down, and basic utilities like electricity and water became scarce. Fuel shortages led to long lines and violent confrontations. The healthcare system neared collapse, with shortages of medicine and an exodus of medical staff. The Beirut port explosion in August 2020, which killed over 200 people and devastated large parts of the city, underscored the countrys deeprooted corruption and negligence. Amid this, many families survived only through remittances from relatives abroad. Those without relatives overseas had to send their young to find work in other countries. For those left behind, life became a daily struggle to afford food, medicine, and fuel. People waited in endless queues for essentials, power outages lasted up to 22 hours a day, and crime rates rose sharply. By the end of 2021, Lebanon was gripped by despair, its society deeply fractured by economic collapse, political paralysis, and corruption. The country still hasnt recovered. And might never do. A big chunk of productive people have left the country and those remaining are outnumbered by those who got us into this mess. The corruption is so deep rooted its not only in high officials, but within people. People want to vote for x mafia boss because x has been their provider all their lives. The last elections after the collapse ended with results similar to those before the collapse. Unbelievably sad but true.
Yeah I dont see why people think a civil war and currency collapse in the USChinaEUetc would have broader implications than one in Lebanon.

Because those things are priced in dollars and not gold. It doesnt matter if its priced in dollars or gold. Dollars can be used to purchase gold, and gold can be sold for dollars. The cost of goods is relatively stable vs USD, and gold fluctuates vs USD, it obviously means gold losing and gaining value. I think an argument you may not be considering is how many different dynasties the value of gold has transcended. You may be thinking of a post apocalyptic scenario where food is scarce and there are bands of cannibals roaming the countryside. Instead think of a global shift in power where the value of the dollar becomes worthless overnight. Gold is valued all over the world for its rarity and beauty, and in the modern age is used in computer processors and semiconductors. Its a commodity that will likely never go out of style or decompose. Im not saying everyone should have a fourth of their money in gold buried in their back yard or something but gold definitely has value as a universal untraceable commodity that can be easily carried or hidden.

Thats just objectively wrong. An entire country has deemed Bitcoin legal money, try again. Plenty of people all over the world literally do buy things with BTC. Is it common in most places in the world for people to be actively accepting it? Not yet, but this is a human problem not a Bitcoin problem. First of all most governments will charge you capital gains taxes if it has gone up after you spend it. Not only do you literally have to pay more, you also have an accounting nightmare on your hands. If my Bitcoin gains value over time, and dollars are guaranteed to lose value over time, why would I ever spend Bitcoin instead? Welcome to Greshams Law. I buy Bitcoin every day and am so grateful it is as cheap as it is today. 99 of humans dont even understand it or how it works on a basic technical level this information asymmetry has lead me to 10x my savings in just 7 years. The world will figure out Bitcoin over time, there will be a day when I run out of suckers to dump government monopoly money on for their goods and services and eventually I will have to spend my Bitcoin to get the things I want. Trust me when I say it, Im absolutely not in a rush for that day to come.

The collapse of the US dollar is already underway. Gold is hitting new records for a good reason The world is getting nervous about the dollar, its monetization as a weapon, and the ballooning US debt. Central Banks are furiously adding to Gold reserves. The Gold Standard was never problematic. If you study the monetary history of the world, the fiat currencies lime the USD have all failed in the end., Simple reason Fiat money is not backed by anything and countries succumb to the temptation of printing, crazy amounts. Why? Because they dont have to back it against anything. The trouble starts when a countrys fortunes start to flounder. Then, no one wants to hold that countrys fiat currency and it hastens the collapse. US is inching toward that reality. The only viable and trustworthy currency is one that is backed by gold. Otherwise its just a paper IOU, acceptable while the issuing country is strong, but not so when the holder starts to worry if the IOU they hold may not get honoured. Thats when theyll insist on getting gold to safeguard their interests. If a countrys currency is not backed by gold, no one will want to touch it eventually. That dark day may not be tomorrow but it is not far if the US mints keep printing indiscriminately. CBO estimates that the US debt will be around 53 Trillion dollars by 2030!! Not exactly something that inspires the holders of US dollars.

Youre getting the advice that this sub tends to give, which is only investment focused. A wealth manager can do more than just invest money, so it might come down to whether any of services are of use to you. I use one that stays up on the relevant tax codes so that we can maximize the things I can take advantage. His knowledge of different investment vehicles is larger than mine, so for example last year he suggested we change my 529 contributions. Explained why splitting then evenly isnt the best approach for me. Stuff like that. I can also call him and say hey I have this loan and this mortgage, whats the optimal way to pay them off. A lot of this is stuff I could do, but Im busy as hell and this is well worth it. And its not expensive either so, kind of a no brainer for me.

Things get trickier as you get to the point of wanting or needing to spend your money. And when the market slows or crashes. And especially when those two things coincide. Our wealth manager keeps track of our goals college tuition for 3 kids on specific dates, weddings at some unspecified future date. Medical school? Really, you want to do that and youve gotten in? Can we still afford a more expensive home right now? They recommend market segmentation and asset allocation to help optimize returns, but also protect us in a market downturn. We are riding high on tech stocks, but at what point do you start to pull back and capture gains? When should we take social security? Its complicated with the age and wage difference between spouses. I dont have easy access to software to make comparisons. I would have to sort thru the SS website to get the specifics, on ages, rates, estimates etc. Should we buy long term health insurance? What about a hybrid health life insurance policy? How do you even know about these things? What about Russell index? Dont forget the 4 Inherited IRAs, each with different rules. Did you know there is an income cap for Medicare eligibility?

Managing an old IRA and a 401K is usually passive. This is why you did well. If you get 1M, are you ready to put it into the SP500 and forget about it for the next 10 years? If the answer is yes, and you can do passive investing, then its perfect. If you get 1M, and you feel you might buy ETF, hold a little, then sell if there are bad news, then buy again, or change your investment to bonds then to something else and try different strategies, then you might qualify for a wealth management advisor. The goal will be to pay him 1 to ensure you are not losing 30 on bad decisions and emotional moves. I took the decision to not trust myself with passive investing few years ago. Same as you, good with old IRA and 401K and HYSA, but bad with main portfolio. Transitioning from one mutual fund to another depending on the market news and so on. I decided to have a private wealth management advisor. Since then, many time I asked to try strategies but he always kept me invested and in the right allocation. Im at a point where I start feeling educated and disciplined enough to continue by myself. But I give it a few years before walking by myself. Hope it helps.

Over a 20 year period, 93 of investment professionals UNDERperformed the SP 500. QoD Over recent 20yr period, what of investing pros beat the mkt? Blog ngpf.org I ran some quick models. Lets say the SP 500 delivers, on average, 8 per year. Therefore, if were generous and assume the Financial Advisor was good and equaled the SP 500 performance, with a 1 fee model that means the customer will get 7 return instead of the markets 8. In that scenario, the person who manages their own investments in lowcost index funds ends up with 20 more wealth at the end of 30 years as compared to the person who paid a FA 1 per year.

What are your goals for all the accumulation? Have you run Monte Carlo simulations to law sure your plan can withstand a multitude of market conditions? Are you married? If so, have you taught your wife how you pick when to buy and sell, so she can keep running your plan without a hitch if something happens to you? Have you assigned your wealth to any specific goals, and do you monitor those goals to make sure youre on track? What about kids? Or you have them, have you talked with the about how theyll treat your assets when you pass away? Have you done any estate planning? Have any trusts set up? Advisors dont only manage your investments, they manage goals and expectations and help shift things of life demands it. And yes, i am a financial advisor. Not soliciting for business, just highlighting some of the questions we ask. Plus we give you the gift of time by handling your financial affairs for you. Advisors are so much more than investment managers.

Different people have different situations, objectives, levels of education, risk tolerances, etc. At what point and why should I be willing to pay someone else to manage my investments? At the point at which you figure you need one for a specific reason and you can justify the cost it will incur.

No more time than you would have to spend on a dividend stock.. Real estate investment trusts are fairly simple businesses. Think of owning a beach house and renting it out. They are no More complicated than that. They own Commercial real estate principally or other assets like data centers or Residential and those properties have a value or net asset value or book value. They collect rents, pay their borrowing costs and expenses, and the difference is the profit which is distributed at least 90 of taxable income per year to the shareholders. via a fairly large dividend. They provide huge tax benefits. Theyre fairly simple to evaluate and understand and per multiple European studies and American studies. Their long term performance is two to 3 higher than the S and P 500. Now obviously nothing has beaten the S and P 500 since March of 2009 when its been zero interest rates and everyone piling into tech stocks to the moon. But this wont last forever. Everything always reverts to the mean. I like Rexford industrial, REXR, and VICI properties, and ADC a shopping center REIT, they all have good growth at a reasonable price, and unlike TECH stocks they own buildings not ephemeral patents that can be incinerated overnight, Think Blackberry, Yahoo search, etc

If by massive wealth you mean hundreds of millions and exotic trust funds to avoid inheritance taxes, thats another story. For most people, even those with tens of millions, you can learn everything you need to outperform an investment manager. If you dont want to educate yourself, sure, give away huge sums of money, but if you are willing to learn the basics and you understand your own human behavior, you will easily outperform them. A simple boglehead approach to tax advantaged retirement investing is all you need.

replies.text: Rsp puts an equal dollar amount in each holding, compared to DIA which roughly speaking buys an equal number of shares. So if stock A is 10share and stock B is 100share, RSP will have 10x as many shares of stock A as stock B in order to have the same value. This is only true as of the initial purchase date however, since stock prices move. If stock A goes to 15shares but stock B doesnt move, RSP will now own 50 more of Stock A than stock B. In order to avoid having to trade every day, RSP only rebalances periodically I believe semiannually, but not positive off the top of my head, so any time between rebalance dates there will be whats called drift, and the weights wont be perfectly equal
removed
Any reason? Theres no evidence suggest equal weight beats market weight and the Dow is certainly a choice.
Thanks. Its rebalanced quarterly.
Thanks!
Rebalancing from fixed income into equities. I wanted to get away from the dominance of Microsoft Co I have significant positions in tech already. So I put some into RSP and added to DJIA.
Historically equal weight SP has outperformed market cap weight and the dow has historically had lower volatility than the SP with similar returns
Ahh my mistake, but that sounds right
What caught me by surprise was that I was expecting a DJIA kind of equal weighting, where the number of shares purchased were equal.

Yeah the Dow is a price weighted index, which is part of the reason why most practitioners more or less ignore it these days. Its a relatively silly, antiquated system imo, but its just how it was designed and old habits can be hard to break
Ok price weighted. Now when I look at the DIA etf holdings, there are an equal number of shares for each stock. Is that whats referred to as price weighted? I may have had the definition incorrect.

Yeah thats effectively how it plays out. The target weight of each holding is a function of the share price as opposed to, for example, the companys market cap. DJIA does some complex adjustments to account for corporate actions, but an easy heuristic is to just buy an equal number of shares and the rest works itself out

Yes, the weight of a position is dollars of position dollars of account. The dollars of a position is share price number of shares. In order for an index to be price weighted, share price number of shares dollars of account must be proportional to only share price. Therefore, number of shares must be constant across all positions.

Being way out of the money with that low to expiry is essentially gambling by most standards. Options premiums are about risk reward. Buying a near the money option is expensive because the risk is low. Buying further out is less expensive to buy but the risk is high. The further out of the money ones will spike in value if the stock has a big swing. But you dont need to make a wild swing to make money on, for example, long calls.

Theres two ways you can learn to trade. Day trading with short term contracts which means having a decent understanding of TA and a good control of your emotions. I suck at that one. Or once you get more money you can learn how trade longer term options and play fundamentals and news cycles. The second is way more forgiving but requires more capital. Just focus on learning to be better and dont think youre invincible. It took me losing a lot of money before I realized I suck at day trading but Im decent at following trends and getting value from that. Also a hell of a lot of luck thrown in. No single trading strategy works for everybody so just play it slow unlike I did until you figure out what trading style suits you. Also stop buying weeklies until you have a much better grasp on the market. And dont be upset when you inevitably blow up one or two or three accounts lol

Eek, not a fan of stop losses. Its pretty well known that HFT scalps them. They have the ability to find your stops using deep book analytics and, if the situation presents itself, theyll knock you out. Youre better off entering positions with options and then continue to use them to hedge. For example, buy a 12 month LEAP on whatever youre interested in, if it moves in your way, sell a shorter expiry against it. You can usually get whatever premium you paid for the option back using this method, still book gains, and have a built in stop loss by using the option.

Everyone is different but blowing up your account is often a good time to take a break and reflect. Letting the person earn back their own money is a lesson they need to learn. The best time to jump back in is after a market crash since its easy money good time to rebuild an account. Ill offer some things Ive learned over a couple decades of on and off trading, making and losing and remaking some rather large sums of money. Because just browsing through these comments Im going to venture most of the people offering advice havent actually blown up an account before and are just memeing. First and foremost it should be a what did I learn moment, so you can avoid doing it again, at least the same way. Mistakes and bad luck happen in the market, so its totally possible to learn from your first experience and still blow up the account again. But if you arent learning and getting better, youre just a degenerate gambler. One of the most important elements is that you shouldnt be investing money you cant afford to lose, whether its in a high risk investment or not, because low risk investments sometimes go bust too. Keep that shit in a checking account or iBond if youll need it within a couple years. And once you get into the 100k range you should be diversifying a bit not going allin on one risky play maybe even at 50k, if youre being conservative Second, buy things you wantneed along the way. If you scrimp and save and never buy anything, and then lose all your money, youll feel worse because of all the austerity you experienced for no reward. If you have what you need to be comfortable the loss hurts less. Third, reevaluate your highrisk gambles on a regular basis, dont just throw your chips down and wait for it to moon or bust. Sometimes the situation changes and you need to acknowledge when your initial thesis is no longer on the table and its time to get out with whatever is left, even if its only 510. But always have a reason for getting in, and a target for getting out before you even buy in, that way even if you lose you know why and had a rational reason for it, not an emotional miscalculation. And last, when Im considering whether I should sell a losing investment I like to look at it from a position of least regret. This isnt an objective sell at 50 loss rule, its unique to each person. If you take the loss and the gamble turns around and skyrockets, would you feel better or worse than if you didnt sell and lost the entire amount? Because in volatile stocks weird things happen sometimes, so sometimes taking a position off the table completely even though its the conservative approach might not be the best for everyone. You definitely preserve more capital that way, but sometimes its better to avoid being screwed by lady luck, from a mental health perspective. But you cant do that on everything, you need to be able to recognize a well and truly dead investment and salvage the scraps.

In the meantime, it has a PE of 62 when BYD, a growing company has PE of 22. If you just valuate Teslas EV business, it should be worth 60 to 70 at best. The overvaluation is because people are pricing in autonomy in the share price before Tesla has achieved it. Not to mention, the path to get there will not be easy. If you overlay interest rates overtime onto a chart with TREE, it essentially trades completely inverse to interest rates. I doubt its quite that simple. Their best financial performance was FY 2019 when they recognized 1.1B in revenue and their stock price hit 450 in June of that year. the fed rate in 619 was 2.4. From there, rates were lowered to basically 0over the next year, and kept there for the next two years until rate increases began mid 22. During that time the value of lending tree stock fell from 450 to 60. Again, the interest rate was basically 0 for the entire time. TREE was one of many overly hyped fintech stocks carrying a PE over 250 at its peak. Their financial performance never met the hype and the price fell as a result. As interest rates went down, so did their revenue. I expect them to do better moving forward, but I doubt the market rewards them with such ridiculous valuations again.

You were the one who suggested in another comment that IonQ could have a proprietary QML algorithm. I would be interested in hearing the talks this week because I am not familiar with Yamadas work. For all of your talk that I am making too many blanket statements, you are assuming an awful lot about my professional experience. I would not idolize this industry if I were you Ive learned more in my two years out of private industry than my time in it. Ive also been able to stay more up to date. You say its incredible to think that QC cant help with AI, Id argue the exact opposite. 1 ML is inherently a big data problem, something QC is bad at because youd need to load in and read out data. Part of the reason factoring is such a good problem for QC is because it is relatively easy to load a 2048 bit integer. Whereas in ML youd probably have to load your training data, which would be expensive if you have a lot. 2 maybe youd be looking at solving some optimization problem related to training, at best that would have a Grover sqrt type speedup which would quickly get eaten by error correction overhead rendering it practically useless 3 current methods use variational quantum circuits and classically optimize them, which have no fundamental speedup and people can only point to heuristic improvements. These are on toy problems essentially. For large scale ML this would probably not work at all I mean youre free to consider this a larp and invest in this company with your current knowledge. With what I know about QC, I wouldnt. Then again I missed the crazy price spike this month so what do I know

Anything denominated in USD should use US Treasury bonds as the risk free benchmark. There is no risk that the US government would default, they can always print more money. The actual risk is inflation. Inflation expectations are priced into the treasury yields. That makes them the appropriate benchmark for other debt denominated in USD.
