A CSuite SVP. As leavings go. Id say he will be missed and is leaving on great terms. From LinkedIN ARCHERS ASSEMBLE without me.After almost exactly 3 years at Archer I have decided to move on.When I joined Archer after a few coffee chats with Brett Adcock and Adam Goldstein and some insight into what they were up for, the company was in a quite early stage. The powertrain team that I took over was less than 15 people. We used mainly off the shelf components, motors, inverters and battery cells from prototype vendors.Fast forward to 2024, the powertrain team is more than 150 people in total. Alex Clarabut leading battery, Dillon Thomasson drive units, Stephen Spiteri power electronics and Paul Frihauf leading BMS to name just a few. All rockstars in their fields of expertise. For sure the best team in the hashtagevtol industry. And one of the best in the whole ,,electric transportation of any kind industry.We have designed and validated our own motors, inverters, batteries and battery management systems. Hardware, controls, software, system integration we did it. We have established a close development and commercial cooperation with our battery cell supplier Molicell. We have established close collaboration with the Stellantis engineering community Ned Curic Michael Bly other words Powertrain is set up for success and a safe launch.On the manufacturing side it was pretty clear that no existing supplier could give us what we need the combination of aviation certified manufacturing and leading edge EV craftsmanship. So we designed our own scaleable manufacturing system. And built it. And brought it up. And it runs very well. Kudos to Isaac Harper and Heath Smoot team is set up so well that they will be just fine without me. Which I consider the ultimate goal of a leader built a team that is so good that they can do great without you. YOU GOT THIS, ARCHER POWERTRAIN TEAM!!! So for me its time to move on. I have not 100 decided yet what to do next. It will for sure be in the ,,electrification space. The intention is also to revive my European roots and at least have one leg in Germany. Germany treated and educated me very well kudos to my Alma Mater Ruhr University Bochum I am very excited about the next weeks and months and about the choices and decisions to be made. Stay tuned.

Here is an example of what I am talking about. This was the Uber selfdriving car accident that ended their program. Now, Uber did have LIDAR. But they reduced it to just a single 360 degree sensor, creating a blind spot. The woman crossing the street is completely invisible until just a couple seconds before the car hits her. The actual area isnt nearly this dark. This is a camera artifact. Per Ubers own executives, they would have been able to detect her if they had a side LIDAR. I dont drive a Tesla, but I have used their selfdriving tech. It will warn you if you are driving in very dark conditions with dings and multiple cameras blocked or blinded errors. I mean, its a visionbased system. It needs vision to be able to work. It isnt a 1000 success switch the less light it has, the worse it is at detecting stuff it should be detecting. This is a physical limitation to their approach. You may actually be able to AI your way to mitigating it, in the same way that your phone uses algorithms to improve lowlight photos, but as of now that cant be done fast enough to work for a selfdriving system.

I got private loans offerings at 3.25 and can put those on accounts, offering 3.75 yearly. Sounds like the perfect arbitrage. Only the loan will run for years fixed and the rates for the account are not guaranteed. If you bet the loan on the SP on average every year you will beat the interest. No doubt. The problem is, that there is always a chance you hit the year with the stock market crashing and being depressed for 2 or 3 years. If you have bet your companies money on those gains, your company is likely to struggle from the overall situation and additionally from having to pay back the loan. Which likely means, you will have to sell the assets you bought at a loss in order to stay liquid. There is no free money. If this offer was that good, the bank would buy the SP and not offer you the loan at these conditions. You should trust their economists to do the math, how risky that business is. If you really thought it was a good decision you wouldnt be asking. Lets put it in perspective. In 19261928 the stock market did so well that it was estimated that 45 of traders bought stock with borrowed money. When money is easy to get, people tend to be sloppy with it. In 1929, fueled by runups by never before seen frenziedpace, the stock market took one too many steps out on the ledge and found it had nothing but air propping it up. A slight pullback led to panic selling and margin calls. Which set forth a downward spiral of fear, panic, margin covering, and a firesale to liquidate, no matter what. Borrowed money. Caused it all. Borrow money for speculation ONLY IF you have the funds to repay it tomorrow. Meaning, if your own cash is making more than the interest youre paying, AND only if you have it to pay back all at once, then use borrowed money. But of not. Dont. Dont invest with borrowed money, especially in options.

I did this AFTER the Corona crash to buy quality dividend stocks. Loans were dirt cheap sub 2, and you could get some quality stocks paying more than 12 dividends back then. I paid back the loan over the next two years and still have the shares. Would I do it now in this market? HELL NO. Will I do it again if we crash? Hell yes, but nothing too big that cant be paid back if things go wrong.

As someone who has been in this market for over a decade, Ill start with BE FUCKING CAREFUL. Youre not boarding a train, youre boarding a rollercoaster. While its true that this market has grown, has more regulation, more adoption, has had solid institutions and big name jumping on it, has more solid exchanges, has ETFs, etc...its still volatile and theres still a lot of scams. And its also true that this market is still somehow following I would say more rhyming the same cycles despite it being known and that it should have been priced in. So you might be tempted to think its predictable. But a lot of people are also misreading those cycles. Theyre not perfect linear cycles. So dont get too cute thinking you got the cycles figured out. That said, you are right that we should curb our expectations if we get another bullrun. Those cycles are tapering down and seem to get less intense each time. But I also wouldnt be surprised if despite it all, we see a bullish run in 2025 with a quick phase of FOMO, and then a crash the following year. But I would be careful with any assumptions in this space.

Mining is the validation mechanism of block generation. Mined blocks are then distributed across all other mining nodes to confirm the validity of the transactions. A mining pool is a shared distribution of mining processing power. While the individual miners are independent hardware, they share the responsibility for transaction and block validation. The point I was trying to make is that a collective of many independent miners who operate as a collective single identity could be so inclined to operate in bad faith to manipulate the transactions added to a block. This is the principle idea behind the 51 attack. Should a mining pool control the majority of validation nodes processing power, then they can effectively control the future of transactions added to blocks. I think any mining pool found to be doing this would probably see a mass exodus and the faith and value of Bitcoin would suffer. But I think there are at least a few Nationstates that would be inclined to shake those branches for whatever reasons. As for Mandala, no surprises there that youve not heard of it. Simply a point that the function of Blockchain goes beyond the use case of a financial tool and investment device. As a parachain within the Polkadot ecosystem think Ethereums shards its security is backed by the proofofstake of the entire ecosystem, thereby allowing even small, unknown chains to have robust security and high quality block integrity.

The SEC order on Dr. Wang calls into question one part of the P2b data, but ignores the fact that Dr. Wangs biomarker results were contemporarily replicated by a fully independent 3rd party lab at the same time Quanterix. Dr. Wang also has plausible explanations refuting the SEC allegations, though ultimately thats not going to be resolved until far in the future with the DOJ trial. I know the company has been through a lot over the past few years. Im not saying this stock will definitely go up, but I think the chance of a turnaround is mispriced. On average, this play could be profitable. Of course, I cant go into too much detail in a WSB post. Its not about predicting exactly what will happen anyone who claims they can predict the stock market is probably just kidding themselves. But I believe youd come out ahead if we ran this scenario a bunch of times.

I see the biggest opportunities when the entire market has a solid opinion about something. Thats where you can find prices that are irrational or mispriced. It doesnt mean going against the crowd is always a winning strategy, but if you just follow what every retail trader is doing, you wont get great returns. For those looking to play it safe, ETFs like the SP 500, QQQ, or MSCI World make a lot of sense and can provide decent returns. When I think about the next 10 years, Im not too sure what will happen. Im more focused on the next 13 years. Sure, you can jump on the NVIDIA train and the whole AI hype, but while AI is a hot topic right now, weve seen four waves of AI before, each bringing new revolutionary advancements. Im skeptical about how smart these LLMs really are, and there are many other forms of AI that have potential too. Additionally, NVIDIAs valuation is influenced by factors like demand for gaming GPUs, data center growth, and the overall semiconductor market trends. However, with a 3 trillion market cap, Im curious to see if they can maintain that level. It seems heavily tied to momentum and hype, and we all know hype can fizzle out. If youre looking to play it safe over the next year, maybe consider investing in a few broad and diversified ETFs, and perhaps look into some China and India indexes, too. Overall, I think investing in Intel could be a good addition to your portfolio, but I wouldnt recommend putting your entire portfolio into it.

The market and the broader economy are distinct entities. A significant portion of consumers remain financially stable, and I observe a sizable group with substantial capital participating in the market. At the same time, another segment of the population has been left behind, unable to benefit from the rapid appreciation of assets, and they are experiencing financial hardship. Historically, when there is a large disparity between wealthier and struggling groups, it rarely bodes well for societal stability. Furthermore, this growing wealth gap undermines the predictive power of traditional economic indicators. Those who hold the greatest influence in the market have largely profited from the recent asset surge. As a result, their financial stability allows them to continue shaping market dynamics. Meanwhile, those left behind, though financially strained, may not represent a sufficiently large portion of market participants to significantly alter its direction. This divergence underscores the ongoing disconnect between market performance and the real economy. I dont see where in your analysis you account for this dynamic.

The end consumer struggles first, which then causes the businesstoconsumer companies that sell to them to struggle, which then in turn causes them to cut spending or close up shop, which then in turn causes the bigger B2B businesses like Microsoft, Google, Amazon AWS, and Meta that sell to those B2C businesses or to some other middleman B2B intermediaries down the chain to take a hit in their earnings but not a catastrophic one or anything like that. I think some companies are more overvalued than others and mayshould take a bigger hit, but Im feeling too lazy to go through each one right now. But I will say this for what I think of overall SPY valuation I use sites like currentmarketvaluation.com and multipl.com to see what the SP 500 is valued at overall vs. historical averages. Currentmarketvaluation shows the SP 500 Buffet Indicator, CAPE ratio, and Mean Reversion all being above or near 2 standard deviations above historical averages i.e. Strongly Overvalued, i.e. near the red dotted line. The last 2 times that happened were in 2021 and 19992000. So, that makes me bearish overall. Seeing the sentiment survey on aaii.com often a contrarian indicator leaning so heavily bullish in a historically very overvalued market makes me feel even more bearish. I feel like best case, the market is fairly valued right now if earnings growth is superb. If earnings growth is tepid, market is overvalued. If no earnings growth, even more overvalued. If earnings decline or recession, extremely overvalued. But in the meantime, clown market gonna clown market and algos will bubble it higher if theyre so determined to do so.

If a doctor experiences an erection lasting longer than four hours, they should seek immediate medical attention, just like any other person with this condition. Heres what they should do Seek Emergency Care The doctor should go to the nearest emergency room or call for emergency medical services right away12. An erection lasting more than 4 hours is considered a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment to prevent permanent damage to the penis3. Medical Evaluation At the emergency room The attending physician will perform a medical history and physical exam to determine the type of priapism ischemic or nonischemic1. An ultrasound may be used to measure blood flow in the penis3. Blood tests may be done to check oxygen levels in the penile blood and look for underlying causes1. Treatment Options Depending on the type and duration of priapism, treatments may include Aspiration Excess blood is drained from the penis using a needle and syringe1. Medication injections Drugs like phenylephrine may be injected to constrict blood vessels and reduce blood flow to the penis1. Surgery In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to restore normal blood flow12. Followup Care After emergency treatment, the doctor should Follow up with a urologist for further evaluation and management1. Investigate and treat any underlying conditions that may have caused the priapism3. Consider preventive measures if recurrent episodes are a concern1. Its crucial for the doctor to overcome any potential embarrassment and seek immediate care, as untreated priapism can lead to permanent erectile dysfunction or penile tissue damage34.

Either you really believe the economy is going to boom with lower rates which is what the stock market seems to imply which youd think would make long rates go up to compensate for the opportunity cost or you think we stagnateshrink even with lower rates. In that case if the government continues to issue debt without offsetting tax revenue youd have to expect some currency devaluation as bond issuances continue in which case I cant see people lending money to the government for 20 years for a 4 return. I think a massive steepening of the yield curve is a real possibility where the fed manipulates the short end while the long end sinks. But the most likely scenario is that it just settles at a slightly higher rate. Because nothing in the report shows anything of concern. Ive worked in SNFs in both East and West Coast. None of the practices are out of the norm. It just shows they increased services to their patients, and offered new services like respiratory therapy and sensory integration. This is how many LTCs are expanding to reduce readmission rates, limit fines. Using the COVID waiver to skillinplace was to avoid sending too many patients to the hospital which was overloading hospitals and making more people sick. LTC residents are a highly vulnerable group and needed increased assessments which is why the billing rates were at the 3x rate. If SNFs avoided this practice theyd be putting their patients at high risk. The report said PACS was misleading due to mentioned QM rates. That not misleading, its simply true. There are many factors that go into CMS ratings, from staffing ratios to number off falls, wounds, psychotropic use, etc. Its like a car company mentioning they have class leading fuel efficiency. Are they being misleading because they didnt mention that they DIDNT have class leading seat capacity? There is nothing misleading by mentioning your best assets, and thats what PACS did. They said administrators have limited experience and are bros. So effing what? They dont like that administrators are young and have a fun personality? Really? This whole report screams bias and nonsense in order for the activist short sellers to make a quick buck.

I did thought that the report was garbage and added to my position initially. Digging a little bit deeper it seems to me that several SNFs have been sued for similar abuse none are public companies. I am more worried about the over billing part due to covid waiver which seems like the most likely case they can get caught with. PS I hold a significant PACS position

The over billing through COVID waiver is of course a concern, however this was during a time that state governments were changing their guidance on a literal daybyday basis. One day theyd say to wear PPE and isolate, the next theyd say not to. We even had state surveyors in my building and they argued amongst themselves about what the right protocols were, because they all had different opinions on it.
So all in all youre staying long because you believe that it will be hard to prove those allegations?

Hard to prove, sure. But really because its a great company. I have friends that are nurses and therapists at a PACS building and they said they do more for their patients than any previous SNF owner. When the allegations came out the employees I know said they thought it was garbage. I did my own research and came to the same conclusion.
Appreciate your inputs, I am still long for PACS. Lets hope for the best!

China does what China does well, sell things cheap. Consumers in SE Asia dont have as much to spend on stuff. Even as a US fat cat, I dont see it as worthwhile to spend on an iPhone when I can get a phone that does the same thing for a fraction of the cost. This is what killed Apple on PC, and they are repeating it with phones. Huwawei isnt competing with Apple, they are competing with Samsung, Motorola, HTC etc. iOS has had 30 of global market share for the past 15 years. Apple is sometimes the top selling phone maker globally but usually not. Right now that looks like Samsung. For someone with an average income of 10kyear like in Indonesia, that 1000 phone is priced out of reach. Would you spend 110th your yearly income on a phone? Tesla said at their inception their goal was to make an inexpensive electric peoples car. BYD beat them to the punch. The idea of making a cheap car is a good one, it is just the US makers cant get over their markups. Its more profitable to sell a 50k car than it is to sell a 10k car, just as it is more profitable to sell a 1000 phone than it is to sell a 200 phone. When you have a bunch of profit being made, someone is going to come in and undercut. If someone is making a zillion dollars doing something, someone else is going to find a way to do it for half a zillion dollars. This is the way. The Chinese, with their scale, are happy to make 10 on a widget when the US companies need to make 100 on the widget. Aside from just paying their people less and having the people profiting also be the regulators, they know they can scale to their own huge market, and extend that to the billions of people in the world that arent US rich. They also arent answering to shareholders demand for profit to the extent that US companies are.

ChatGPT 4s last update was in 2023, and it is entirely ignorant of anything thats happened in the market since then. I have immense skepticism about LLM gibberish engines in general, but the first hurdle to clear here isnt even an LLM issue, its a timing issue. Markets simply move faster than training updates do.

Its true that a lot of people confuse LLMs with AI as a whole. But honestly, even if they havent figured it out yet, there are practical ways to use these models in trading. Its less about creating a foolproof strategy and more about making sense of vast amounts of data or even generating ideas. That said, the market is complicated, and expecting any AI to nail it consistently seems a bit unrealistic. If youre in the game, you gotta stay sharp, no matter what tools you think you have at your disposal.

If you exercise the call option when the underlying is trading on that price and sell immediately you would have a net profit of 0.

A straddle just means buying a call and a put at the same strike price. The market does have to move more than it would if you just had one or the other, in order to offset the loss incurred by the opposite, and since youre buying both calls and puts, its more expensive. Dont try this with an account less than 5k and dont try this on days where theres no news. A small move in the market will just make you lose more money. Im going to use the SPY as its cheaper than the SPX, but the same principle applies for both, the SPX is just 10x more expensive. The SPY is currently 551.05 in after hours. You would buy a call at 551.05 and a put at 551.05. Lets say you did a 0dte expiring tomorrow at EOD sept 4th. Do not accidentally buy a 0dte in after hours for eod today. There isnt enough liquidity after hours to ensure a sufficient move. As long as the SPY moves up to 555, or drops to 546, roughly a 5 move tomorrow, youll make money. Ordinarily, if you bought a call, it might have to only move 2.50 for you to begin making money but since youre also buying a put, it will have to move more. Thats okay, as long as you feel the market will make big moves, regardless of direction. Today was a perfect example. The SPY dropped 8 dollars, so you would have gone 3 in the money per contract. If you had bought 10 call contracts for 2770 and 10 put contracts for 1810, and the spy had gone up to 558, the 8 dollar move from today, you would have made 2420. If the SPY had dropped 8 to 543, you would have made 3670. Straddles are perfect for volatile markets. When you know theres big news coming, like GDP, or JOLT, or anything else that impacts the market in a big way, but you have no idea if its good or bad, its better to take a smaller profit by using a straddle, than risk everything by betting on a direction and being wrong 50 of the time. More like wrong 90 of the time, right? Thats how you wipe out your account, by chasing big gains when you could have make 2k today. Making your monthly rent in a big city in one day is always a solid play.

Straddles. Look at the market today. It moved 100bps. Tomorrow is JOLTs. If its good data, we could retrace back up 3050bps. If its bad, we could get a continuation down of another 70100bps. Since we wont know what it is until it happens, its better to be ready with a straddle. Make a little money everyday. Dont risk everything on a sure move only to lose it all when it goes the wrong way.

Just keep in mind, that the options exercise operation may not be immediateintraday the stocks may land in your account only a day or two later and therefore it may not be possible to sell immediately. Though it should be possible to shortsell immediately using the stock borrowing facility of your broker if any, then cancel the loan when shares arrive from the exercise. Some brokers might even pretend, that the exercise was immediate and give you the shares immediately. Although this would be some additional servicebenefit on their end, the clearing house OCC, etc. does not work that way.
I come here to see what not to do but occasionally you find hidden gems like this, thanks

Thanks, Im looking into this more now. Seems pretty straightforward. How does this actually make you money? You would be ITM on one of the positions but losing on the other at the same time. Do you need to sell one of the contracts once you have an idea which way the market is moving or how does the strategy for selling them work?

Straddles are perfect for volatile markets but death on days where the market doesnt move a lot. Your spending more money to buy both calls and puts, so if it doesnt move a lot, youre screwed. You do have to move enough to offset the loss of the other contract, so its best reserved for days when theres big news, like GDP, or JOLT, or something else large. Today, there wasnt much news, but the market was trading on fear from last week, so you do have to pay attention to broader things. What is the state of jobs? What is the state of housing? What is the state of tech? What overseas potential conflicts could scare investors here? etc,etc,etc. If you have to trade, and you really dont, not every day, straddles on days with big news, or just before, or just after major events, are the best way to try to make some money.

Actually that is just following the GatesMcdonalds theory. It is better to have 3 locations doing each doing half of what one store in an area would do. Even though individual locations produce less, you are still up by one half a locations business. And it actually works this way. The more locations you have in an area the more total volume you do because you make it ever easier to get customers in your door. Family dollar and dollar tree are just following the related idea that being in an area of high competition retail space is better, because not only do you get the people coming to you, but also traffic that came to other retail outlets near to but didnt find what they wanted

You could buy shares and create synthetic shorts against part of the position if you want to be basically risk free. If you think merger will happen. 48 of your shares will be bought for 15. The other 52 will convert but might be worth more than 15, exactly 15 or less than 15, who knows. Here is an example of the above. Buy 1000 shares. You will get 15 for 480 of them. Buy 52 ATM puts and sell 52 ATM calls for some expiration next year maybe June. Long puts and short calls will act exactly like shorting stock. As the stock goes down, the long puts increase in value and the short calls decrease you sold these so thats good. This is called a synthetic short. You are effectively offsetting any losses and gains in 52 of your shares with the synthetic short options. You will sell the other 48. This maths out to somewhere around a 20 gain on your entire position of shares as long as the merger happens with no risk on the other part of the position. You also collect around a 2 dividend yield on the shares you hold. You can also sell 10 puts for next year sometime. The June 2025 10 puts are giving you premium that is around a 22.4 annualized return on the capital tied up.

Difference in price is because that is what the market is pricing on the odds of the deal falling through, shares getting watered down, there not being enough cash to satisfy all the folks who want the 15 payout rather than the new shares which will likely tank and get watered down even more within a year or so, current Biden regulators getting in the way, future HarrisTrump regulators getting in the way, maybe some other folks like Canadian regulators or EU getting in the way, folks suddenly backing out, lawyers finding something wrong with the terms, accountants finding something wrong with the books, Redstone deciding to 2x water down the shares, etcetcetc. And in all those cases it might not just be a Oh the deal is dead but Oh the deal will be pushed from 2025 to 2027. Either way there is never free money on wall street. 99 of the time youre taking some kind of risk for any kind of premium whether you know it or not.
There is a limit to how many shares will be tendered at 15. If its oversubscribed, you may only be able to sell a fraction of your shares at 15.

Its not an investment thesis, its a merger arb thesis. Its a risk of the merger not happening vs the profit you get if it does. It could be the worst company on earth to invest in but if the probability of merger was 99 then its a good trade if the reward is enough.

I took the 10 puts route, I have sold a large amount. I think that its very likely the merger happens and its not one that the US govt will try to block. I also think if the merger does not happen, PARA is actually way undervalued at 10. Both sides of the merger want it to happen. One possible issue is that shareholders sue because they think 15 is still too low for a buyout of their shares. I see worst case in that situation that the buyer raises the 15 price somewhat as it would still be a really good deal for them. Given the 4852 thing, you should assume that at merger close, PARA shares should trade at around 12.60 to reflect the 15 on only 48 of the shares risk.

Delta9 THC is federally legal now if it is less than .3 of a product by weight. So, if a piece of candy weighs 5 grams it could legally have up to 15 mg of Delta9 THC, which is even more than the standard 10 mg dose you see in most recreational dispensaries. The problem with this is that the Delta9 THC has to be synthesized from CBD or another legal cannabinoid, rather than just extracted from cannabis as its done in legal states. This creates a lot of opportunities for contaminants to enter the product.

If the Fed cuts it takes away the possibility that theyll hike or hold going forward. So its a very significant indicator of what will happen going forward and stocks are forward looking.
The rate hiking cycle started with a single 25 bps increase and turned into 500 bps. A single cut doesnt mean much, but its often the beginning of a cycle.

Something that a lot of posters in this sub seem to miss is that today, the stock market, especially the parts of it that move big, are highly speculative. And speculation is all about banking on potential. The reason why this cut is such a big deal is the same reason why future guidance often outweighs fundamentals like PE ratio theyre banking on the potential if the shifting trend continues. On the downside, it means the market is very hypedriven. On the upside, when it goes right, it goes very right. It also means you can be semisuccessful just playing on the hype, as long as you have the kind of free time needed to keep up with the changing winds.

All he basically said was that rate cuts would be ON THE TABLE in September if the data gives him more confidence that they are driving towards their 2 inflation goal. His statements are in no way a done deal that there will be a rate cut at the next fed meeting. The market is setting itself up for an upset.

Buy the rumor sell the news! Thats what I see happening... the markets going up up on the rumor but the fundamentals have shifted wildly from the initial euphoria of QE. Remember debt is still VERY high, and liquidity in the market is causing all these inflation tantrums. So its a conflicting situation of sorts. E.g. because of high liquidity, people are ready to pay a higher premium. High liquidity essentially came from the QE in 2020 along with money distribution to help people survive job losses and other economic situations, but spending was far more curtailed because no travel, no eating out, not much vacations etc. So people saved a lot and that along with the 2022 ramp up, and then 2023 eruption in jobs and salaries along with the tech boom. Salaries that were high due to corporations feeling good with their valuations, based on stock markets which were pumped up by way of liquidity flowing there too. Not to mention the real estate craziness that fed into the cycle of flipping buying buying, driven by remote work and incentives to work hybrid coz companies saw that there were much more benefits e.g. no more insurance to pay for employees turning up at work, etc.. So all in all, the market is coming to a reconciliation and the push higher imo is a strategy by funds and MMs to push to highs and then sell at those highs, and after seeing many stock market greed movies WOWS, its not totally unfounded for this behavior to continue because, it always goes up. Dump over!

Be careful!! UNG invests in Gas Futures Henry Hub. So that means it invests in gas delivered 12 months out. They sit currently at 2.1 or whatever. However, prices for JanFeb futures sit at 3.5. i suggest you read up on the term Contango. Basically, everything else equal, natgas front month could just tick up to 3.5 while UNG doesnt gain a single cent! Let that sink in. Put in other words Contango brings high rolling cost, when you change from front month to next, you can pay up. So while on the screen it shows you that gas is more expensive, UNG didnt increase. It just changed the contract. On the fundamental side there is a massive gas glut in US going on. Oil producers just do ,,drill baby drill because shale oil production is massively in the money. Those guys ger natgas as side product, so even if gas sits at 1.6, 1.7mmbtu, the guys keep drilling because oil pays for the side product to get rid off. Check out what happened in spring only around 1.61.7, gas producers started to shut in. Not before. Long story short if nothing fundamentally changes, the play is short natgas. If you bet on dropping oil prices, middle east escalation and massively hot in summer and cold in fallswinter, then you can do long natgas. Default play this year is short natgas.

When nat gas at historic lows earlier this year everyone knew the price would go up. The contango was 20 per month, so if nat gas goes up 10 in a month you still loose 10. UNG only holds the next month futures and rolls mid month. The actual contango hit usually doesnt happy until Henry Hub rolls at the end of the month. The volatility can be spectacular. Personally I trade the volatility and you absolutely cannot hold UNG long term. I typically hold a couple days to a week. Because of the contango drag all time lows on UNG are a common feature. If you perform technical analysis it must be done on the Henry Hub not UNG.

There is a somewhat likely longterm scenario where nat gas sees negative pricing. Im late to it and its been said already but nat gas prices are inversely correlated to crude prices. So when the price of oil is up high enough that operations ramp up, the natural biproduct of those operations natural gas sees a supply glut... There is only so much storage for this glut in supply, and the technologydemand for conversion to LNG cant keep up as of yet either. So as the demand for storage increases past the actual price of nat gas, nat gas prices turn negative. As long as this is a net positive for oil producers, they could care less about the biproduct. In the past nat gas would just be burnt off at the wells in these supply glut scenarios... but due to tighter regulation and fines for doing so that becomes an even more costly last resort.

I agree that Natural gas consumption is projected to increase due to its role as a bridge fuel in the energy transition. It offers lower emissions than coal, supports renewable energy integration, and meets growing energy demands in developing economies. Additionally, the expansion of LNG infrastructure is opening new markets, further driving global demand for natural gas. Longterm investment with a 11 correlation to natural gas prices is complicated due to the nature of available financial instruments. Most natural gas ETFs and funds invest in futures contracts, which are subject to contango and backwardation effects. These phenomena can cause significant tracking errors over time, as the funds must regularly roll over contracts, often at a loss. Additionally, the inherent volatility of commodity prices and the influence of various external factors like weather, geopolitics, and supplydemand dynamics make it difficult to maintain a consistent longterm correlation with spot prices Some alternatives Integrated energy companies Natural gas infrastructure stocks Utilities with natural gas exposure Natural gas equipment and services Energy ETF

Maybe the term I am using is confusingincorrect. The positions are long NG. Downside means unrealized losses. Each 50 cent move down generates 5,000 loss per contract. So, a 0.50 drop equals 5,000 unrealized loss on the first position. Then you enter position 2. So, another 0.50 drop equals a 10,000 unrealized loss on position 1 and a 5,000 dollar unrealized loss on position 2. Then you enter position 3. So, another 0.50 drop equals 15,000 unrealized loss on position 1, a 10,000 unrealized loss on position 2, and a 5,000 loss on position 4. Then you enter position 4. There the exercise stops and the total unrealized loss at this point is 15,000 10,000 5,000 30,000. If price goes down the unrealized loss continues to grow. EDIT 1 For further clarity, at the point of entry on position 4 the unrealized loss of only position 4 is 0.00, but the accumulated unrealized loss is 30,000.

Hmm, tough to say. So on the gas power trading side the holy grail is to handle the fact that power is extremely spiky because it cannot be stored effectively. i.e. if you have a slight mismatch between demand and supply, your grid trips withing milliseconds. Different markets and roles are designed to secure stable operations. But for a trader that results in super nasty math, especially with more and more renewables entering the game. Think of it this way Generation is of highly stochastic nature, e.g. sun shines or doesnt, you know basically 5 min ahead and can lose double digit generation in a few minutes same with wind. Demand is a bit more projectable, but still stochastic depending on temperature, holidays, events, grid trips, etc.. So you have random input, random output, random pricing, random trader behaviour, etc. in a pretty fragile system and illiquid market. The arms race there is predicting and interpreting weather better and be able to trade, dispatch and balance extremely fast. On gas its similar, a bit less dramatic because you can store and compress to a certain extent grid doesnt trip in milliseconds, but rather minutes or hours. But trading is very much coupled to power, so it brings the same challenges as all is connected through nasty feedbacks. On top the challenge for gas is the geopolitical mess. In LNG the worst I have worked with are flexible LNG cargos, so basically you have a physical option with floating strikes. Say you have a cargo LNG that is set for Japan, but you can reroute if its more profitable to send to Europe. You can think of it as an option with the strike being the difference between European and Japanese gas price, and on top of it the freight cost and fuel difference. All of this is variable. Now if you take such a decision momentarily, you can fix all of it and lock in the profit for rerouting. The challenge starts when you need to value such an option in the future, e.g. to know how much you are willing to sell it for or buy it for. Figuring that out I would say is one of the most secret sauce for an LNG operation. Just off the top of my head, no claim for completeness or anything and Im sure there are pros around here that can challenge me on all this.

Situation 1....your up 10 now in the positive and feeling that high so u continue to hold hoping for that 10 to turn into 20 30 40 100 etc. Maybe it goes up a bit mo4e from her3 but then starts to fall back and bleed if the sp starts to reverse again. CRWD currently provides the best endpoint security software out there at the moment from what Ive read, if youre a larger organisation, its the most secure easy to use product. In the industry and can confirm this. They are the closest thing to a Magic Bullet in endpoint security, as your organizations could be quite literally missing mostall other critical controls, inadequate staffing, incompetent employees, etc. and they will still have you covered. They absolutely fit the Clevel dream model of Cut a vendor a check and forget about it. Unfortunately, I quickly discovered two things. 1. Nobody had any idea how to do it and in some academic circles, even discussing got you labeled a crank and killed your funding. 2. I wrote a whitepaper, in 1993, that estimated the computational complexity of the human brain as exceeding an exaflop as a minimum and that supercomputers not PCs! were at least 2030 years away from being able to simulate that. Accounting for Moores Law. So, 1993 30 2023 and here we are, right on schedule. Isnt science amazing? 3. I still continued to follow the research and actively contributed to the late Chris McKinstry MindPixel opensource AGI project which ultimately failed and was abandoned. Then this happened... So, after 13 years, no measurable progress towards AGI and the suicide of two prominent researchers in quotes because neither of them actually produced anything that worked I decided to formally hang up my AGI hat and abandon it as a potential pursuit. That said, I still paid attention to the space AlphaGo was a big win for example and took a deep dive into LLMs in the Spring of 2023, which allowed me uncover OpenAIs secret frontier model. People who know what they are talking about never and I mean never just say page fault by itself, unless they are referring to the process of accessing virtual memory behind the scenes which is the almost universal context. If you meant a program generating an unhandled exception leading to a segfault, due to accessing memory they werent given access to by the OS, then anyone who knows what they are talking about, prepends invalid to page fault. But even then thats not really the language anyway, you sound like a noob. Heres a protip about yours truly. I never, ever, talk about anything unless I have checked my facts first. If you have ever done any Windows systems programming which I have and its obvious you havent, you would know they universally use that specific language in their kernel error codes. This is the error message from the Crowdstrike outage The PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA bug check has a value of 0x00000050. This indicates that invalid system memory has been referenced. Typically the memory address is wrong or the memory address is pointing at freed memory Source one of many and just the first hit I found Full list of BSOD error codes showing they exclusively use the language PAGE_FAULT when describing these cases This again shows your lack of even basic readinglanguage skills as an invalid page fault would be a doublenegative in this context and imply a valid access to memory. The correct usage would be A critical page fault kernel error is an invalid reference to system memory. Whereas an invalid page fault in a nonpaged area would be a valid reference to system memory. Im guessing you are so clueless that you dont understand the context of a PAGE FAULT has a different meaning when used in kernel error codes referencing nonpaged memory vs describing a page fault due to attempting to access virtual memory that has been swapped to disk. And these are logged as well as informational error codes. Ill add that a BSOD is desired behavior in this case as you dont want a bad kernel driver writing to random pages as that would lead to data corruption which is way worse. Second no, running in kernel space is not required. Running in user space and communicating with an OSprovided service running in kernel space made for that purpose, is the much safer albeit marginally slower way to do it. You are the posterboy for the DunningKruger Effect as you have just transparently telegraphed to me that you have literally zero experience working on forensic investigations involving APT threat actors or even have any experience working with NextGen EDR clients. Including specifically Crowdstrike, as they in particular do not market to zeroes like yourself. You dont know what the software actually does because you have never used it. First of all, Crowdstrike isnt exclusively an antivirus product. It operates as a kernel mode rootkit by design, as it can be configured to log extensive system information about all running processes. Such system calls, disknetwork access, etc. Second, you are absolutely, 100 correct that Microsoft could expose a safe usermode API to allow a system process running as Administrator to access all the same information. However, there is a big problem with that because the bad guys in general and APT actors in particular will write kernelmode rootkits that not only can trivially evade usermode detectionlogging, they can actively spoof systems calls and replace error codes see StuxNet for example. So instead of disabling the usermode EDR product which could be detected, they could hijack it and inject whatever they want via their kernel rootkit. So do shut up already with your droning claims of expertise already and go get a macbook, it will protect you from running thirdparty stuff in kernel mode by default. I think you need that. Already have one and I hate to break it to you but the vast majority of InfoSec peeps run nix. Either OsX or Linux. I have a windows gaming laptop, which is fine, but I dont use it for anything other than entertainment.

When problems overwhelm us and sadness smothers us, where do we find the will and the courage to continue? Well, the answer may come in the caring voice of a friend, a chance encounter with a book or from a personal faith For uWater897, help came from her faith but it also came from a squirrel Shortly after her divorce uWater897 lost her father. Then she lost her job, she had mounting money problems. But she not only survived. She worked her way out of despondency and now she says life is good again How could this happen? She told me that late one autumn day when she was at her lowest, she watched a squirrel storing up nuts for the winter. One at a time he would take them to the nest And she thought if that squirrel can take care of himself with a harsh winter coming on, so can I Once I broke my problems into small pieces I was able to carry them, just like those acorns, one at a time.

The door plug was removed at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, last September so that problems with some rivets could be repaired. But the necessary paperwork for that temporary door plug removal was apparently never created. So when workers replaced the door plug temporarily, other workers were unaware that bolts needed to be reinstalled, said Elizabeth Lund, senior vice president of quality for Boeing Commercial Airplanes. It sounds simple enough. We need to fix these rivets, door plug is in the way, remove it and do the work. Why in the hell they decided to not my job putting it back right is bonkers to me. I get torque specs, etc, but they should have just left it out no? I mean, its not their job to install it right, but they totally can remove it since the door plug team was completely unaware and did not do it for them. I know its common in the trades to mess up someone else work that is in your way, but you freaking leave it apart for them to fix, you dont hide the crap.

Ive worked at MRO facilities that help repair the planes at the airports when the airliners want to save money, instead of getting the manufacturer like embraer or boeing to repair it. There are numerous issues in my brief stint there, but they are similar to the first rollout when the plane is being built. There is a lack of talented blue collar workers to do the repairsinstall because they are underpaid and literally undocumented hispanic workers. The actual MODMRB engineers that do the analysis are understaffed but typically have to be on call whenever a plane is grounded. The Damage tolerance team is on call basically 247 with rotating shifts and regularly gets woken up to handle shit. There is not enough organization in documentation and SOP to do the repair according to a manual. Especially when every airline has their own manual that they want you to download from airbus world but the manual is just a scanned pdf with no ctrlf capabilities whatsoever. Everyone is just out for themselves, trying to do the least amount of work as possible, while goofing off, and just caring about blowing their next pitiful paycheck on some fds or something. This creates a culture of keeping your head down and not caring about documentation, and definitely not trying to improve something when there is a deficiency in accountability. So there likely never was any paperwork made, the person that did the install likely doesnt work there anymore due to turnover, and the manager probably was never even aware that this person existed.

The amount of times Ive been presented with incomplete paperwork and am told just BS it is also way too high. A lot of management at other companies just dont care because the necessary papertrail requires a ton of time and slows every aspect of production down. We get audited annually but the audits dont do any digging. They ask for a random batch of jobs and as long as everything is filled out they assume it was done properly meaning the individual process and inspection steps on the travelers are filled out and complete prior to that part moving on to the next step. People are lazy and dont care and since there is no accountability its becoming common work culture to just BS the papertrail. FAA parts have such high requirements that if a door fell off a boeing jet 5 years after it was built the FAA should be able to reach out to boeing and know within a day exactly who had hands on that part, for what step, and at exactly what time, from the first ply of material to the last nut and bolt every single aspect of the manufacturing of that part is supposed to be recording. The FAA expects to be able to point a very accurate finger at the exact person responsible for that step anytime something goes wrong. For example if I forgot to install a bolt the papertrail would say that and myself and the QA inspector responsible could potentially be sued by the FAA or criminally charged for not adhering to their policies. The fact they cant provide this is insane to me. Weve had failures that the FAA has reached out to us about and within a few minutes of pulling the paper work we are able to tell them every single piece of information they want. Its an obnoxious amount of paperwork and a real hassle but when it comes to commercial aircraft its pretty fucking necessary. The FAA needs to know which exact person in the company was responsible for the failure so they can hold that person and the company responsible.

Its called an ODA, and its a pretty standard thing throughout aviation. The FAA just isnt well funded enough to have oversight over every operation, so it delegates authority. There are individuals who are authorized to approve data DERs or entire company organizations to basically act as their own FAA ODAs. In this case, Boeing, like every big US aviation outfit, has their own ODA. Not saying its right or wrong, just that ODAs have been a thing for a long time and are standard. Source Aerospace engineer for over a decade
For things like aircraft it is necessary, too much can go wrong

The reason NVDA dominates is not because of their chips its because of their parallel processing library called CUDA. CUDA powers almost every ML models you interact with today. The models truly dont care what hardware they use, but they cant wont use AMD because their CUDA competitor library called ROCm is trash. ROCm is, at the very least 1 Massively inefficient when compared to CUDA 2 Incompatible with most major libraries, such as Cafe, TensorFlow, etc. 3 Only works on a very limited number of AMD cards, most of which are not consumer facing 4 Been very slow to roll out bug fixes, improvements and compatibility updates. They need to fix their software first, and popular libraries need to integrate it. Once we see some improvements and more integrations with ROCm, then maybe models will actually use the AMD chips. Before then, AMD chips are basically as useful as sand for AI.

Alright genius, when AMD bought Xilinx, they had to account for the purchase in their financial statements. This involves amortizing spreading out certain costs over time, which reduces their reported GAAP earnings. Lower GAAP earnings make the PE ratio look higher than it actually is. But, this amortization is just an accounting move that helps AMD save on taxes. It doesnt mean AMD is making less money its just a way to reduce their tax bill by showing lower profits on paper. Yes, the use of chiplets in AMDs MI300 design is a significant factor in enabling the production of advanced chips without substantially increasing the complexity of the packaging. Heres how chiplets contribute to this advantage 1. Modular Design Chiplets allow AMD to design and manufacture smaller, modular components that can be combined into a single package. This modularity simplifies the design process because each chiplet can be optimized individually. 2. Yield Improvement Manufacturing smaller chiplets can lead to higher yields compared to producing a single large monolithic die. This is because defects in smaller chiplets affect a smaller portion of the overall product, reducing waste and costs. 3. Scalability Chiplets enable AMD to scale performance by adding more chiplets to a package, allowing them to create more powerful chips without designing entirely new monolithic dies. This approach offers flexibility in meeting different performance and power requirements. 4. Integration of Different Technologies With chiplets, AMD can integrate different types of technologies e.g., CPU, GPU, memory, specialized accelerators within a single package. This heterogenous integration can enhance performance and efficiency while keeping packaging complexity manageable. 5. Interconnect Efficiency Advanced interconnect technologies like AMDs Infinity Fabric allow chiplets to communicate efficiently with each other, maintaining high performance while simplifying the design of the interconnects within the package. 6. Cost and Time Efficiency By reusing existing chiplet designs and integrating them into new products, AMD can reduce both the cost and time required to bring new products to market. This approach leverages existing investments in design and manufacturing processes. Overall, the chiplet approach enables AMD to create advanced, highperformance chips like the MI300 while maintaining manageable levels of packaging complexity, improving yields, and offering greater flexibility and scalability.
